title: Brooklyn Beckham pictured just hours wedding actress Nicola Peltz
story: Share this articleExude elegance like Victoria in a dress from her own collectionClick to buyWho better to showcase Victoria Beckham&#39s latest designs than the frontwoman herself?The singer-turned-designer&#39s beautiful dress has topped our wish list. Cut from an organic cotton-blend, it incorporates a square neckline, contrast straps and A-line skirt to create an elegant aesthetic.Love the look as much as we do? Click the product image to add Victoria&#39s dress to your basket. It retails for ¬£590, so might be pricier than your usual dress spend, but you&#39re bound to hold on to a piece like this forever.Alternatively, head to the carousel, where you&#39ll find gorgeous lookalikes by H&ampM, Reformation, &amp Other Stories and Staud. Prices start at just ¬£19.99. If you&#39re feeling spendy, why not treat yourself to her Bottega Veneta bag too?MailOnline may earn commission on sales from these product linksBottega Veneta chain bag at SelfridgesReformation &#39Vinny&#39 dress at NET-A-PORTERStaud &#39Wells&#39 dress at MyTheresa&amp Other Stories cut-out dress (now reduced to ¬£52.50)   BILLIONAIRE BRIDEBrooklyn and Nicola started dating in October 2019, after being introduced by Sofia Richie, the model daughter of singer Lionel.They went public in January 2020 and the engagement was announced in July the same year and sealed with a ¬£160,000 emerald-cut diamond ring.The pair are said to have signed a pre-nuptial agreement, meaning that they will exit the marriage with whatever they took into it should romance fade.¬†Nicola is the youngest of eight siblings, and one of three children by Claudia Heffner Peltz, Nelson Peltz‚Äôs third wife.She was a tomboy who dreamed of playing hockey for a living until she took a drama class when she was 12.Her screen debut was in a Miley Cyrus pop video when she was 13.Aged 15, she was cast as Katara in the 2010 fantasy adventure, The Last Airbender.She is best known for her role as Mark Wahlberg‚Äôs daughter in Transformers: Age Of Extinction. She has since appeared in the TV series Inhumans.Her exes include pop star Justin Bieber, whom she dated briefly in 2016, and Anwar Hadid, the brother of supermodels Gigi and Bella.They split ‚Äòamicably‚Äô after a year, but she unfollowed him and his entire family on Instagram after he was pictured kissing model Kendall Jenner.It has been widely speculated that she is the ‚ÄòHollywood mean girl‚Äô described by actress Bella Thorne in a 2015 interview.In it she said: ‚ÄòI have a mean girl. She‚Äôs in the business, and she‚Äôs very, very mean. I stay away from her at all costs.I never say hello to her. ‚ÄòHer siblings are not mean like she is. It‚Äôs just her. One of the reasons I don‚Äôt like her is because she‚Äôs been a billionaire since she was very little, and she‚Äôs never had to work for anything in her life.‚ÄôThorne knows Peltz because her boyfriend Gregg Sulkin also co-starred in the film Affluenza with Nicola Peltz in 2014.Nicola has never commented on the speculation.

title: Newly eligible voters likely Instagram visit ballot box survey shows
story: Share this article 'It can increase your chances of getting credit. Many young adults may be virtually invisible to the financial system because there's not enough information available to lenders about them.'Figures from the past three general elections suggest that people are more likely to vote as they get older, according to the British Election Study.The average turnout for 18 to 34-year-olds is around 50 per cent compared to just over 80 per cent for those aged 65 and above.Experian datasets found 227,087 young people who became eligible to vote in 2021 were on the electoral roll, compared to 657,356 who used Instagram at least once a month.Estimates of voter turnout among those aged between 18 to 24 dropped from 54 per cent in the 2017 General Election to 47 per cent when Boris Johnson won a landslide majority in 2019.

title: uk jobless rate wage squeeze inactivity inflation us stock markets business live
story: The TUC say today‚Äôs data shows the sharpest monthly fall in public sector real wages on record, and are urging the government to help. This trend is being driven by older workers, says Jake Finney, economist at PwC, with the 50-64 group accounting for more than half of this increase since the pandemic started. Resolution Foundation agrees, saying ‚ÄòCovid retirees‚Äô are leaving their jobs. This chart shows the rise in long-term sickness (the lime-green columns). Stephen Evans, chief executive of Learning and Work Institute, says some people are leaving to care for others, as well as retiring or being ill themselves. But, Pat McFadden MP, Labour‚Äôs shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, highlights that last month‚Äôs spring statement failed to give as much support as hoped for strugging households. That reflects the jump in banker bonuses, after business boomed in 2021. Here‚Äôs his summary on the jobs report: That suggests that firms have been raising wages to attract and retain staff, as workers are hit by rising prices. The UK‚Äôs unemployment rate has dropped further below its pre-pandemic levels as employers struggle to hire staff, and more people drop out of the labour force. This increase was driven by those who are economically inactive because they are looking after family or home, retired, or long-term sick, the ONS explains. Companies did add more staff, with 35,000 more people in payrolled employment in March than in February. But while the number of full-time employees increased during the latest three-month period, this was offset by a decrease in part-time employees, as this chart shows: Job vacancies hit a new record over the quarter, jumping to 1,288,000. But the rate of growth in vacancies continued to slow down. There were 50,200 new openings added in January to March 2022 compared with the previous quarter, the slowest rise in almost a year. The largest increase was in human health and social work, which increased by 13,100 to a new record of 215,500 vacancies. More details to follow.... That would be the fastest pace since 1981, and probably spur the Federal Reserve to raise US interest rates aggressively over the coming months. Economists now expect half-point hikes in both May and June. We also get the latest economic confidence index for Germany from the ZEW institute, which will show the impact of the Ukraine war on investors.

title: d%C3%BAn laoghaire rathdown council faces government intervention over move to block homes
story: Minister of State for local government Peter Burke has been asked to issue formal directions to the council compelling it to take action over breaches of  recommendations.  Photograph: Tom HonanD√∫n Laoghaire-Rathdown County Council is facing a Government intervention over its contentious move to block new homes being built in the south Dublin suburbs of Killiney and Dalkey, as a row intensifies over the future of some of the most valuable lands in the State.Planning regulators objected to the ban, arguing it was ‚Äúan unnecessary restriction‚Äù on sustainable development. But councillors refused to remove the measure from their 2022-28 development plan, in defiance of the regulator‚Äôs statutory recommendations to overturn it. Now regulator Niall Cussen has asked Minister of State for local government Peter Burke to issue formal directions to the council compelling it to take action over breaches of such recommendations. The development plan says ‚Äúsignificant parts‚Äù of Dalkey and Killiney are characterised by low density development, adding that ‚Äúno increase in the number of residential buildings will normally be permitted‚Äù in some areas. In correspondence to the Minister late last week, Mr Cussen has also asked him to issue directions over new restrictions on buy-to-let apartments in the development plan. The regulator opposed measures that require three-bedroom apartments to be built in 40 per cent of the units in build-to-rent schemes in ‚Äúnew residential communities‚Äù.Mr Burke is understood to be preparing to issue draft directions on both counts in coming days, meaning the matter will go back to the council. That move essentially means the council will have to reopen the development plan it adopted last month, after 18 months of debate.The Office of the Planning Regulator (OPR) was established in 2019 to provide independent oversight of the planning process. One of its functions is to assess development plans to ensure they properly apply national policies.City and county councils around the State are in the process of adopting a new wave of development plans, which sets the framework for housing and other developments for the rest of the decade.Mr Cussen‚Äôs call for a ministerial direction in the D√∫n Laoghaire-Rathdown plan is his sixth. He previously asked the Minister to intervene in the plans of Cork County Council and the councils in Kilkenny, Laois, Meath and Westmeath. Asked about the regulator‚Äôs decision on its plan, D√∫n Laoghaire-Rathdown council said any notification seeking a ministerial direction goes to the Minister and not it as the planning authority. ‚ÄúThe Minister then has two weeks in which to issue notice of any intention to issue a direction to the planning authority. That further two-week period has not yet passed,‚Äù the council said.The regulator‚Äôs office had no comment on its decision, which follows a four-week review of the development plan. Any ministerial direction ‚Äúcommences a process by the local authority, including public consultation, after which the OPR further considers the matter with a view to recommending, or not, that the Minister issue a final direction‚Äù on the plan.‚ÄúThe OPR works proactively with local authorities in the deliberations on their plans to ensure the best outcomes for communities which are consistent with regional and national planning policies.‚ÄùStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: frances populist revolt coming
story: What did they mean by that? The French public has delivered a first-round result in their presidential election that leaves political nerds unable to reach a consensus about where events are likely to go from here.On the one hand, a four-point margin for the incumbent Emmanuel Macron over Marine Le Pen was bigger than some polls had predicted. The Western world‚Äôs ‚Äúcentrist dad‚Äù brigade might have been inclined to breathe a sigh of relief and claim there is no discernible path to victory for Madame Le Pen in the second-round run-off in a fortnight‚Äôs time.But the centrist dads have been wrong before ‚Äì about Brexit, about Donald Trump and about Britain‚Äôs 2019 general election, to cite just a few recent examples. There is at least as strong a case for looking at yesterday‚Äôs result and concluding that the establishment-minded centre cannot hold and that it is now not a question of whether there will be a populist Right takeover of the apparatus of government in France, but merely of when.For a start, there is a simple comparison to be made with the first-round vote of five years ago. Back then the charismatic insurgent Macron won 24 per cent, to Le Pen‚Äôs 21 per cent. Half a decade has added an unspectacular two or three percentage points to the vote shares of both and the same to Jean-Luc Melenchon, the far-Left populist who scored 19.5 per cent five years ago and 22 per cent last night.But look at what has happened to the traditional establishment parties of centre-Left and centre-Right, the Socialists and the Republicans. Five years ago the former was thought to be at its lowest possible ebb when its candidate won just six per cent, while the latter was deeply disappointed with a 20 per cent share. Last night those scores slumped to two per cent and five per cent respectively.So France is in a vigorously anti-establishment mood and it is hard to see how five years of incumbency and presidential peacocking will enable Macron to harness that as well as he did in 2017. There is a widespread feeling that he is a ‚Äúpresident of the rich‚Äù with an entourage dominated by privileged young Parisians swanning around in made-to-measure suits and harbouring luxury liberal beliefs.Le Pen, by contrast, has sought out the populist sweet spot of being to the Right on cultural issues and to the Left on economic ones. Her campaign has taken her around the market towns of France, speaking to the common people who formed the bulk of the ‚ÄúGilet Jaune‚Äù protestors and who care more about the price of petrol than the high politics of EU summits or even the suffering of Ukraine.In the first round this time, Le Pen has not only established a strong lead among working class voters but also among the young, with a radical plan to scrap income tax for the under-30s being the core of of her economic offering.Macron himself appears to understand that he will not win the run-off as a conventional capital city centrist given the current public mood and last night pledged to represent the aspirations of those who voted for Le Pen and her fellow Right populist Eric Zemmour, the bulk of whose seven per cent vote share is surely currently heading her way.The decisive factor now will be where the voters of Melenchon end up. Many despise the values of the Paris-based elites just as much as Le Pen‚Äôs supporters do and many also are firmly traditionalist on social and cultural matters. Last night Melenchon did Macron a favour by urging them not to vote for Le Pen, though he could not bring himself to endorse the French president.The next two weeks will see French elites attempt to kill Le Pen‚Äôs ambitions in the usual way ‚Äì using her surname and previous leadership of the Front National against her, as well as her unwise past praise for Vladimir Putin, in a bid to persuade voters that she is simply not a respectable choice.But Macron himself seems to understand that, barring Le Pen malfunctioning disastrously again in a televised debate as she did last time, this will not be enough. During his first term Macron has tried hard to keep onboard voters who are anxious about the state of French society and has made a series of speeches about enforcing integration into the French way of life for migrant communities.If he holds on in two weeks‚Äô time ‚Äì as he is just about favourite to do ‚Äì it will surely be because he remains a sufficiently canny campaigner to keep one foot in the populist camp himself rather than because the French public are gravitating back towards establishment norms.Nobody expects anything like the crushing two-to-one drubbing he gave Le Pen in the run-off last time. Even if they beat her this time, how the French establishment would fend her off again in 2027 is very difficult to see.More from NewsPrincess Anne greeted by traditional performances at Papua New Guinea schoolPolitics latest news: Crispin Blunt under pressure to withdraw claimRussia-Ukraine latest news: All options on table if Russia uses chemical weapons in Ukraine, minister warnsBritons facing &#3912 months&#39 of travel delays due to staff shortagesLondon local elections 2022: When are they, why is this year significant and how to vote?Local Elections 2022: What is up for election, where, and how to voteMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: gallery highlights male gaze manet masterpiece woke attempt
story: The ‚Äúmale gaze‚Äù in a Manet masterpiece has been highlighted by the Courtauld Gallery after curators introduced new labels addressing ‚Äúmisogyny‚Äù in art.The London gallery, which holds the UK‚Äôs foremost Impressionist collection, reviewed the labelling of all of its paintings as part of a three-year, ¬£57 million refurbishment. Some information panels now address issues like artists‚Äô racism and sexism.Manet's masterpiece, A Bar at the Folies-Berg√®re, has been reinterpreted with a new label which suggests that the painting has an ‚Äúunsettling‚Äù quality, because of the presence of a man on the canvas.The 1882 work depicts a barmaid staring out at the viewer of the painting and - in a mirrored image - towards a male patron of the eponymous Folies-Berg√®re (a Parisian cabaret club) who returns her gaze.The female subject‚Äôs ‚Äúenigmatic expression is unsettling‚Äù, a new information panel states, ‚Äúespecially as she appears to be interacting with a male customer‚Äù.The suggestion that an ‚Äúunsettling‚Äù quality of the painting is enhanced because the woman talking to a man has been criticised for unwitting ‚Äúmisogyny‚Äù, because it diminishes the position of the female model in the work.Ruth Millington, a historian whose book Muse chronicles the female inspirations for great art, said: ‚ÄúIt completely shifts the viewer‚Äôs attention away from her and onto the man in the picture.‚ÄúThis interpretation, in a woke attempt to call out misogyny, unwittingly centres the male gaze.¬†The writer implies that the woman is unsettled by the man‚Äôs presence, framing her as a passive victim of her circumstances.‚ÄúCurators must stop trapping female muses and models with male-centred interpretations such as this.‚ÄúIn a painting of multiple gazes, it‚Äôs unfair and misogynistic to emphasise the male perspective. I‚Äôd rather read a fresh new label which invites viewers to imagine what the woman is thinking.‚ÄùThe model Manet used for the painting was a real-life woman called Suzon who worked at the Folies-Berg√®re, a venue frequented where prostitutes plied their trade, and it has been suggested that a subtext of the painting is the exploited barmaid‚Äôs availability to male customers, along with the alcohol she is selling.The Courtauld holds the UK‚Äôs leading collection of Gauguin works, but the French painter known for his time in Tahitian subjects - and teenage brides - ¬†has now been reappraised by curators for ‚Äútaking advantage of his position as a European coloniser‚Äù.A label on his Post-Impressionist work Nevermore states the painting depicts ‚Äúone of several teenagers that he took on as ‚Äòwives‚Äô‚Äù, adding that ‚Äúthe widespread racist fantasy of Tahitian girls as sexually precocious led to their unabashed exploitation‚Äù.An information panel for his 1897 painting Te Rerioa now informs visitors that its subject matter was intended to ‚Äúappeal to a white European audience‚Äù by ‚Äúexoticising‚Äù Polynesians.Further information on Gauguin‚Äôs memoir Avant et Apres - recently acquired by the Courtauld - states that the 213-page manuscript is ‚Äúpeppered with examples of his own racism and misogyny‚Äù.The treatment of other cultures as ‚Äúprimitive‚Äù has also been addressed in a new label for the self-portrait of Roger Fry, the Bloomsbury group painter, known for his advancement of Gauguin-inspired ‚ÄúPrimitivism‚Äù in Western art.Updated information on the portrait states: ‚ÄúFor modernist artists and writers, African art belonged to an earlier stage of civilisation known as ‚Äúprimitivism ‚Äú‚ÄúThis reveals the reactive ideas of the time, which underpinned even the views of progressives like Fry.‚ÄùThe Courtauld‚Äôs relabelling comes following widespread reassessment of problematic artists, with the Picasso Museum in Paris recently inviting artists to critique the painter‚Äôs personal life, and the National Gallery highlighting Gauguin‚Äôs sexual proclivities in a 2019 show.Manet has also faced reappraisal over works like Olympia, a bold nude that scandalised the Paris Salon in 1865, and which has invited more recent criticism at the Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay for its sidelining of a black woman in the painting.The Courtauld has been contacted for comment.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: All options on table if Russia uses chemical weapons in Ukraine, minister warnsPrincess Anne greeted by traditional performances at Papua New Guinea schoolPolitics latest news: Crispin Blunt under pressure to withdraw claimBritons facing &#3912 months&#39 of travel delays due to staff shortagesLondon local elections 2022: When are they, why is this year significant and how to vote?Local Elections 2022: What is up for election, where, and how to voteMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: spare easter motorists misery issuing national injunction oil
story: Injunction applications are being prepared by ministers to halt environmental protesters targeting oil supplies in an attempt to head off Easter travel chaos.Suella Braverman, the Attorney General, is understood to have held a meeting with ministers on Monday night as they drew up plans with local councils for a series of injunctions to target the key activists.It is expected inidual injunctions will be served within days on the key protesters who have been holding up fuel supplies by targeting three crucial depots in Warwickshire, Hertfordshire and Essex. They also blocked two central London bridges on Sunday in a series of ‚Äúdangerous‚Äù stunts.Holidaymakers fleeing London for the Easter weekend face a double-whammy of environmental protests and rail upgrade works.¬†After a week of delays and cancellations at airports and ferry ports, Extinction Rebellion is planning to bring parts of central London to a standstill over the weekend.¬†Emergency plans are being drawn up for UK airports, with border guards from Scotland and Northern Ireland offered bonuses to work at Heathrow security desks.¬†Lucy Moreton, of the Immigration Service Union, said backroom staff who normally check prohibited items will be on the front lines to prevent disruption.¬†She told The Daily Mail: ‚ÄúThey get expenses and overtime and they‚Äôre being offered a cash bonus for each shift they cover at Heathrow. Some passengers will sail through, but others could be looking at several hours in a queue. It won‚Äôt be chaos universally but there will be patches.‚ÄùLabour on Monday called for immediate nationwide injunctions, similar to those that brought a halt to Insulate Britain protests on motorways and roads across England.Steve Reed, Labour‚Äôs shadow justice secretary, said the Government needed ‚Äúto stop standing idly by and put an end to this disruption that is causing misery for motorists.‚ÄùSome 1,200 out of 8,378 pumps are shut, with one in three petrol stations in southern England forced to close, according to Campaign for Fair Fuel.The chaos by activists from Just Stop Oil comes ahead of a record 21.5 million motorists preparing to take to the roads this coming Easter weekend.Downing Street signalled the crackdown on Monday morning when the Prime Minister‚Äôs deputy spokesman said: ‚ÄúProtest is a cornerstone of our democracy but we will not tolerate guerilla tactics that disrupt people going about their day-to-day business.‚ÄùThe spokesman added: ‚ÄúWe fully support the police who are putting significant resources into their response to the demonstrations.‚ÄùEssex Police has arrested more than 350 protesters since the disruption started on April 1 but the campaign group said some of its activists were still locked on to pipework at an oil terminal in Grays on Monday.Warwickshire Police said there had been 34 arrests over the weekend linked to protests at the Kingsbury oil terminal, where protesters have tunnelled under a major access route.Two of the eco-activists ‚Äì Nathan McGovern, 22, and Louis McKechnie, 21 ‚Äì posted a video in which they talk about having been chained to pipes at the Grays oil depot for more than a day and breathing in asbestos as a result.‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been up here over 30 hours, haven‚Äôt slept, haven‚Äôt felt safe, had a panic attack a while back, it‚Äôs really uncomfortable,‚Äù said McKechnie.Ministers hope to emulate their eventual success against Insulate Britain, which saw protesters jailed for breaching the nationwide injunction introduced by the Government.Rachel Nolan, Essex‚Äôs assistant chief constable, said: ‚ÄúAnyone who attends any location and wants to conduct a peaceful protest in a public area will be allowed to do so in a responsible, respectful and meaningful way.‚ÄúBut we have been dealing with people who are trespassing into restricted areas holding flammable chemicals, posing dangers to themselves and others and it‚Äôs totally unacceptable.‚ÄùThe force said that policing protests in Thurrock has cost Essex Police ‚Äúin excess of ¬£1 million‚Äù.At the same time, campaigners have also urged Network Rail and Transport for London to ‚Äúget real‚Äù over their ‚Äúcrackers‚Äù plan to upgrade parts of the network during the busiest weekend for travel since the start of the pandemic.Network Rail is carrying out 530 upgrade projects over the bank holiday weekend, including HS2 works at London Euston.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: All options on table if Russia title: britons facing 12 months travel delays due staff shortages
story: Travellers are facing up to 12 months of delays at Britain‚Äôs airports and ports as the travel industry struggles to recruit enough people to fill vacancies, industry experts have warned.Kully Sandhu, the managing director of the Aviation Recruitment Network, told the BBC‚Äôs Today Programme that it will take ‚Äúat least the next 12 months for the industry, vacancy wise, to settle down.‚ÄùThousands of people heading abroad for the Easter holidays have been warned they face long queues, delays and cancellations.Manchester Airport, along with others, has warned that long waits at security could continue as it struggles with staff shortages, with some passengers facing queues of 60 to 90 minutes over the next few weeks.Industry leaders have said the lack of staff is the primary cause of the issue, the both the pandemic and Brexit leading to a shortage of workers.‚ÄúBrexit has not helped because we had a natural attraction of iniduals from the European market who would apply for vacancies in UK airports. We no longer have that talent pool, and we are relying on iniduals in the UK,‚Äù Mr Sandhu told the BBC.¬†‚ÄúIt makes it very difficult for recruiters to recruit these iniduals because we are all fighting for the same type of candidates.‚ÄùThose returning to the UK this week will also face the misery of long queues as Border Force have warned they too have a lack of staff available to check inbound passengers.Lucy Moreton, the General Secretary of the Immigration Services Union, told the BBC that the agency was struggling with a chronic shortage of officers.‚ÄúFor the first time in living memory, Border Force isn‚Äôt attracting the number of candidates to fill the vacancies they‚Äôve got,‚Äù she said.Ms Moreton warned that this, combined with the particularly large numbers of people travelling over the school holidays, would mean ‚Äúthe queues will move from security based outbound, to Border Force based coming in.‚ÄùLast month, Heathrow Airport recorded its busiest month since the start of the coronavirus pandemic, with 4.2 million passengers passing through the terminal, an eight-fold increase from the same month in 2021.¬†That figure is expected to rise again this month owing to the Easter holidays as well as the government‚Äôs removal of all pandemic-era travel restrictions.However, both Mr Sandhu and Ms Moreton rejected calls for security checks to be loosened during the hiring process, saying the checks were vital to protect the UK‚Äôs national security.‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt expect your police officer to be incompletely trained or not security cleared and we certainly wouldn‚Äôt want anything else for Border Force.‚Äù¬†‚ÄúMore resources would enable those checks to get through quicker, but we can‚Äôt cut corners on the training so we are looking at a very difficult summer.‚ÄùMore from NewsPrincess Anne greeted by traditional performances at Papua New Guinea schoolPolitics latest news: Crispin Blunt under pressure to withdraw claimRussia-Ukraine title: river oxford becomes second england achieve bathing water status
story: A stretch of the Thames will become the second designated river bathing spot in England after record levels of support.¬†The Wolvercote Mill Stream in north Oxford will be regularly monitored for harmful bacterial levels during the swimming season between May and September.¬†The decision came after a campaign by locals who want the monitoring to lead to cleaner water at the spot.¬†The consultation had 1,267 responses, with just seven not in favour of designating the site, a record level.¬†The river has an average of 46 swimmers a day during the peak season, but tests have found levels of e-coli bacteria exceeding the threshold level for safe bathing water quality.The designation does not guarantee clean water, but is expected to put pressure on Thames Water and local landowners to stop pollutants entering the area and will enable locals to know when it is safe to swim.¬†A 2021 study of local river water quality found no stretch of water in Oxford would be classified as fit for bathing, with the main cause being raw sewage overflows.¬†Raw sewage was discharged for over 1,500 hours from five overflow locations in Oxford, according to data from the Environment Agency.¬†England has only one other river with designated bathing status, a stretch of the River Wharfe at Ilkley, West Yorkshire, which was rated ‚Äúpoor‚Äù for water quality after tests in January found evidence of human and animal bacteria.¬†Claire Robertson, Oxford Rivers Project Officer at Thames21, said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm overjoyed this designation is going ahead. This stretch of river is a regularly used and treasured place for hundreds of people - families, swimmers, kayakers, rowers, anglers, birdwatchers - and a home for many other creatures, and this is the very least it deserves.‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to working locally with Thames Water and other partners to ensure the water quality improves, and nationally to help other groups protect their local rivers.‚ÄùThe East Cowes Esplanade on the Isle of Wight will be added to the list of designated bathing spots, which includes coastal waters.¬†MPs have called for water companies to ensure that at least one stretch of river in each of their areas is monitored by 2025.Polling for The  earlier this year found that more than 80 per cent of people expect to be able to safely swim in a local river, despite officials from the Environment Agency insisting they are not intended for human use.‚ÄúWhile bathing water quality has improved in recent years and England now has the cleanest bathing waters since records began, we know that water quality at these sites won‚Äôt change overnight.¬†‚ÄúIt will take time and all those with a role to play must commit to achieve the necessary improvements,‚Äù said Rebecca Pow, Environment Minister.‚ÄúWe are continuing to drive up the quality of lakes, rivers and seas for the public to enjoy through the measures in our Environment Act, and I would encourage more applications for popular bathing areas, both inland and coastal, that may also be suitable for designation.‚ÄùMore from NewsPrincess Anne greeted by traditional performances at news politics -questions-rishi-sunak-must-"Rishi Sunak faces a whole list of concerns amid tax rowByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsCrisis-hit Rishi Sunak will undergo an investigation by the Prime Ministeraposs sleaze watchdog as he battles to save his political career. Downing Street confirmed that Boris Johnson had ordered his ethics adviser Lord Geidt to probe the Chancelloraposs conduct after a request from Mr Sunak himself.Mr Sunakaposs family finances have been in the spotlight after it emerged that his we Akshata Murty had non-domicile tax status, allowing her to legally avoid paying UK taxes on overseas income. She U-turned on Friday to save her husbandaposs job by vowing to pay UK tax on herforeign income, which includes an estimated ¬£. million-a-year in shares from the Indian IT giant Infosys - founded by her billionaire father Narayana Murty. Mr Sunak attempted to defuse the row by asking Lord Geidt to investigate, as he said he was confident he had declared everything properly. The Prime Ministeraposs deputy spokeswoman said: Iaposm not aware of whether Lord Geidt himself has begun his work. But I can confirm that the Prime Minister has agreed to the request from the Chancellor for Lord Geidt to undertake this work. Here are some of the questions the Chancellor needs to clear up. How much has his we saved in UK tax through non-dom status  Mr Sunakaposs nightmare week began when it emerged that his we held non-dom status, potentially saving her millions of pounds in tax. The arrangement, which is legal, allows people who are domiciled abroad to avoid paying UK tax on their overseas income. Her spokeswoman initially tried to claim it was because she was an Indian citizen but she then admitted that Ms Murty paid the British Government ¬£,-a-year to keep the status.Ms Murty was forced to into a U-turn on Friday and said she would now pay UK tax on her foreign income. This includes a .% stake in Indian IT giant Infosys, founded by her billionaire father Naranya Murty. Her share is worth an estimated ¬£ million and provides around ¬£. million in idends per year. Under non-dom rules, Ms Murty was not obliged to pay UK tax on this income - and it is unclear how big her tax bill could have been.The BBC estimated she would have saved ¬£. million in UK tax based on these figures.Ms Murty remains domiciled in India where she eventually wants to . What did Rishi Sunak declare about it  Mr Sunak is understood to have declared his weaposs tax status to the Cabinet Office when he first became a minister in . Sources said the Treasury was also aware, so as to manage any potential conflicts of interest. However, what happened after he made the declaration is not clear, because her status is not on his public declaration of ministerial interests.  Mr Sunak has asked for Lord Geidt to review all his declarations of interest since he became a minister in  to ensure they had been properly stated. He said he was confident he had acted appropriately at all times, but his overriding concern was that the public should have confidence in the answers. Guidance to ministers says the list is not an account of all the interests or financial arrangements held by a Minister or members of their close family, adding: Rather it is a list of any such interests, which are, or might reasonably be perceived to be, directly relevant to that particular minister‚Äôs public duties. Why did he hold a US green card until last year  Mr Sunak confirmed on Friday that he held a US green card for more than a year while he was Chancellor. A spokeswoman said he sought guidance ahead of his first US trip in a Government capacity in October - despite taking on the top Treasury job in February . People with green cards are treated as lawful permanent residents by US tax authorities, and it is seen as a step towards full citizenship.  Mr Sunakaposs spokeswoman said he filed US tax s, but specically as a non-resident, in full compliance with the law. The Sunaks met at Stanford University and worked in the US before moving to the UK to pursue Mr Sunakaposs political career. They are understood to have a holiday home in Calornia.At a Downing Street press conference, Boris Johnson said he was unaware of Mr Sunak holding a US green card, but stressed that the Chancellor had done absolutely everything he was required to do. Is he a beneficiary in tax havens  The Independent reported on Friday that Mr Sunak was listed as the beneficiary of trusts set up in the British Virgin Islands and Cayman Islands to help manage the tax and business affairs of Ms Murtyaposs family interests. But a spokeswoman close to the Sunak family said: No-one in Akshataaposs family is aware of this alleged trust. Labour called on Mr Sunak to explain the situation.Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves said: We need full disclosure now. Has he broken the ministerial code  Labour has accused the Chancellor of breaking the ministerial code, the set of guidelines that top politicians must follow.It states that outside interests must be reported to the Permanent Secretary of their department. It is understood Mr Sunak did report his weaposs status to the Cabinet Office and the Treasury was also aware. The ministerial code says the register of interests should also cover interests of the ministeraposs spouse or partner and close family which might be thought to give rise to a conflict. Lord Geidt will examine this as part of his investigation. Politicians who break the ministerial code are traditionally expected to resign. title: fishy rishi beached chancellor struggling
story: Fishy Rishi is a beached Chancellor struggling to survive and considering quittingChancellor Rishi Sunak seems unlikely to ever succeed the morally corrupt incumbent Prime Minister Boris Johnson - all down to the ongoing non-dom scandal related to his we, Kevin Maguire says" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _The-Prince-Of-Wales-And-Duchess-Of-Cornwall-Celebrate-The-British-Asian-Trust.jpg" width"" "" The Tory minister and his billionaire heiress we Akshata Murthy were the victims of a smear campaign this week Image: UK Press via Getty ImagesopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Apr |commentsFish rot from the head down and the stench of contempt in Downing Street is seeing scales falling from voters‚Äô eyes. Fishy Rishi is a beached Chancellor without credibility, struggling to survive and contemplating resignation over the Rishi Notax scandal. The nets trawling the sordid financial affairs of his incredibly wealthy family may yet produce another jaw-dropper that will force the Tory moneybags to resign in disgrace. And the morally corrupt Prime Minister he‚Äôs now unlikely ever to succeed ‚Äì charlatan Boris Johnson, who presided over widespread law-breaking during Covid, his head on the chopping block until Putin spared him ‚Äì remains a rotten man. Downing Street‚Äôs decaying neighbours represent a Conservative government decomposing rapidly, with ministers mocked for regurgitating on the airwaves pathetic excuses for indefensible behaviour.  Draw a Venn diagram and the fools spouting drivel to shield slippery Sunak and an heiress we, Akshata Murty, who‚Äôd pay ¬£, to avoid millions of pounds in British tax, overlap with idiots who ly claimed Johnson didn‚Äôt hold parties and is innocent of all charges. Whether what non-dom Murty and Green Card Sunak did was legal misses the point that it is unacceptable for a Chancellor to put up taxes for the little people while his family lawfully dodge them. Sleaze taking the Tories back to the John Major era is a glorious opportunity for Labour ‚Äì and a challenge. Leader Keir Starmer is receiving conflicting advice. Either he sticks with Ed Miliband and Jeremy Corbyn‚Äôs proposals to end the non-dom scam, or he listens to those who say it would be seen as anti-business. Championing fairness could draw a thick red line between Labour and the Tories at the election. The Conservative fish is rotting... Labour needs to use its head. title: oscars now open accusations double
story: Oscars are now open to accusations of double standards over Will Smith slap responseDarren Lewis says consistency is clearly lacking in the wake of Will Smith slapping Chris Rock on stage at the Oscars - sexual predators Harvey Weinstein and Roman Polanski still have theirs awardsWill Smith and we Jada Pinkett Smith at the  Vanity Fair Oscars Party after he slapped Chris Rock Image: Getty ImagesopinionByDarren Lewis:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsIn their rush to be seen to be doing something about Will Smith, the Oscars board of governors ended up doing nothing more than leaving themselves open to accusations of double standards.They couldn‚Äôt take away Will Smith‚Äôs Best Actor Oscar for slapping Chris Rock when sexual predators Harvey Weinstein and Roman Polanski still have theirs.They couldn‚Äôt expel Men In Black star Smith because he‚Äôd moved far more quickly to take control of the story and resign from the Academy.So they banned him from all their events, including the Oscars, for  years. Fair enough. We are all agreed that you can‚Äôt go around slapping people, even though this column remains of the opinion that we are in a weird place with so-called comedians at awards nights: Dead set against violence but prepared to normalise the kind of bullying and humiliation of iniduals at these types of events that would probably earn you a trip to HR in the workplace. Again, shame on Rock who made Smith‚Äôs we Jada the butt of his jokes because of her shaven head. It is well known she suffers from alopecia. Would she have been fair gameshe‚Äôd had breast cancer  Reading Smith‚Äôs autobiography on holiday last week , I was also struck by this in the second chapter. ‚ÄúWhen I was nine years old, I watched my father punch my mother in the side of her head so hard that she collapsed. I saw her spit blood. That moment in that bedroom, probably more than any other in my le, has defined who I am today. ‚ÄúWithin everything that I have done since then ‚Äì the awards, the accolades, the spotlights and the attention, the characters and the laughs ‚Äì there has been a subtle string of apologies to my mother for my inaction that day. ‚ÄúFor failing her in that moment. For failing to stand up to my father. For being a coward.‚Äù None of that excuses his actions two weeks ago. But it does explain why he snapped on that night. His book also details a string of examples he would come to recognise as double standards in his negative treatment over the years. A furious debate is understood to have raged within the Academy‚Äôs , members in Whats App groups in the fortnight after Smith‚Äôs slap.It would be fascinating to see a Venn diagram of which members were dead set on Smith‚Äôs suspension and which ones signed a  petition calling for Polanski ‚Äì who admitted raping a child four decades ago ‚Äì to be released from detention in Zurich.It took  years for the Academy to take a stand over Polanski, only expelling him in . Before then he‚Äôd won a Best Director Oscar in  to a standing ovation. No statement from the Academy back then blasting his ‚Äúunacceptable‚Äù and ‚Äúharmful‚Äù conduct, as there was last week over Smith. Allegations over the conduct of a string of other big names, including Kevin Spacey, Woody Allen and Mel Gibson have not seen any of them exiled over the last few decades either, even temporarily. But consistency doesn‚Äôt appear to be paramount in the minds of the Academy or its members ‚Äì only appeasing the social media mob. news politics rishi-sunak-hides-media-ethics-"Rishi Sunak faces a whole list of concerns amid tax rowByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsEmbattled Rishi Sunak faced claims he tried to dodge scrutiny over his familyaposs tax affairs as broadcast media were blocked from a high-profile event in the North today. The under-fire Chancellor was accused of hiding from the cameras at Darlington College on Monday, following days of criticism after it emerged billionaire we Akshata Murty had been avoiding paying UK tax as a non-dom.It also emerged that, while advisers denied access to the BBC and other broadcasters, the Chancellor was accompanied by his ¬£,-a-year taxpayer-funded photographer.The Tory minister denied that he was out of touch with the British public, however, and insisted he understood that many ordinary families were struggling with the high cost of living.  Reporters who were allowed in were instructed in advance not to ask about the saga threatening to derail his career in an apparent bid to avoid embarrassing the under-fire minister. During questions, Mr Sunak refused to be drawn on his billionaire weaposs tax status - or claims that he held a US green card while Chancellor - and images of a smiling Chancellor, taken by his own vanity snapper, were distributed to outlets and shared on social media. A Labour source said: ‚ÄúHard-working families across the country face spiralling energy bills, rising prices at the petrol pumps and crippling Tory tax rises.  ‚ÄúIt beggars belief that Rishi Sunak is carrying on with his taxpayer-funded vanity photoshoots without a care in the world. For this out of touch Chancellor it‚Äôs a case of ‚Äòcost of living crisis  What cost of living crisis ‚Äô‚Äù Sources at the event also said the Chancelloraposs PR advisers tried to shield the Chancellor from dficult questions when he appeared on stage with Tory mayor for Tees Valley Ben Houchen.They said: ‚ÄúUsually you can‚Äôt move for cameras when the mayor has ministers in town but this time the news media seemed about as welcome as a letter from HMRC on Rishi Sunak ‚Äôs doormat.They clearly wanted maximum control as the Chancellor even chaired the . During the QA, the Treasury events team with microphones didn‚Äôt even wait for the Chancellor to point out who would ask the next question asthey had been vetted in advance. Boris Johnson has ordered his sleaze advisor to look into Mr Sunakaposs financial declarations to make sure all the rules had been followed.Mr Sunakaposs political career is at risk of being derailed by the row over his weaposs non-domiciled status and his own former holding of a US green card.  Mr Sunak also asked for all three press questions to be submitted together to avoid giving detailed answers, or the opportunity for follow-ups. But asked whether he was out of touch with the British public, the Chancellor said: On cost of living, I know itaposs dficult for people. Of course I know itaposs dficult. I want to make sure that we can do, and I can do, everything we can to get through what are some challenging months ahead. People are looking at what is happening around them and seeing prices go up and of course people are worried by that. I want them to be reassured that me and the Government are on their side and doing what we can to ease the burdens that we are facing. Yet aides have briefed that Mr Sunak ordered an aggressive Whitehall inquiry into how his weaposs tax details were leaked, rather than focusing on the cost of living crisis.  Labour leader Keir Starmer said all Cabinet ministers should declare whether they have ever used schemes like non dom status to reduce their tax.I donapost have any non doms in the shadow cabinet because I understand the fairness of the issue, he said. He called for the PM to guarantee that no other members of the Cabinet have been using these schemes to reduce their tax. I think on behalf of everybody who is now paying more tax we are entitled to an answer to that question.Health Secretary Sajid Javid has admitted he was previously a non dom for tax purposes.But No  refused to say whether the PM was taking any steps to find outany other ministers, or their spouses, have green cards or non dom status. A government spokesman said: All MPs and sitting peers are automatically deemed to be resident in the UK for tax purposes, by law. Ms Murtyaposs non dom status could have saved her an estimated ¬£ million in taxes on idends from her shares in Infosys, an Indian IT company founded by her father. title: what undeniable queens platinum jubilee
story: What is undeniable is the Queens Platinum Jubilee will see a new phase to her reignThe Queen has struggled with wider poor health issues forcing her to miss public engagements - making it clear that the time is fast approaching for Prince Charles and Prince William to ease her burdenThe Queen contracting the virus at the age of  was downplayed by Buckingham Palace Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Apr |commentsDiscussing the debilitating exhaustion inflicted on some Covid victims, the Queen both connected with those facing long-term ill effects and may have given us an insight into her own condition. Her contracting the virus at the age of  was downplayed by Buckingham Palace. Understandably, the monarch was unable to fulfil a number of engagements and wider poor health caused her to miss ceremonies at which her attendance was once a given. Like many vulnerable and older citizens, even a head of state must look after herself and be cared for carefully because age doesn‚Äôt travel alone, as Labour MP Dennis Skinner once observed. Other royals, particularly Charles and William, can take the strain to ease the burden. What is increasingly undeniable is an unparalleled Platinum Jubilee is also the start of a new, dferent phase in her reign.  The info war The misery, fear and death suffered by Ukrainians at the hands of Putin‚Äôs war criminals is harrowing and heartbreaking.Graphic accounts and details from traumatised survivors, men and women who a couple of months ago were living peaceful, even mundane lives, are the first draft of historyand charge sheets for investigations and,hopefully, prosecutions.What we‚Äôre reading, hearing, seeing and feeling isn‚Äôt unique to this war. But rapid, ubiquitous communications allow us to be informed sooner and in greater depth. Ukraine is a tragedy inflicted by a guilty man.  Rishi‚Äôs rattled Demanding the head of whoever ulged details of his rich family‚Äôs unforgivable tax arrangements, rattled Rishi Sunak again demonstrates he‚Äôs an out of touch Conservative Chancellor. He and puppets parroting the deceit that Sunak‚Äôs been totally open should stop and ask themselveshe was, why is he so eager to unmask the person who told the truth. title: boy 9 left screaming after
story: Boy, , left screaming after Bovril spills on foot leaving him with horror burnsWARNING GRAPHIC IMAGES: Nine-year-old football fan, Theo, was left with second degree burns after a cup of Bovril was accidentally dropped on his foot at the Riverside stadium in MiddlesbroughGraeme Baverstock and son Theo who was injured by hot Bovril at the Riverside Image: Teesside LiveByPoppy KennedyLiam Buckler:,  Apr |commentsA young boy was left screaming and suffered second degree burns after a cup of Bovril was accidentally dropped on his foot at a football match. Nine-year-old Middlesbrough fan Theo Baverstock was intending to watch his hometown club with his dad Graeme against Fulham on Wednesday evening.However, he suffered second degree on his foot after a fellow supporter dropped a freshly poured cup of Bovril on his foot, which left him in AE, TeessideLive reports.His dad Graeme said: We went to the Boro game and we were stood in the queue and a gentleman turned around with a cup of bovril. He dropped it by accident and it went straight onto Theoaposs foot. Straight away he started screaming so itaposs gone through his shoe and his sock. First aid got involved as did the club doctor and he got taken straight to hospital where they found he had second degree burns. I felt really sorry for the gentleman who dropped it, he didnapost mean to do it and it was a total accident.Theo is quite shook up, heaposs just had it rebandaged. Heaposs had to go every two days to the hospital for checks on it. I just wanted to say that it could happen to anyone. Itaposs not against them butit is being served so hot it can so easily be dropped on anyoneaposs foot like it has done. Heaposs got a bit of an infection in it and he has to go onto antibiotics. It looks quite bad at the moment. The extent of Theoaposs burns are visible in the graphic picture which show how badly his foot was injured after the accident at the Riverside. The liquid soaked through his trainers and sock before scalding him. Although Theo is now recovering at home, he is struggling to sit and rest as heaposs a bit of a live wire. Graeme, , said: Heaposs getting there. Heaposs quite a livewire so heaposs not use to laying up. With the school holidays now he canapost go swimming or playing football - he missed his last game of the season today. It has upset him a little but in himself heaposs happy, heaposs chirpy heaposs still fine. Itaposs just harder to get him to realise how bad it could gethe doesnapost look after it and rest. It was an absolute total accident, no one is to blame for it. Graeme has praised the amazing staff at the Riverside stadium where first aiders were on the scene in minutes and police allowed him to pull his car right up to the ground so he could take Theo to hospital. He said: Iaposve got nothing but praise for the staff, the club have been great and theyaposve contacted me as well to see how he is. They didnapost have to do that. Itaposs one of those unfortunate things but I do think to myself, itaposs that hot itaposs gone through his shoe, sock and heaposs still getting second degree burns from a drink that served within a crowd. When youaposre in the queue youaposre touching shoulders, it could have landed on his chest - it could have been so much worse. Itaposs more why is it being served so hot. Iaposm not wanting to blame anyone but I donapost see how it can be so hot. Someone could knock it over anyone and itaposs going to affect them like it did Theo. I want to thank everyone with how much theyaposve helped but I wanted to get the awareness out that this can happen to people. Is it too hot  Is it worth looking at  It could have been an even smaller child stood there and it wouldnapost have been their foot it landed on. Middlesbrough FC have been contacted for comment. title: britains third largest baby same
story: Britains third-largest baby born weighing more than a stone - and he loves porridgeFive-month-old Alpha Stone Mitchell, is as big as his older sister Twyla-Bay, who is almost one and a half - his mum says his massive growth is thanks to chomping down breakfasts of porridgeCherral said her bump was huge but she never expected Alpha would be so large Image: Cherral Mitchell   SWNSByJoe Smith:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments A baby crowned Britainaposs third-largest newborn was delivered weighing more than a stone and is already the same size as his -month-old sister.Five-month-old Alpha Stone Mitchell, is as big as his older sister Twyla-Bay, who is almost one and a half. His mum says his massive growth is thanks to his hearty breakfasts of porridge. Alpha was born via C-section on October  last year, weighing in at a chunky lbs oz, making him Britainaposs third largest newborn.Despite not yet being six months old, big boy Alpha - who now weighs st lbs, is already wearing clothing designed for nine to -month-olds. Mum Cherral Mitchell, , told the Sun she has had to wean her hungry little man off milk.Now Alpha loves to chow down on porridge and rusk biscuits, even though most babies donapost do so until at least  weeks. Cherral said: We knew he was going to be a big boy as my bump was huge, but we didnapost realise quite how big he would be until he was here. Iaposd had three babies before and with Alpha it felt like we skipped the newborn stage altogether and went straight to him being three months old.‚Äù People often mistake Alpha and his sister Twyla-Bay for twins, despite her being more than three times his age, Cherral said, because Alpha is already almost the same height as her.Alpha starts the day with baby porridge, followed by a oz bottle of baby milk every three hours and a baby rusk biscuit in the evening. Cherral who is also mum to Rouge-Angel, five, Lyon, three, and Twyla-Bay, one, with electrical engineer husband Tyson, , said none of her other children were anywhere near Alpha‚Äôs size at the same age. When he was born at John Radclfe Hospital in  Cherral and Tyson were shocked at his size, despite doctors‚Äô predictions that their baby would be a whopper. Cherral added: ‚ÄúWhen we first saw him, my first thought was he was not going to fit into any of the clothes I‚Äôd brought in the hospital bag. Tyson even had to go home to bring back some three to six-month clothes for him.‚Äù Hospital staff measured Alpha and began to google records for the largest babies born in the UK right there in the delivery room. They excitedly informed Cherral that her newborn was the third-largest in the UK. Tipping the scales at lb oz Alpha comes in just behind Guy Carr who measured lb oz at his birth in , and George King who clocked lb oz in . news uk-news british-airways-passenger-who-lost-"Heathrow Airport: Long lines owing to delays and cancellationsBySam OrmistonJoe Smith:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments A furious British Airways passenger who believes he was scammed out of ¬£, by the airline after his flight to Dubai was cancelled.David Spencer, from Nottingham, says he forked out for two business-class tickets, priced at ¬£, each, but has only received a pitul ¬£, refund - he claims the airline are now giving him the silent treatment.David was due to fly to Dubai from Heathrow Airport on December  with his friend Lotte Reynard for a New Yearaposs Eve party, MyLondon reports.After sipping on free wine at Terminal  the pair boarded their flight only to be left waiting on the tarmac for three hours before being told to disembark andto the terminal.After another three-hour wait, British Airways told passengers their flight had been cancelled. The airline offered the pair an alternative flight but it would not have got them to Dubai in time for their scheduled New Years Eve celebrations. Instead David and Lotte made a mad dash over to Terminal  to catch a last-minute Emirates Air flight at their own expense. David said: The whole point of the holiday was to go for the New Year celebrations. At best after the cancelled flight with British Airways, their rescheduled one would have got us there the day after. After an enjoyable five-day getaway, David and Lotte ed home to Heathrow, in what was a less eventful leg of the journey with only a few hours delay. After months of continuously attempting to contact British Airways, however, David has still not been compensated for the majority of his trip.  The ¬£, sum which he says he was originally owed includes the price of two business class flights from London Heathrow to Dubai, a one night stay at the Wardlow Hotel and a ¬£ airport transfer. Of that huge sum, he has only received ¬£, compensation, which is the industry standard for cancelled flights of that nature. David, who recently ed from a trip to Thailand, was hoping to use some of the money that is owed to him from British Airways in order to fund that. However, his holiday has been and gone, and there are still no signs of getting a full refund any time soon. He insists that he would not be content with a voucher, and has vowed never to fly with the airline again. He added: After hours on hold and countless phone calls over a period of months, the customer relations department got back to me and paid out ¬£, compensation with is the standard aviation compensation for cancelled flights. But British Airways holidays still have not contacted me to pay back my cancelled flight, hotel and transfer costs. Despite continuously trying I still canapost get hold of them.  I recently flew with Emirates Air to Thailand and I had absolutely no problems. Even when I had a slight issue with myflight, I was able to phone someone and they actually picked up. Iaposve even had cancelled flights with Ryanair in recent years - but even with them, I was able to get a refund no problem. Their telephone systems are rigged so you can never get hold of anyone and eventually it hangs up. I have tried for hours and hours. I have sent numerous e-mails to their complains department, you eventually get a response and a case number but nothing happens, it‚Äôs a scam. As I see it British Airways have purposely set their systems up so they hold onto customersapos money - and then you can‚Äôt get hold of them to sort it out. As time goes on, I try less and less to sort it out because Iaposm in their hands. No one picks up and I just feel hopeless. I am truly at a loss. The whole system is rigged, there is nothing I can do. British Airways has been contacted for a response. It comes as British Airways CEO Sean Doyle was forced to send an apology email to tens of thousands of flyers in response to the barrage of complaints that the airline has received recently - particularly in response to people who have struggled to speak to call handlers about urgent matters. title: cash strapped brits praise 35
story: Cash-strapped Brits praise ¬£ Aldi hack Martin Lewis says keeps you warm for p a weekAs part of his advice Money Saving Expert Martin Lewis suggested buying items like heated USB gloves and electric blankets, so people can heat themselves instead of their homesShoppers have praised the cash saving trickByRachel PughWilliam WalkerOvernight Editor:,  Apr |commentsCash-strapped Brits have praised Aldi for a ¬£ Specialbuy after advice from Money Saving Expert Martin Lewis.Last week, the ITV This Morning finance expert advised people on how they can stay warm without turning the heating on.As part of his advice, Martin suggested buying items like heated USB gloves and electric blankets, so people can heat themselves instead of their homes.Now Aldi shoppers have discovered a ¬£ Specialbuy that is helping them use the Money Saving Expertaposs advice, reports the Manchester Evening News. Posting on the Extreme Couponing and Bargains Facebook group, Barbara Mann shared a picture of a ¬£ heated throw with sleeves you can buy at Aldi. She wrote: After Martin Lewis recommendations for keeping warm and using electric blanketsyou only need to be warm in one room...bingo. ¬£ Aldi. The post clearly struck a chord with struggling shoppers, as itaposs been commented on more than , times. Responding, Emma Sherman said: I have this and absolutely love it! Its amazing also for when I have a fibro flare up! Lisa Harrop said: I bought this for my hubby in February I have used it a couple of times at night or when ill and itaposs really warn without been plugged in. Lorna Quinn wrote: They are great. And I use it as an electric blanket on the very cold nights. So comfortable. Joanne Guy commented: Iaposve got one of these and itaposs lush, so comfy and warm even without turning it on! Amanda Payne-MacArthur said: I use mine every day. Unfortunately the blankets are currently out of stock on the Aldi website, but you may be able to find one in your local storeyouaposre lucky. title: couple sleep coats cant imagine
story: Exclusive: Couple sleep in coats and cant imagine using heating again as energy bills doubleGerald Porter, , and we Mair Porter, , from Melksham, Wiltshire, say they won‚Äôt be using the central heating again after their energy bills more than doubled and they now rely on hot water bottles and fleece jackets to stay warmGerald Porter and we Mair have stopped donating to charities as he can no longer afford it Image: MARC GIDDINGSByZahra Khaliq:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments An elderly couple are being forced to wear coats to bed as they can no longer afford their heating bills since they more than doubled last month, saying the increase has ‚Äútaken over their lives‚Äù.Gerald Porter, , is even debating going back to work to get more money to support his we Mair, , who has just been diagnosed with dementia. The couple, who live in Melksham, Wiltshire, have been forced to give up their social lives as cash is so tight and have even stopped using their oven to keep bills down. Gerald served in the Royal Air Force for  years and feels the country he devoted his le to is letting him down. He tells The Mirror: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to complain really because I‚Äòve had a good le, but it comes as a huge disappointment.In the quiet hours when you sit and think, well we did all that and we‚Äôve ended up with all this worry. You‚Äôre sort of living on the edge really. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt knowit‚Äôs a matter of age but you think, what did we do all that for  Le has changed completely. Before, we would go out lunching and that sort of thing, meeting friends - but we don‚Äôt do that anymore. We can‚Äôt afford it, every penny has got to be watched. For years, I‚Äôve contributed to causes like the Salvation Army or UNICEF. I give them maybe ¬£ or ¬£ a month - not much - but that‚Äôs all stopped. I just can‚Äôt afford it. It grieves me to do it, but there you go, I just can‚Äôt do anything about it.‚Äù Since their bills jumped from ¬£ to ¬£, Gerald and Mair have started setting strict budgets for their daily gas and electricity usage, which means giving up the use of their central heating altogether. Gerald has worked out that it costs him p to boil his kettle - a cheaper solution that allows both him and Mair to surround themselves with multiple hot water bottles to stay warm while at home.They‚Äôve also stopped using the oven to keep costs low, relying instead on their microwave. He said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre on a fixed income so there‚Äôs nothing we can do about it. I can put it on and go into debt but I just want somebody to do something. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt imagine a time that I can turn the heating on again, there‚Äôs nothing in sight and there‚Äôs nothing  I can do‚Äù ‚ÄúThe dference between ¬£ and ¬£ - it‚Äôs a chasm that I can‚Äôt cross. I‚Äôm not putting the heating on because I refuse to go into into debt.‚Äù Gerald added: At night, we cover the bed in coats and use an extra blanket because Mair is particularly susceptible to the cold. We wear coats indoors now. They‚Äôre like long jackets lined with synthetic wool. We‚Äôre having to use those in bed too just to make sure we keep warm. As you get older, the extremes of heat and cold affect you more. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got an Aga, but we have no plans to use that. Putting it on would be absolutely catastrophic. We just use it for storage - it‚Äôs just a nice piece of furniture now, nothing .And yet this isnapost the only dficulty that the couple are facing, as the cost increase came shortly after -year-old Mair was diagnosed with vascular dementia. Gerald added:I‚Äôm trying to take it in my stride. It‚Äôs unavoidable, but just another thing to worry about really. Iaposm afraid with my weaposs illness, they sort of retreat within themselves. She doesnapost have opinions now. She has very basic feelings like aposI‚Äôm too coldapos or aposI‚Äôm too hot.aposGerald went viral on Twitter last month after sharing a message about how the price hikes are impacting their lives. He said: ‚ÄúOur heating is the biggest expense we‚Äôve got. We live on very average pensions, and the reason why I put the tweet out wasnapost an appeal for help or anything, it was anger. I was so angry. When I worked the figures out I thought, my God, what am I doing  I had loads of people come back to me and say, aposweaposll give you some moneyapos. I even had a young woman say, Iaposm a single mum but Iaposve got some money put away and you‚Äôre welcome to half of it. He added: From a large point of view, there is help. I‚Äôve also got my family. Youaposre a telephone away from homeyou need anybody. My granddaughter is wonderful. I couldnapost manage without it. Iaposm very lucky. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Since Mairaposs diagnosis, Gerald has sent out an application for her to receive an Attendance Allowance and hope it will take away some of their financial strain. ‚ÄúIt would definitely help. It‚Äôd cover bills full stop, says Gerald. But Gerald believes that he shouldnapost have to rely on others to support him financially, and that the government should be held responsible for the effects that the cost of living crisis are having on regular people like himself.  I detest the thought of relying on benefits. The kindness of strangers. I really hate that. People are generous. I know that from the tweet. That really surprised me. But itaposs just the thought that you are really are an inidual. Now youaposre on your own. Youaposve got to get over it and thereaposs nothing I can do, except sell stuff. Thataposs what I could do. Iaposm afraid Iaposve lost complete patience with anything the Government says, or any politician really. Iaposve seen a lot of governments, and these people are the worst, worst of the lot. The pair have acknowledged that while the cost of living crisis has forced them to live frugally, they could have been much worse off. Gerald said There must be a lot of people a lot worse off than me, and not just elderly people either. I donapost have a mortgage, I donapost have any debts. If you‚Äôve got a mortgage and a couple of children, itaposs going to be really tricky. Our Cost of Living team of experts are here to help YOU through a very dficult year. Theyaposll be bringing you the latest money news stories and also providing specialist advice. Whether itaposs rocketing energy bills, the cost of the weekly shop or increased taxes, our team will be with you all the way. Every Thursday at pm they will take part in a Facebook Live event to answer your questions and offer their advice. Visit facebook dailymirror live to watch. You canabout our team of experts here. If you have a question - or want to share your story - please get in touch by emailing webnews@mirror. Even at -years-old, Gerald is considering going back to work to earn a few extra pennies‚Äù. I donapost want to do it but Iaposm hoping I can. It would have to be from home and it would have to be a computer device. One of the first things I looked at was working remotely for Amazon but I‚Äôm not even sure of how it works. Despite the drastic changes they‚Äôve already made, Gerald believes there is still a long way to go. He said: I think it may get worse, particularly with the administration that is in charge of the country now. The way they operate, the stereotypical Tory administration - the sole incentive is profit.Do you have a cost of living story to share  Email yourmirror@trinitymirror.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON PensionsEnergy billsCost of Living: Were Here to Help" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: elderly woman fleeced 1000 distraction
story: Tesco trolley scammers steal ¬£, from woman, , in distraction schemeLola Sledmere, , from Little Chalfont, had her pin stolen by a trio of thieves at Tesco in Amersham, Buckinghamshire, in a complex distraction ordeal which left her traumatisedLola Sledmere who had her pin stolen at Tesco in Amersham, pictured outside Tesco Amersham, Bucks Image: Ian Vogler   Daily MirrorByBradley JollyNews ReporterCharlie Duffield:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsAn -year-old woman had ¬£, stolen from several cashpoints, as far as  miles from her home, over two days.The horric thievery took place after she was distracted by a man when she went toher trolley to the car park of Tesco superstore in Amersham, Buckinghamshire. She believes another criminal snuck into her car, a few yards away, and stole her card.According to CCTV taken inside the supermarket, a third criminal was loitering behind her, and watched her insert her PIN at the checkout. She thinks the trio worked as a team to fleece her in the shocking broad daylight theft.  Since the incident Lola, who is a widow, has struggled to sleep and has become wary of leaving her home in Little Chalfont, Buckinghamshire.The mother of four told Express : I have been told this activity is re, particularly in some supermarket car parks in and around London.Itaposs affected me very much. I have been struggling to sleep because I think about it all the time. It is just so clear in my mind. I have felt sad and worried, and stupid to be honest. It is just very upsetting. I have been very very upset and I no longer trust people. It was absolutely disgusting.  The money is yet to be reimbursed into Ms Sledmereaposs account although police are investigating the theft. Ms Sledmere, who worked in psychology, added: Of course, it has impacted me financially too. I am a pensioner. I have a state pension but Iaposm not well off at all. I live alone, so of course it is going to affect me financially. I have seven grandchildren who all need money and it is upsetting I canapost help them at the moment. After Ms Sledmere paid for her shopping, itaposs thought she was followed out of the supermarket and to her car by the man who saw her PIN.  She put her shopping and handbag in her vehicle, left it unlocked as she turned to push the trolley to the bay just yards away. But another man spoke to her at the bay, asking for directions to Chesham, which is less than three miles away. Ms Sledmere said: I thought this was strange. I thought he was being a bit stupid actually as there are plenty of signs for Chesham and itaposs only around the corner. But I offered help. Someone previously must have looked over my shoulder and got my PIN number when I was paying at the checkout. The checkout was the very one closest to the enclosure where people pay for their own groceries so it is pretty open and easy just for someone to stand there and not to be noticed. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  I got to my car, put my shopping away and I was near the trolley bay so went tothe trolley. I hadnapost locked my car and thought I didnapost need to because I was so very, very near the bay. It was yards away. I thought the man was just waiting to use my trolley but he stood there and asked me the way to Chesham. I felt secure because I hadnapost got my handbag on me, which he could have snatched. I did notice him looking over my shoulder quite a lot, which was odd, but I went back to my car and drove home. title: girls 6 8 kicked pushed
story: Girls,  and , kicked and pushed by man outside Tesco in shock unprovoked attackMum-of-two Charlene Brown took her two daughters to Tesco Express on March  - but as she left her girls Azariah, , and six-year-old Kimoire were knocked to the floor while two men were "tussling" each otherAzariah, eight, and six-year-old Kimoire were pushed to the floor while two men were tussling with each other outside a supermarket Image: Charlene BrownBySam OrmistonRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr |commentsA mum says her young daughters were left crying and bleeding after a man kicked and pushed them in an unprovoked attack outside Tesco. Charlene Brown was with her two daughters while taking out cash from a Tesco Express in Peckham Rye to buy them all a Chinese takeaway on March .But to Charleneaposs horror, her two girls Azariah, eight, and six-year-old Kimoire were thrown to the floor while two men were tussling with each other outside the supermarket, reports MyLondon.The mum-of-two claims the attacker, a -year-old man who is non-verbal and has disabilities, hit both of the youngsters as his signicantly shorter carer struggled to restrain him. After calling  the police rushed to the shop on Rye Lane and got there very quickly, Charlene said. Speaking to MyLondon, Charlene, who lives in Brockley, said: My girls ran to me and screamed aposhe pushed meapos while crying hysterically. I went up to the men and screamed aposwhat‚Äôs going on  You‚Äôve hurt my childrenapos. He kicked Kimoire, then I realised that Azariah was crying and her nose was bleeding. A Tesco security guard asked us to come in the store so they could attend to my eldest daughters bleeding nose. The police arrived within seconds and eventually, they explained that because the attacker is autistic and non-verbal, that meant that an arrest could not be made. Charlene, who works in a mental health inpatient ward at Lambeth Hospital, claims that both her daughters are emotionally scarred following the incident and that they are now too scared to leave the house.She added: I‚Äôm in the process of trying to arrange counselling as they‚Äôre having struggles with social spaces now. The worst part is nothing can be done. I think accountability should be taken somewhere. My children have been hurt and no one is responsible, which I think disgraceful.  Azariah and Kimoire are currently staying at their grandmotheraposs house in Bedfordshire over the Easter break - and mum Charlene is glad that they are able to enjoy some downtime in a quieter area following the unprovoked attack.Now, the NHS worker is concerned that the same thing could happen to a pregnant woman, or a baby, or another vulnerable person.Charlene says she felt disheartened that no one stopped to check that her daughters were alright, other than two local schoolboys, even though plenty of people witnessed the incident. She added: I just want to make the streets safe andpeople are hurt someone needs to take accountability. A politan Police spokesperson confirmed the incident took place. They said: Police were called at around .pm on Thursday, March , to a shop on Peckham Ryefollowing reports that a child had been pushed by a man. The girl fell to the ground and suffered minor injuries.Officers attended and detained a -year-old man who was with his carer. Due to his vulnerabilities, the man was not arrested. The circumstances were explained to the child‚Äôs mother. No further action will be taken.
