title: i taste tested non traditional
story: I taste-tested non-traditional Hot Cross Buns and found one very disappointingThe simple offerings of a humble hot cross bun are a thing of the past, with the supermarket shelves now groaning under the weight of bizarrely flavoured offerings - including rhubarb and custardCan a non-traditional hot cross bun really be better than the original  Image: MirrorPixByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsPreviously the toughest decision when it came to hot cross buns was decidingit was too early to start eating them. And the topic of debate would be whether to toast it or simply eat it fresh, obviously with lashings of butter. But now, the supermarkets have decided that the traditional flavour was not enough. From every angle, youaposre bombarded with dferent flavours - from salted caramel to triple cheese. If youaposre a purist like me, itaposs enough to make you weep. In my opinion, the humble hot cross bun needs nothing more than plenty of fruit, a hint of spice and a glazed topping. But this isnapost enough for the modern world, so, I sampled some of the unusual offerings on sale this year. We sampled a range of hot cross buns from Waitrose, MS, Co-op, Aldi, Lidl, Sainsbury‚Äôs and Tesco and gave each one a score out of five. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter hereMS  Extremely Cheesy Hot Cross Buns Blurb: Loaded with Extra Mature Barberaposs Farmhouse Cheddar  Smooth Red Leicester.What I thought: It‚Äôs a delicious cheese bun. But I just can‚Äôt get on board with the idea it‚Äôs a hot cross bun. It has none of the elements that turn it into one- except that it‚Äôs mockingly marked with a pastry cross. I would give this a ‚Öñ and only because there was cheese involved. Co-op Spiced Masala  Chilli Hot Cross BunsBlurb: Hot cross buns with caramelised onions, sultanas, ground spices and dried jalape√±o chillies.What I thought: Surprisingly good. This is an elevated hot cross bun - the sweet caramelised onion pairs well with the spiced bun, while the jalapenos give a little kick. A delightful savoury treat.   Sainsburyaposs Chocolate  Caramel Hot Cross BunsBlurb: Hot cross buns made with salted caramel pieces, dark chocolate chunks and caramel fudge piecesWhat I thought: Adults should have no more than seven teaspoons of sugar per day, but this feels like that would exceed it. It is a sugary nightmare, but the caramel fudge pieces offer something dferent. Overall itaposs quite stodgy and at times, it tastes a bit synthetic.   Lidl Deluxe Triple Chocolate Hot Cross BunsBlurb: Delightfully soft, triple chocolate buns filled with indulgent milk, dark and white chocolate piecesWhat I thought: Iaposm a big fan of chocolate, so I really wanted to like these, but while they look pretty good, the first bite was dry and stale - as was the next and the next. The taste was slightly improved when the chocolate melted as it gave a little more sweetness, but it wasnapost enough to make me want to eat a whole one.  MS Salted Caramel  Blond Chocolate Hot Cross BunsBlurb: Delicately spiced hot cross buns enriched with golden blond and milk chocolate, salted caramel fudge and toffee pieces.What I thought: Hard to see how these are ‚Äòdelicately spiced‚Äô when all you can taste is chocolate and caramel. These pack a serious sugar punch, rather than the more delicate flavours you‚Äôd normally expect from a traditional bun. If you‚Äôd like to eat a sweet pick-me-up, this is perfect, but book a visit to the dentist afterwards.   Aldi Rhubarb and Custard Hot Cross BunsBlurb : Packed full of delicious candied rhubarb with custard flavouring.What I thought : Definitely the sweetest hot cross bun I have ever tasted. The bun itself was quite light in colour and the actual taste was quite similar to that of brioche. They did not have as much fruit in them compared to a traditional hot cross bun but the candied rhubarb was a welcome sugar fix.  These are a very sweet treat and the flavours in their work really well together. Maybe they arenapost that traditional but they are certainly inventive. MS Blueberry Hot Cross Buns Blurb: Four butter enriched hot cross buns with juicy Vostizza currants and sweetened dried blueberries. Best served toasted with a spread of butter.What I thought: These were a total disappointment. Similarly to Dr Ashenden, I brand these an outrage. Itaposs basically a brioche bun with blueberries on it, and a white cross draped on top as an afterthought. The fruit is lovely and juicy, and they smell great, but I wonapost be buying another pack. ‚ÖñThe winner: Frankly, only Co-op stood a chance here, the rest were far too sweet and stodgy. I‚Äôd recommend sticking to a traditional hot cross bun. title: mum sick stomach after horror
story: Mum sick to her stomach after horror crash video that killed daughter shared onlinePaige Rice, , was a passenger in an Audi S when it crashed head on into a Mercedes taxi inside the Queensway Tunnel, in the early hours of Sunday, October  last yearInstagram influencer Paige Rice, , died in hospital after the horror crash in October last year Image: BPM MediaByCharlotte HadfieldRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr |comments A grieving mum has issued a heartfelt plea to the thoughtless people sharing a video of a horror crash that killed her beautul baby girl on social media. Paige Rice, , was a passenger in an Audi S when it was involved in a fatal smash with a a Mercedes taxi in the Queensway Tunnel in October last year.Her ex-partner Callum Miller, , a labourer from Stockport, was clocking speeds of mph as he drove the Audi through the tunnel - which connects Liverpool and Birkenhead.An inquest into their deaths, held at Gerard Majella Courthouse in Kirkdale on January , heard Merseyside Police initially launched a criminal investigation into a potential offence of causing death by dangerous driving.But the probe was dropped when it became clear Callum would not survive.Dashcam footage of the crash, which also left the taxi driver with le-changing injuries to his leg and hip, has now emerged on social media, the Liverpool Echo reports. Clare Rice, Paigeaposs mum said she has not been able sleep since finding out that the video was circulating online as she asked people to remove any posts containing the footage. Ms Rice wrote: Yesterday, I found out there‚Äôs a video circulating on social media, a video of the crash that killed my daughter. Now I have no idea who has this video and how it‚Äôs got online but I want you to know, I‚Äôve not slept since and I feel sick to the stomach. After we lost Paige I was askedI wanted to view the footage, I chose not to for my own sanity. When you grieve someone who‚Äôs died and in such a tragic way, Your mind chooses what to think about and what to block out.Finding out the video was online has been really triggering for me, moments which I‚Äôd been blocking out to survive my days were now at the forefront of my mind. Why would you want to watch my daughteraposs last moments  I‚Äôm heartbroken, the thought of strangers, people who don‚Äôt know Paige or me watching something so traumatic and distressing. When people post such personal pictures or videos without consent, it can have a serious impact on people‚Äôs lives. Ms Rice said her le has been turned upside down by the death of her daughter as she shared a series of photos of herself with Paige growing up. She continued: I‚Äôm still Paige‚Äôs mum and I still have that protective instinct. I know Paige would hate that this video is online. Look at these pictures, this is my beautul baby girl Paige.  She was taken from us in October, only  years old. No matter how old your child gets, they‚Äôre still our babies. I had Paige at a young age and it‚Äôs Pretty much always been us three. My le has revolved around my children and making sure they never went without. I can‚Äôt tell you how much my le has been turned upside down since loosing my daughter. When you lose a child, just getting through an hour is an accomplishment.  The last five months has been a blur when it comes to time and I don‚Äôt know how I‚Äôm surviving each day with this heartache, a pain you will never know, unless you‚Äôve lived it. To cause added stress and upset is disrespectful and thoughtless. My le will never be the same again. I‚Äôve lost my daughter and my friend and my son has lost his sister and we‚Äôve all lost a massive piece of our lives. Paige left behind many broken hearts, she is loved and now missed by so many people, someone‚Äôs daughter, sister, granddaughter, niece, cousin and friend. We don‚Äôt deserve any more upset. I hope the posts are removed, I‚Äôd be extremely thankful. title: sabina nessa would made more
story: Sabina Nessa would have made more headlinesshe was white, grieving sister claimsJebina Yasmin Islam told BBC Radio s Today programme she didnt feel her sisters murder received enough press coverage and believed it was down to her ethnicitySabina Nessa was murdered last September while walking through a park in South East London Image: PAByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Apr |commentsThe sister of a murdered teacher believes she and her relatives would have been treated dferentlythey were a normal British white family. Sabina Nessa, , was murdered by Koci Selamaj in a park in South East London last September. He has been jailed for le after pleading guilty to the horric crime and had refused to attend sentencing proceedings in court last week, with Mr Justice Sweeney calling this decision cowardly - a video link was made available to him, but he turned it down. Sister Jebina Yasmin Islam told BBC Radio aposs Today programme this morning she didnapost feel her sisteraposs murder received enough press coverage. She said: My sister didn‚Äôt get as much headlines, I feel, at the start. Maybe was it down to her ethnicity  ‚ÄúShe didn‚Äôt get the front pages on some of the papers and, in Sarah Everard‚Äôs case, she did. I think it‚Äôs just down to our ethnicity, to be honest. And I feel likewe were a normal British white family we would have been treated equally, I guess.‚Äù She also said that there has been no support from the Government, describing people in senior positions as useless. She added: Theyaposve not said nothing.  Priti Patel has done a tweet on Friday and I was not happy about it because all of a sudden sheaposs using my sisteraposs name for publicity reasons. And to be honest she has no right.Afterwards, Jebina appeared on ITV to speak about her sister.Speaking about the huge loss, Jebina explained: Itaposs all surreal, it feels like a bad dream that weaposre all going through. Itaposs just heartbreaking, you would never have thought that your young -year-old sister was brutally taken away.  If she was like ill, we could have had some time to spend time with her, make memories. But her le was taken away without a second thought and out of nowhere. Itaposs impacted us a lot, itaposs impacted myself, my sisters, weaposre scared to walk the streets alone now, and also given the time of day as well. It was also revealed that Sabina had plans to one day become a headteacher. On Frida, Selamaj was jailed for le and must serve a minimum of  years. Sabina was strangled after being struck on the head  times with a hazard triangle. Following Koci‚Äôs sentencing, Sabina‚Äôs sister Jebina Islam hit out at Home Secretary Priti Patel for her ‚Äúlack of support‚Äù.She responded to a tweet from Ms Patel, who insisted she was doing ‚Äúeverything in her power‚Äù to tackle violence against women and girls.Jebina wrote: Yes @pritipatel you don‚Äôt know what we as a family are going through and to be honest you haven‚Äôt even bothered to ask since the death of my sister. Lack of support from yourself and @BorisJohnson just shows how ‚Äòimportant‚Äô it is to tackle male violence to you guys.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Murder" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news two-covid-rules-uk-needs-"Boris Johnson ‚Äòcan‚Äôt rule out‚Äô another lockdownByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments Wearing masks in crowded spaces and limiting mixing indoors are some of the Covid rules the UK needs to bring back to avoid a brutal Easter, an NHS chief has warned. The NHS Confederation has accused the Government of abandoning any interest in Covid whatsoever and says hospitals are set to deal with a brutal Easter as bad as any winterapos.Last week Covid cases hit the highest since February  at , infections. That is despite official tallies having plunged because of Noaposs decision to axe the ¬£billion-a-month mass-swabbing regime. The NHS Confederation, which acts as a representative for hospitals and ambulance trusts, called for mitigating actions such as not meeting people indoors and mask-wearing in crowded spaces. This would help prevent the spread of the virus, the health and wellbeing organisation told The Times.It also said the Government needs to introduce a public information campaign in England to ask people to stay away from AE unless they have an emergency.The so-called coronavirus dashboard shows casesdecreasing, however hospitalisations and deaths are still rising although both statistics usually lag behind infections.It is estimated a record one in  people currently have coronavirus in England.  Confederation boss Matthew Taylor said: NHS leaders report a clear disconnect between the Governmentaposs Living with Covid plan and the realities at the NHS front line. We have a Government that seems to want to wash its hands of responsibility for what is occurring in plain sight up and down the country. No  has seemingly abandoned any interest in Covid whatsoever.It comes after Boris Johnson said he canapost rule out another Covid lockdown after previously promising the route to normality was irreversible following two years of draconian restrictions. Mr Johnsonaposs plan has been for us to learn to live with Covid, and the lack of panic from rising cases appears to be due to reports that the latest strain doesnapost cause any more severe illness. Free Covid tests have now ended for the majority of people in England. Only the vulnerable, including those with health conditions and high-risk jobs, will be eligible to pick up swabs without paying. Health bosses still say that vaccines are the best line of defence and spring booster jabs are being rolled out for certain groups. title: uk covid hotspots revealed people
story: UK Covid hotspots revealed as people testing for the virus plummet in one weekThe latest Covid data show a huge . per cent week-on-week fall in people testing positive for the virus while hospitalisations have remained stable - but the number of tests has plummetedConfirmed Covid cases have dropped rapidly - but so has the number of tests being recorded Image: Getty ImagesByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Apr |commentsConfirmed UK Covid cases have dropped sharply in the past week - but the number of recorded tests fell by more than a million in seven days. Latest data show a huge . per cent week-on-week fall in people testing positive for the virus, while hospitalisations have remained stable.Sadly the UKaposs official Covid- death toll passed ,, with , people dying within  days of a positive test in last week.Scotland, where lateral flow tests are still available for free until later this month, is recording the highest rate of infections, latest data shows. In England the South West is recording the largest infection rate, figures released by the Department of Health confirm. It comes as the NHS Confederation warned that very high rates of Covid- are having a major impact on the health service - which is facing pressures it would see in a bad winter well into spring.It warned that ministers risk abandoning the NHSthey do not take action.As well as dealing with large volumes of Covid- patients, there are high rates of staff absences due to the virus, full hospitals and severe demands on emergency care.In the week commencing March , , delays of half an hour or longer were recorded in ambulance hand overs across all hospital trusts in England. The NHS Confederation said that in the last week alone  emergency departments in England have been forced to turn patients away as they issued erts due to being too full. HospitalisationsIn the past week , people have been admitted to hospital with Covid-, and on Friday there were just over , patients with the virus being treated in UK hospital beds. This is up from under , in mid-February, and higher than the post-Omicron wave in January. But more than half are being primarily treated for other conditions, NHS chiefs say. Latest figures show  per cent of those in England are being treated primarily for Covid. On Friday there were  Covid patients in mechanical ventilator beds - up by nearly  since early March.  Cases The number of confirmed positive tests is down signicantly in the past week compared to the week before. According to the latest Department of Health update, , people have tested positive for Covid in the past week - a drop of nearly .. But with free lateral flow tests scrapped at the start of the month in England, and isolation rules relaxed, this is to be expected to a degree. The government figures also show that the number of test results reported has also plummeted. From April  to April , . million test results were registered across the UK - down from more than . million a week before. Free lateral flow tests remain available in Scotland, where recorded infection rates are highest, for another week.  DeathsToday the official UK coronavirus death toll passed ,, with , lives lost since the start of the pandemic in .In the past week , people have died within  days of a positive Covid test - a  per cent rise on the previous seven days. However as with hospitalisations, this is not to say that coronavirus was the primary cause of death. In the week to March , Covid- was mentioned on , death certicates registered across the UK. Hotspots According to the latest government figures, the UKaposs  worst hotspots are all in Scotland. Devon, which is nd overall, has the highest rate in England, while Wrexham in Wales has the lowest. However these figures should be taken with a pinch of salt, as testing has been signicantly scaled back in England. glorious sunshine.And with travellers plotting their weekend, news of the warm weather looks set to mean travel will be busy over the bank holiday weekend.The South East is predicted to be very warm Across southern and eastern areas weaposre more likely to see some sunshine and clearer skies in the afternoon. However, there is expected to be some drizzly rain which is expected later in the week across the North West along with the cloud, but it is not likely to cause disruption ahead of the bank holiday weekend. title: woman born vocal chord paralysis
story: Woman born with vocal chord paralysis forced to quit job and cant visit pubClaudia Serra, who lives in Croydon, London, has left vocal cord paralysis, which means that she struggles to be heard - with her voice described as breathy, quiet and weakClaudia Serra, who lives in Croydon, has left vocal cord paralysis, which means that she struggles to be heard Image: Claudia SerraByEmma MagnusCharlie Duffield:,  Apr |commentsA woman says she has been forced to quit her job and avoid loud environments as a result of her extremely rare condition. Growing up in Italy, Claudia Serra knew something was dferent about her voice. She realised that she couldnapost scream in the playground like other children and singing in school plays was hard as well.Even just talking in a noisy environment or with a group was exhausting,My London reports. When Claudia was , she decided to see a doctor, and was diagnosed with left vocal cord paralysis, a rare condition which causes the voice to sound breathy, quiet and weak, and can affect the breathing.If both cords are affected, the voice can disappear altogether.In Claudiaaposs case, the condition was caused at birth as she was been born prematurely at just six months old. The -year-old said: Despite the pathology, it was a relief to know what was happening. It was the answer I had been waiting for for a long time, especially in adolescence...I was ready to do what I could to find my voice. Once she had finished school, Claudia started speech therapy, which aimed to move the working cord towards the paralysed one. After nine months of twice-weekly sessions and daily breathing and vocal exercises, she found out that, despite some nodules on her vocal cords being removed, her voice still sounded the same.In , Claudia opted for a surgical intervention, known as an Injection Laryngoplasty. The surgery works by injecting fat into the vocal cords to increase their volume - and means that Claudia lost her voice entirely for a week, communicating with a pen and paper. When it re-emerged, it had increased in strength - but only temporarily. The following year, Claudia says she re-attempted the same surgery, only to find that the results were similar: a brief period of improvement, before her voice ed to its previous state. For the next six years, Claudia tried dferent forms of speech therapy, to little success.  Eventually, she says her doctors in Italy told her that there was nothing more that they could do for her. She said: This brought me a lot of sadness...I have never been able to enjoy a nice evening in the pub, or go out for dinner with a group because it is dficult to be heard in noisy environments. Otherwise at the end of the day, vocal fatigue assaults you and you no longer want to talk to anyone. A vocal problem affects everyday le. Itaposs not just about having a hoarse or lower tone - the voice is a delicate communication tool. [We use it to]communicate, to work, have social relationships and to express our feelings. The voice is the mirror of the soul.In October , having moved to London two years earlier, Claudia had her third surgery: a thyroplasty, where an implant was inserted through the cartilage into her voice box. She was optimistic, and at first pleased with the results. She said: After surgery in November my voice was much louder, as was my laughter and coughing. I had less respiratory fatigue while walking, for example, and in noisier environments it seemed easier to raise my voice and speak. But in December, Claudia felt disappointed again, as her voice began to strain in loud environments. [Itaposs like] I miss the air, asI were climbing a mountain. I have to rest, plus [I have] neck and throat pain. At the time, Claudia says she was working at a dog grooming salon. With the sound of dogs barking, pets being washed and people talking, Claudia says it became dficult for her to communicate - leading to fatigue and severe neck pain - and she left the job. It was a real blow that Claudiaaposs third surgery hadnapost altered her voice. She said: I was hoping that with the last intervention I would finally be able to get my voice, to get more vocal stability, but it didnapost happen. Of course, there are those very dficult and despondent moments, but then I look inside myself and I see that there is still that strength and courage to go on and keep fighting. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Claudia is now waiting to find out whether she will need to undergo a fourth surgery. In terms of her work, she is having a hard time finding a job which will accommodate her needs. She enjoyed her role at the grooming salon, and loves cooking, flowers and photography, but requires a quiet working environment where she does not have to strain or raise her voice. All this has made me a very empathetic, sensitive person who knows how to listen, said Claudia. I would also like to expand my knowledge on the voice - and maybe one day help someone like me.  And, despite her long struggle to be heard, Claudia is finally speaking out: she runs a YouTube channel and Instagram account where she shares her experiences, and intends to write a book about her vocal journey.She said: Despite the ups and downs, these years in search of my voice have given me the strength not to give up. There are many people with dferent vocal problems, who do not feel understood, who feel alone, who do not know how to treat their pathology, or who give up. I want them to know that they are not alone and that they donapost have to give up...I know how hard it can be, but one day you will find your voice! title: inside creepy unfinished theme park
story: Inside creepy unfinished theme park Cementland where owner was crushed by bulldozerSculptor Bob Cassilly had the idea for Cementland which was labelled one of the "strangest theme parks in America" but his idea never made it off the ground after was tragically killedThe attraction would certainly be niche Image: Paul Sableman  FlickrByKirsty CardReporterLiam Buckler:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsA former cement factory was going to become a childrenaposs amusement park project called Cementland - before the owner was crushed to death by a bulldozer. Sculptor Bob Cassilly had the idea for Cementland, which was a -acre attraction that was once a thriving factory outside of St. Louis, Missouri but when the factory closed down, the area became a dumping ground for construction companies.The theme park was herald as one of the strangest theme parks in America for its niche theme and troubles over the years, the Daily Star reports.The original cement buildings had been neglected and decaying- but Cassilly had a vision to spruce up the landscape to a wide range of dferent ideas.  Mr Cassilly had a vision which ran more than just cement and ruins as he saw an idea for art and history, architecture, and evolution. Bob said back in : ‚ÄúThey talk about historic districts and stuff like that but one of the main things is, our architecture is basically copying stuff from Europe. But our industry, it‚Äôs kind of like jazz, it‚Äôs an American, original thing.  Why not look at it for what it is  It‚Äôs impressive. It might be threatening, but you can‚Äôt help but be impressed by it.‚Äù The attraction has been photographed by Paul Sableman, where you can see glimpses of Mr Cassillyaposs vision for the amusement park were slowly taking place. His dream was to create an art amusements park but it never got off the ground after a horrying incident where Cassilly was tragically run down by a bulldozer and killed on the building site of Cementland on September , . He was  years old.  However, his widow and several medical experts didn‚Äôt believe that Bob‚Äôs cause of death was a bulldozer accident. In , physician Dr Arthur Combs reexamined the autopsy reports and said he believes the sculptor was beaten to death before the murder scene was staged to look like an accident.Over the last six years, the ruins have fallen into further disrepair after a warehouse fire caused a roof to fall in. There was an attempt to put security in who were hired to keep vandals and trespassers away in  but in  there is no evidence that this arrangement remains in place, according to the latest photographs. And over the last last six years, the land has been neglected after a warehouse fire caused a roof to fall in. In order to honour Cassilly‚Äôs le, memorials have been held at Cementland but the attraction remains incomplete. story: Mum comes up with plan to make sure her baby isnt switched at birthA woman took to TikTok to share how shes going to make sure her baby isnt switched after she gives birth in a video that has been viewed more than , times Image: @my_sahm_lestyle TikTokByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Apr |commentsAlthough there have been incidents of switching newborns, theyaposre incredibly rare.To reduce the chances of this happening, hospitals have a number of precautions in place like giving babies a band with their details on and even footprinting.But this doesnapost always put parents at ease.Mum-to-be Sahm, who is  weeks pregnant, came up with a plan to ensure this doesnapost happen to her and shared the idea on her TikTok @my_sahm_lestyle The video, which has been viewed more than , times, was captioned: Have y‚Äôall seen switched at birth  Yeah...he‚Äôs getting a cute white or blue toe at birth lmfao.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. She explains: Me paranoid because I‚Äôve heard of babies being switched at birth, so whatever works and keeps me at ease I‚Äôll do! People thinking I‚Äôm crazy for thinking of painting my son‚Äôs toenail when he‚Äôs born. Since being posted, the video has racked up more than , likes and dozens of comments from other parents who admitted they had done the same.One person said: I did exactly that with my  babies. Their dad went with them every time they took them for anything but it gave me peace. Another wrote: Girl you just gave me a good idea lol I‚Äôm taking a blue nail polish and [I donapost care] who tells me I‚Äôm crazy lol. A third commented: Thataposs very clever. Do it!!!! You are the Mumma. Others shared alternative ideas that could put her mind at ease, as one woman suggested: I just didn‚Äôt let them take my baby out the room whatsoever. They did everything right in front of me.Sahm replied, saying: Of course, I want that too but sometimes things can happen. I want to be extra prepared in case baby has to leave the room. Another remarked: I took a mental note of the positioning of my baby‚Äôs milk spots. And someone  suggested that she put a sticker somewhere on the babyaposs body where the nurse canapost see.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: my friend wants name baby
story: My friend wants to name her baby after an STI - shes making a big mistakeA woman took to Reddit to ask users whether she was in the wrong for upsetting her friend in a baby name discussion - but many people said she did the right thing Image: Getty ImagesByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Apr |commentsA woman has angered her friend after pointing out the real meaning behind a baby name she loves.In a post on Reddit, the anonymous woman explained that her pal, who is five months pregnant, often shares potential baby names with their friend group - and the most recent is a little unusual.Yesterday we all got together to hang out and she told us her latest favourite. Chlamydia, she revealed. Apparently, the mum-to-be has been obsessed with the name ever since reading The Odyssey in school and always liked her Greek Mythology stories. Realising that her friend was referring to the character Clytemnestra, she corrected her, but this only annoyed the mum. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. So I interrupt her and go, aposWait, you mean Clytemnestra not Chlamydia. Right apos And sheaposs all, aposNo, I meant Chlamydia.aposAfter a quick Google search proved that she was right, the friend backed down - but she was noticeably annoyed for the rest of the night.When the Reddit poster went home that night, she received a long text from the mum, calling her a bad friend for embarrassing her in front of everyone. She says I could have brought it up in private and didnapost need to be so condescending about it.She was just talking about a name she liked and I made her feel like an idiot. The woman said she ignored the text, as she thought her friend was being an idiot, for basing her childaposs name on a book she hadnapost read in years and mixing it up with an STI. A simple google search before getting so attached to the name would have solved the problem before there was one, she said. But then she started getting texts from the other girls in the group telling her how upset the mum was and how she should apologise.I donapost think I have anything to apologise for, and besides, they were perfectly happy to sit there and let her think her std baby name would be a good choice, she continued. Imagine how embarrassed she would have been after she found the mistake later and realised that none of her friends had the decency to tell her the truth. She concluded her post by asking Reddit users whether she was in the wrong but the majority said she did the right thing. One person said: You didn‚Äôt embarrass her - every single person within earshot already clocked her mistake - you were the only person decent enough to correct her. Another wrote: If sheaposs old enough to be pregnant, she should be old enough to know what chlamydia is. She embarrassed herself. While a third commented: You were the only real friend thereno one  was gonna say anything.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news weird-news people-convinced-dog-cat-old-"Owner shares adorable moment dog and rescue cat cuddle on sofaByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Apr |comments An adorable dog and rescue kitten have persuaded people they were actually a human couple in a past le.Three-year-old shepherd hound, Meadow, was tasked with choosing his own rescue kitten to adopt, and straight away, he was drawn to one-year-old Twig. Ever since arriving home, the pair have become utterly obsessed with one another and are inseparable. Their owner, LeeAnn Babirad, from New York, US, shared a TikTok of them snuggled up on the sofa, and it has been viewed more than . million times.She told The Mirror : So, I took Meadow to a private farm to pick out her own kitty. These two approached other and the rest is history. Theyaposve been best friends ever since.  to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. They eat together, play together, sleep together. They even watch critters out the window together.In the viral video, the duo are peacefully laying on the sofa watching television. Meadowaposs arm is cradling Twig and she rolls over to nestle even further into his neck.The footage is captioned: If we could all love each other like this catand dogdo. In the comments section, thousands of animal lovers have shared their devotion to the pair. One person said: Quite possibly the most precious thing Iaposve ever seen. while another wrote: This really touched my heart and made me tear up. One user commented: But whatthey were a couple in a past le... and they finally found each other again. The theory was supported by dozens of other TikTok users, with a fan echoing: This is totally an old couple who loved each other dearly then came back as a cat and a dog.The duoaposs adorable relationship is even more precious because Meadow recently lost his canine companion. After LeeAnnaposs service dog sadly passed away, she took Meadow to a privately owned farm and let him choose a cat to adopt. She explained: I watched them all interact with each other. They approached each other and both acted submissive. So, we brought Twig home that night! The pair have since been captured on TikTok sharing food bowls, playing together and sleeping in the same bed.Another dog who has become best friends with rescue kittens is one-year-old puppy Popsy. Popsy developed a close bond with foster cats, Fawn, Hera and Ralph, after owner Catherine Walsh, , from Wapping, London, fostered for the animal charity, Battersea.Catherine said: Anything Popsy would do, they would want to do as well - they would wait at the door for us to get back when I took her on a walk. story: Sainsbury‚Äôs employee dishes the dirt on the most annoying thing that customers doA Sainsburys employee has gone viral on TikTok for revealing the most annoying part of his job and comments customers say that wind him up the most in a video that has been viewed , times Image: @akafiali TIKTOKByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Apr |commentsEver wondered what supermarket assistants really think of you when youaposre shopping  Well, hereaposs your chance to find out.Sainsburyaposs employee Akafi Ali has revealed what itaposs really like to work at the store and the most annoying things that customers do on his TikTok @akafiali.In a video that has since been viewed more than , times, Akafi said the most irritating thing that customers do is arrive before the shop opens on a Sunday. Most stores open for business at am on a Sunday, but some keen shoppers are seen turning up as early as am Akafi says. Since being posted, the video has racked up more than , likes and almost  comments, many from retail assistants who could relate.One person said: Say it again for the people in the back. title: terrifying spirit armies 30ft phantoms
story: Terrying spirit armies and ft phantoms among spectres haunting famous UK landmarksParanormal investigator John West, , from London, has compiled a catalogue of bone-chilling stories from the rural communities and cities of Scotland in his new book, Britains Haunted HeritageGhostly apparitions of clashing armies and a ft grey man are mentioned in Johns book Image: Getty ImagesByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr |comments Monstrous ft ghosts and clashing spirit armies are just some of the terrying phantoms haunting landmarks across Scotland, according to a paranormal investigator. John West, , has toured the country to compile a catalogue of chilling experiences for his new book, Britainaposs Haunted Heritage.In the tome he writes of mountain beasts, a fleet of phantom Viking longships and the spirit armies from each side of the English Civil War battling even after death. The folklore expert has compiled two books on ghosts after visiting Edinburgh and its spooky surrounds. He said Scotland is particularly re with the supernatural and spectres, calling it the most-haunted part of the UK, due to its history of war and plagues. John told The Sun : ‚ÄúScotland is a country steeped in history. It‚Äôs endured invasion, war and plagues.It‚Äôs no wonder it must be the most-haunted part of the UK. I believe Celts are much more in tune with the paranormal. But even now, there are places which make my blood run cold. ‚ÄúThe atmosphere becomes oppressive in these places and you just need to get out of there. Scotland has them in abundance.‚Äù The folklore expert revealed one particularly blood-curdling sighting is of a ft grey man which is said to haunt the hills of Ben Macdui in the Cairngorms. Reports about the humanoid monster go back  years, with climbers saying they were terrorised by the monster. Another story involves the ghost of a wizard stalking the grounds of a medieval building in Edinburgh.  John also wrote of the chilling case of Major Thomas Weir and his sister Jane- who were both accused of witchcraft before being executed in . But a part of their home is still standing in the city - and visitors claim to hear laughter and chanting ringing out from its rooms. John, who says heaposs been interested in haunted sights since he was a boy, has been ghost hunting for  years. He said he became fascinated by the paranormal realm after sneaking away to read his mumaposs books of ghost stories. John would be transfixed by the phantoms on the covers, he added. The ghost hunter, who lives in London, says that rural communities and Scottish islands are just as haunted as the big cities like Aberdeen, Dundee, Edinburgh and Glasgow.  He says Iona - which is situated in the Outer Hebrides - is haunted by a fleet of ghostly Viking longships. Meanwhile, spectral armies have clashed at the Pass of Killiekrankie in Perthshire, John says. Earlier today, it emerged that a hotel dubbed the UKaposs most haunted terried the workmen tasked with its demolition after thinking they were trapped in rooms by unseen spirits. The former Birkdale Palace Hotel was once the talk of the town in Southport, attracting the likes of A-listers such as Frank Sinatra and Peter Sellers. The Hungarian Football Team, one of the best sides around at the time, called it home during the  World Cup before losing in the quarter finals to the USSR.Known for its luxurious reputation, the , room hotel had a dark history, Liverpool Echo reported.Its architect was said to have taken his own le when it was built in the s facing inland, rather than having its grand fa√ßade facing out to sea. In  night porter Alan Wills was found guilty of murder of six-year-old Amanda Graham, whose body was found under a bed in room . title: woman urged rethink marriage fianc
story: Woman urged to rethink marriage to fianc√© over his elaborate plan to avoid her familyA woman took to Reddit to ask users whether she was in the wrong for being angry at her fianc√© for playing a "horrible stunt" on her - but people are telling her to "rethink marrying this guy" Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsA woman has revealed how she was left fuming after her partner went to extreme s to avoid going to her familyaposs reunion.In a post on Reddit, the anonymous woman, , explained that her -year-old fianc√©, whom sheaposs been with for eight years, has a twin brother who looks exactly very closely alike. But due to him living overseas and restrictions in place because of the coronavirus pandemic, she has only met him a couple of times.This past weekend, her family was having a big reunion. My fianc√© complained about the reunion and told me he could not attend, she said, despite her saying how much it would mean to herhe met more of her relatives. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. However, when the day rolled around, he told her that he would meet her there. While we were chatting with family members, my aunt asked him what he did for a living and he answered, and everything seemed to go well, she said. When I got home, I saw my fianc√© sitting on the couch playing a video game. I askedhe had a good time at the reunion and he told me he did. But, having felt like something was off, she asked him to tell her what her cousinaposs name was - and he couldnapost answer. He thought about it for a long minute and then started laughing, she said.He told me that his twin brother attended the reunion and he was dropped off by a friend. I was so angry with him that I asked him to leave so I could think everything through. He went to stay with a friend and Iaposm still so devastated that he would pull this kind of prank on me. My parents are very upset with him and are being very supportive. He thinks Iaposm being dramatic and there was no harm in what he did. She concluded her post by asking users whether it was unreasonable of her to be angry with him, but people were quick to assure her he was in the wrong. One person said: This is gold! I have siblings that are twins. They pulled the olapos switcheroo in grade school. But by age  you should know better.Another wrote: That wasnapost a aposprankapos but a horrible stunt attempt for him to avoid a family reunion. I would evaluate this relationship and askpulling that aposprankapos was really worth upsetting his future in-laws. Not to mention how the extended family will feelthey find out about this stunt. A third commented: Itaposs honestly really weird, though. Itaposs like they watched way too many kidaposs shows where twins swap places and thought it would still be hilarious even though theyaposre grown men. Someone  wrote: Homie dropped these, along with a number of red flag emojis. And one person said: Really better rethink marrying this guy. What do you think  Was he wrong to prank her or is she overreacting  Let us know in the comments.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: food chain worry sparks summit call
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: ice cream mackies
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. title: exports spike in red meat to us set to drop
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express‚ÄØePaper‚ÄØapp will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm,¬†or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening¬†Express¬†branded newsletters.¬†You will now receive¬†Press and Journal¬†newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express¬†ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: sullivan family says dr grays made the difference in safe delivery of baby
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express‚ÄØePaper‚ÄØapp will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm,¬†or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening¬†Express¬†branded newsletters.¬†You will now receive¬†Press and Journal¬†newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. title: six by nico aberdeen opening date the chipper menu
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express‚ÄØePaper‚ÄØapp will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm,¬†or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening¬†Express¬†branded newsletters.¬†You will now receive¬†Press and Journal¬†newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express¬†ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles.
