title: young-musicians-show-talent-contest
story: The Young Musician of the Year competition, which attracted a dozen young people from schools and music schools in the town, was held recently via Zoom.The winner of the vocal section was Kirsteen Brownlee, from the Mansfield School of Music, with her performance of I‚Äôd Give My Le For You by Claude-Michel Sch√∂berg from the musical Miss Saigon.Sam Scott, a drummer from Loretto School, came out top in the instrumental section with the Paul Simon hit  Ways To Leave Your Lover.The runners-up were both pupils of Musselburgh Grammar School ‚Äì Sadie Croosdale in the vocal section, with Requiem from Dear Evan Hansen by Benji Pasek and Justin Paul, and pianist Michael Hoole in the instrumental section with Praeludium by the German composer J.S. Bach.The musicians played and sang a wide iety of music, ranging from classical to ‚Äôs pop legends Duran Duran, giving the judge, Rob Harrison, of Erskine Stewart‚Äôs Melville Schools, a tough task.The musicians attracted ‚Äúconstructive and positive comments‚Äù from him, a club spokesperson later said.She added: ‚ÄúThe club would like to pass on their very grateful thanks to the music teachers, accompanists, parents and, of course, the wonderful competitors who once again impressed hugely with their skills.‚Äù

title: relay-life-coming-dunbar-summer
story: East Lothian‚Äôs first ever Relay for Le will be held at Hallhill in Dunbar on June -.Teams can sign up for the event, which sees team members take turns to walk around the track for a -hour period to signy that cancer never sleeps.Elaine Lennon, chairperson of the Relay for Le Dunbar committee, encouraged people to sign up.She said: ‚ÄúAccompanying this fun, family-friendly and accessible challenge will be a festival-like atmosphere of entertainment for the whole community, who will be invited to join in the fun while cheering the participants on.‚ÄúKey elements of it are the emotive and celebratory survivors lap which launches the event, the reflective Candle of Hope which lights up the track overnight, and the opportunity to fight with us in the battle against cancer by raising and donating funds for Cancer Research UK .‚ÄùRelay For Le celebrates the power of community fundraising in the fight to beat cancer.Teams of family and friends fundraise for cancer research, then unite as a community to celebrate and remember everyone who has been affected by cancer.One in every two people will get cancer in their letime.Cancer has played a part in the le of Elaine, who grew up in Dunbar before moving into Edinburgh.Her brother Greig Hannan was just  when he died from kidney cancer in September .The talented musician played lead guitar in the Setting Sons, a classic punk covers band, and also worked as a postman.The dad-of-three, who lived on the town‚Äôs Ash Grove, also played football for Dunbar United and Cockburnspath FC.Elaine‚Äôs dad, Duncan Hannan, was diagnosed with bladder cancer later that year and will be on hand to walk the survivors‚Äô opening lap by Elaine‚Äôs side, after she was diagnosed with breast cancer five years ago.Speaking about her diagnosis, she said: ‚ÄúI was scared, upset and mainly worried about how mum and dad would cope with even more of this dreadful disease in the family.‚ÄúMy husband Alan and daughter Carrie were my rock, and Carrie even agreed to shave my hair for me to help me take control.‚ÄúSix years on, now, and I‚Äôm feeling fine.‚ÄúCRUK was an incredible help in many ways, from the role they played in discovering radiotherapy and other key treatments.‚ÄúAlso, working for CRUK made me more aware of checking myself and that‚Äôs what found my lump and made me go see about it.‚ÄúThe whole family now take part in fundraising to create more tomorrows for more families.‚ÄùThe county‚Äôs first Relay for Le will get under way at am on Saturday, June .The Candle of Hope ceremony will then take place between pm and .pm as walkers continue throughout the night.For more information, search for Relay for Le on Facebook, visit cancerresearchuk.org or email relaydunbar@gmail

title: cherry-trees-planted-gifford-remember-impact-pandemic
story: The trees were planted on March  ‚Äì the second anniversary of the start of the first lockdown ‚Äì outside the village‚Äôs Tweeddale Arms Hotel.The National Trust came up with the idea to create spaces where people could remember all those who had lost their lives, honour key workers and reflect on the shared experience of the pandemic.Gford Community Council, East Lothian Council and Gford Horticultural Society created the tribute.Roger Wilson, Gford Horticultural Society president, was delighted to be involved, with the trees also to be registered as part of the Queen‚Äôs Green Canopy, which is marking the Queen‚Äôs Platinum Jubilee.He said: ‚ÄúThese cherry trees will bloom each spring around the time that the pandemic first changed our lives.‚ÄúThey will be a permanent reminder of those incredibly challenging times and a symbol of how our community came together to help one another.‚Äù

title: vet-column-taking-pet-holiday-plan-long-way-advance
story: These last two years have really taken their toll on our ability to go on holiday, but hopefully this summer we should be able to make our way to sunnier places without too much red tape. Unfortunately, I still have a job to do and won‚Äôt be holidaying for a few months, but it doesn‚Äôt stop me dreaming of sun and sea. I do love the south of France and hopefully I‚Äôll be heading there soon.But what about my pets  When I‚Äôm away for a short spell, I like someone to look after my pets in their own home. They are relaxed in their own environment.However, when on a longer holiday, my pets are looked after extremely well by boarding kennels and cattery in East Lothian. Cats are not usually the best travellers but you can try using calming cat pheromones to relax them. Your vet can advise you on ‚ÄòFeliway‚Äô cat calming products for any journey. My dog Lucy, on the other hand, loves travelling and adores going to the boarding kennel. She gets so excited when she knows she is on her way to the kennels.But whatyou want to take your pets with you on holiday  In Britain today, pets can travel by road, rail, sea or air. Each form of travel presents its own unique set of problems.The Highway Code is very specic about animals in cars. They should be under control in vehicles and unable to distract you while you are driving. If you want your dog to be loose in the car, he should be separated from you, and thus an estate vehicle, SUV or hatchback with a strong dog guard is ideal. Alternatively, a crate or cage can be used, the dimensions of which should be comfortable for the animal.Travel, or more correctly motion sickness, affects many dogs. It is due to the effect of the motion on the organs of balance located in the inner ear. Signs are usually excessive salivation, restlessness or excitement. Consult your veterinary surgeon as there are several prescription medicines that are extremely effective for this condition. Excitable dogs can be tranquilised but make sure you do not give too much, which may result in your pet becoming very drowsy, since the dose depends largely on the temperament and amount of excitement.Remember that even the most well-behaved dog can take fright at the sight and noise associated with a railway station and trains. Make sure that the collar and lead are strong and secure.Today, dferent railway companies have ying conditions regarding the transport of pets and therefore you should always enquire prior to your trip. Cats should be transported in secure carriers at all times. When travelling on the underground with your dog, remember it must be carried up and down any escalators. If you have a large dog, seek other means of access to the .Many ships and ferries today have permanent kennels into which your dog must be placed for the duration of the trip. The provision of a familiar blanket or toy helps to ease the tension of the journey for your pet.International Air Transport Associationregulations regarding carrier size apply to all international flights. Remember the container will be your pet‚Äôs home for theof the flight and also for an appreciable time prior to and after the flight after you have checked in and until he is collected after the flight. The carrier should be large enough for your dog to stand up and turn around freely. It is useful to use several thicknesses of newspaper, plus an acrylic dog bed of the VetBed type as bedding. A familiar article in the container helps to calm the animal. It is always worthwhile checking with the airline regarding their particular requirements.Not only has Covid- had a marked effect on travel, Brexit certainly has in respect of travelling overseas with your pets. Previously, for travel to EU countries, we vets could issue passports for your pet to travel with you to Europe. This is no longer the case.If you are considering travelling to an EU country with your pet, please start to plan long before your trip. Animals, specically dogs, cats and ferrets, require an Animal Health Certicateto travel to an EU country, including Northern Ireland. Any other pets require an Export Health Certicate or,you are travelling to non-EU countries, you will require a specic certicate issued in combination of DEFRA and the country you are travelling to.If you are travelling to an EU country, your pet needs to be microchipped and registered to you in the UK. This has to be read and confirmed by a vet prior to your pet being vaccinated against rabies.Recently, Mr Andrew Finlayson came to our Tranent surgery with his beautul greyhounds Celt and Lassie for their rabies vaccines. I checked their microchips and their paperwork prior to giving their vaccines. The AHC can only be issued more than three weeks after this rabies vaccination. The vet must be a registered official veterinary surgeonin order to be able to complete the certicate. The certicate cannot be issued until within  days of your travel from the UK date. Your vet needs to check your pet at this time.If you are travelling to Northern Ireland, Eire, Malta, Norway or Finland, your pet needs to be given medication against tapeworms between one and five days of you travelling. At Dunedin Vets, we combine this with the examination for the AHC.Each AHC is unique to your pet or pets. Up to five animals can travel on one certicate. The certicates are only valid for one journey from the UK. You have to state the country where you are entering the EU and there only certain designated ports or airports you can travel to. There is a specic AHC for each EU country and each one issued has its own unique certicate number, for your pet or pets. The AHC is valid for up to four months you mustto the UK before this time is up, but you can travel around EU countries during this time.These AHCs are long documents which have to be completed accurately with all the correct details, which owners have to provide in advance to the veterinary surgeon who completes them.If you are considering taking your pets to the EU this summer, contact your veterinary surgeon as soon as possible to ensure all the required paperwork is in order. We want to avoid disappointments at all costs.If you are wanting to travel further afield, contact DEFRA as soon as you know. A recent Export Health Certicate for dogs travelling to Dubai took almost six months to arrange.Plan in advance and hopefully everyone can have a lovely summer holiday.

title: dunbar-park-new-home-french-sport-petanque
story: Visitors to Lauderdale Park will be able to try their hand at the sport of petanque.The sport, which involves trying to score points by having boules closer to the target than the opponent, dates back more than  years.Now, after work between ious groups, a petanque piste has been created in the town, similar to that found in Haddington and North Berwick.Stuart McCombie, who has represented Scotland in petanque, is behind the idea to bring the sport to Dunbar.He said: ‚ÄúI used to play petanque many years ago at ious levels with ying degrees of success.‚ÄúI retired to Dunbar three years ago and there are no petanque facilities within Dunbar.‚ÄúFor the last of couple of years, I have been playing in Haddington.‚ÄúThey have got a beautul piste set up beside the river and the church.‚ÄúI play there with the UAand it was not until I moved here and joined that I was playing regularly again on a Wednesday.‚ÄúThey also play on a Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday and it is a long-established nice group of folk.‚ÄúI looked round and North Berwick have got a small piste by the tennis courts but there‚Äôs nothing in Dunbar.‚ÄùDunbar already has its own French connection, having been twinned with the town of Lignieres for nearly  years.Discussions took place between Mr McCombie, Dunbar and District Twinning Association, Dunbar Community Council and Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership . An appeal was put out on social media to check levels of interest in the facility being created.Mr McCombie told the Courier he was ‚Äúquite taken aback‚Äù by the feedback and decided to move forward with the plans.Funding was sourced from both the community council and DELAP, with work to create the piste in Lauderdale Park well under way.Mr McCombie said: ‚ÄúThe building is near completion.‚ÄúThe piste is now almost up and running and I‚Äôve had the first throw, just testing the surface.‚ÄúIt is a fantastic setting, a beautul setting. I did not think for a moment we would get inside the walled garden of Lauderdale Park.‚ÄùMembers of the public will be able to play the sport whenever there is not an organised event being held.Anyone without their own boules can hire them for ¬£ ‚Äì which covers everyone involved in the game ‚Äì from the park‚Äôs cafe.Disabled access has also been created at the piste, with an official launch expected to coincide with Dunbar Civic Week, which runs from June  to  this year.Pippa Swan, community council chairwoman, was delighted to see the plans moving forward.She said: ‚ÄúSeveral dferent options were considered and the conclusion was Lauderdale Park was the best.‚ÄúIt is protected, it has a wall, a cafe, when children are playing in the garden the parents can play petanque.‚ÄúThe other big thing is that it is entirely accessible to anybody. Little kids can play, adults can play, disabled people can play and I just thought it was fun.‚Äù

title: outlander-heading-east-lothian
story: John Muir Country Park, near Dunbar, was converted into an -century battle camp on Sunday, with residents spotting rows of identical old-fashioned tents.Other period pieces were also spotted, including horse-drawn carts, cannons, old-fashioned woven bags for sand or grain and other smaller props.The area remains cordoned off to the public, with cast and crew not having arrived on the site as of yet.The period drama has become an international sensation, following the history of Scotland from the Highland clearances to the Jacobite rebellion and beyond.Actor Sam Heughan has been spotted filming already in Fe and Edinburgh, leading many to believe he will soon be visiting East Lothian as well.More details about what historical battle will be filmed in the county remain unknown, but locals will be hoping to get a glimpse of their favourite actors as they eagerly await the next instalment of the series.

title: met-office-easter-bank-holiday-scotland-weather-forecast
story: It‚Äôs not all bad news though, the weather is set to clear up towards the weekend and it should certainly start to feel a little warmer than it has of late.While it might not be time to pack away your umbrella just yet, spring-like weather is on the way.If you havent already heard, its warming up in the run up to #Easter, but just how high will #temperatures climb  üìàFind out in our updated weather for the week ahead üëá pic EfHeVdpPIt is a rather wet and chilly start to the week rain is expected across most of Scotland today and tomorrow. Expect highs of only - ¬∞C.From Wednesday the weather should start to pick up as warm air spreads northwards, although there will still be the odd shower in places.Another dry day for most parts on Thursday and feeling warmer still with highs of around  ¬∞C.Friday could see temperatures reach as high as  ¬∞C but rain will start creeping back into most regions too.And it‚Äôs not good news for Easter egg hunts as despite Saturday predicted to bring much of the same more settled weather, there is likely to be a distinct turn for the worse come Sunday.For the following week, there is predicted to be a northwest-southeast split likely, with the northwest remaining more changeable with strong winds and rain at times.So while its not all bad news, a heatwave is perhaps overstating the milder weather expected in the coming days.

title: cockenzie-doctor-running-5k-day-year
story: Dr Peter Churn has worked at The Harbours Medical Practice since October  and has long expressed his love for running for his physical and mental health.The doctor has a colourful travelling past, completing his undergraduate medical training in St Andrews and Manchester before travelling to South America and New Zealand, where he worked in a small hospital.He specialised in general practice in Bath before ing to Scotland via New Zealand.The father-of-three said: ‚ÄúI cannot overstate the benefits that a letime of running has given to me.‚ÄúSometimes runs have been easy and joyful, sometimes runs are stf and painful, but I have always felt better afterwards.‚ÄùDr Churn is aiming to complete k a day until the end of  by squeezing in runs ‚Äúaround work and family things‚Äù.The doctor will set off each Tuesday at pm from the medical practice car park for an hour-long run and is encouraging staff and patients to join him.He added: ‚ÄúThis is an hour where we encourage all our staff to spend time doing something for their wellbeing.‚ÄùDr Churn‚Äôs usual days in the practice are Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday, and when out of the office he enjoys cycling, paddleboarding, or running along beaches in East Lothian ‚Äúor after his dog and three children‚Äù.He said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd love ityou would join for a run and blether. We‚Äôll go at the speed of the slowest runner ‚Äì which might be me!‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm not there at pm, please go without me ‚Äì I might be on holiday or le has got in the way for a bit and I‚Äôll see you soon.‚ÄùThe route runners will take is: start at Harbours Medical Practice car park take South Lorimer Place until Whin Park play area turn left onto public path heading westacross field to Edinburgh Rd, heading west turn right onto John Muir Way footpath , heading east around power station site past Cockenzie Harbour past Port Seton Harbour cut across the Links back to Links Rd heading west turn left onto Avenue Rd back to surgery.

title: north-berwick-rugby-boys-just-edged-yorkshire-tournament
story: The county youngsters took on English opposition in a competition hosted by Sandal Rugby Club, Wakefield.As well as the hosts, teams from Gravesend Rugby Club in Kent and Surreys Old Cranleighans Rugby Club also took part.The North Berwick boys ended with a record of two wins, two draws and one defeat to just miss out on top spot.Coach Iain Macintosh said: "It was a successful tour and the boys - and the dads who accompanied them - had a great time."Although the lads finished runners-up to Gravesend, who were a physically bigger outfit, it was generally commented on that North Berwick had played the best rugby."Some injuries went against us but we punched above our weight and look forward to hopefully touring again in future. And thanks to Mike Hetherington at Morrison Personalised Wealth Management for sponsoring the boys tops."Despite the Covid pandemic, the under-s have welcomed more boys to their ranks as the squad has increased in size from  to  this season."This has all been down to the lads¬†enjoying their rugby and inviting along their mates," added Macintosh.Three years ago, the same group won the Scarlets Invitational Rugby Festival in Wales.North Berwick Rugby Football Clubs under-sline up before the start of their tour games in Wakefield, Yorkshire. Pictured areLewis Scott, Oscar Mackenzie, Grfyn Williams, Jake Hetherington, Adam Little, Stan Watson, Charlie Gill, Cameron Fyfe, Ethan Mulligan middle row: Kier McMullen, Jacob Jolly, Daniel Smith, Louis Napier, Gregor Macintosh, Ross Napier, Rhoan Fraser, Fergus Kinnaird, James Hendry and Ethan Glancy. At the front are tour mascots Moray Macintosh and Milo Fyfe.¬†

title: wordle-294-april-9-wordle-word-hints-todays-answer
story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result.If you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If you‚Äôre still trying to save your streak, then don‚Äôt scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Today‚Äôs word starts with the letter S¬†and ends with the letter R.It has two vowels.It can describe a set of items that can help an inidual ascend or descend to another floor in a building.What is today‚Äôs Wordle answer, Saturday, April  If you have given up on today‚Äôs game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now.¬†¬†¬†The Wordle for April ¬†is STAIR.¬†¬†The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.In a statement on Twitter he wrote: ‚ÄúSince launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.‚ÄúThe game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .‚ÄúIt has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me ‚Äì from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.‚ÄúOn the flip side, I‚Äôd be lyingI said this hasn‚Äôt been overwhelming.

title: full-list-scotland-bank-holidays-2022-including-jubilee---see-dates
story: With the Queen celebrating her Platinum Jubilee, the UK will mark the occasion with an extra bank holiday in June.¬†Scotland usually benefits from more bank holidays than the rest of UK we also have¬†January  while other countries do not.In this bumper year for bank holidays, here are all the  dates in Scotland...Monday January   Tuesday January   Friday April   Monday May   Thursday June   Friday June   Monday August   Wednesday November   Monday December   Tuesday December  Easter Monday is not a nationwide bank holiday in Scotland, but certain councils do observe Easter Monday, including¬†Edinburgh, Falkirk and Dundee.¬†Local councils in Scotland have the power to make certain days local public holidays.Bank holidays are a devolved issue in Scotland, meaning dferent powers¬†allocate the days off in Scotland and England.¬†While Scotland does celebrate holidays¬†including Christmas, Boxing day and Easter Friday on the same day as the rest of the UK, others¬†are on dferent dates.¬†Only Scotland marks January  with a bank holiday, and although¬†Englands summer bank holiday takes place on August  , Scotlands¬†comes at the beginning of the month, on August ¬†.¬†

title: dandelion-festival-planned-glasgow-inverness
story: However, Donald Shaw is now turning his attentions to food with a new Summer festival that will celebrate the age-old tradition of gathering to share meals, music and ideas.Mr Shaw said some of the most amazing experiences of his le had been "sitting around a table and sharing a few tunes" while touring around the world with his band.Taking place over three days in June at Glasgows Kelvingrove Park, he said the event also aimed to persuade more of the public to sow and grow what is served on the kitchen table.Scientists, activists, technologists and writers will come together with chefs to spark conversations around food poverty, climate action and sustainability.¬†The multi-instrumentalist and composer said he had picked artists who "shared the ethos" of what the festival is about and the line-up includes Emma Pollok, Admiral Fallow and Karine Polwart. However, performances on the more unusual spectrum will include a live recording by an artist of the sounds plants make as they grow.The festival will culminate with a long table community meal share.¬†: Karen Gillan leads Tartan Week parade in New York¬†"Ive always related to that idea of sharing food with music,"said Mr Shaw, who is originally from Taynuilt in Argyll and is married to Capercaillie frontwoman Karen Matheson."The whole idea of the project is community and the sustainable growing of food and the idea that you can encourage anyone to grow food, even it its a bag of soil of their doorstep."As a musician I spent years touring and some of the most amazing experiences have been literally sitting around a table sharing food and a few tunes, particularly in foreign countries where you are sitting with people and you might not speak their language."Music cuts through all that."He said more artists were also considering how they can creatively engage with the public on issues such as the climate emergency.¬†"I think there is a new thought process for a lot of bands and musicians these days where its not enough to play music and book a gig and go onstage."They have to have some kind of sense of whats going on in terms of the environment and politically.: Full line-up revealed for Summer Nights Festival at Kelvingrove Bandstand¬†"Thats always been part of folk music, where you think about music less in commercial terms."Its the idea that you can come and hear some great music but you can also engage with new ideas."The Event Scotland-run festival has been funded by the Scottish Government and will be held from June -. A second event is planned in Inverness at Northern Meeting Park, from September -."We always had this great idea of a harvest festival being this iconic night in the calender in the say way as Burns night," said Mr Shaw."You share food that you have grown yourself and share music with people you know. Theres almost a spiritual level to it."He said the climate emergency had led him to consider whether it was ethical for musicians to fly half-way around the world to play one night at Celtic Connections.He said: "I have to think carefully as a programmer. What we are trying to do now is say, we cant justy flying you in butyou have other events or you can string together other shows in the UK."He said that this years blended model of some live performances mixed with online ticketed events had allowed the festival to reach a wider, global audience and said some of this might be retained going forward."What we did see more than anything from the live events more than anything was the power of the live experience. The communication between the artists and the audience is absolutely pivotal."I think the onscreen action will never be a substitute for the live experience."It should have been a safe space for informed debate, somewhere for readers to discuss issues around the biggest stories of the day, but all too often the below the line comments on most websites have become bogged down by off-topic discussions and abuse.¬†heraldscotland is tackling this problem by allowing only subscribers to comment.We are doing this to improve the experience for¬†our loyal¬†readers and we believe it will reduce the ability of trolls and troublemakers, who occasionally find their way onto our site, to abuse our journalists and readers. We also hope it will help the comments section fulfil its promise as a part of Scotlands conversation with itself.We are lucky at The Herald. We are read by an informed, educated readership who can add their knowledge and insights to our stories.¬†That is invaluable.¬†We are making the subscriber-only change to support our valued readers, who tell us they dont want the site cluttered up with irrelevant comments, untruths and abuse.In the past, the journalist‚Äôs job was to collect and distribute information to the audience. Technology means that readers can shape a discussion. We look forward to hearing from you on heraldscotland

title: glasgow-kiss-tales-online-dating-womans-perspective
story: The fields of literature and journalism are lined with the soiled reputations of men who have tried to convey physical intimacy in print.Too often these eye-piercing accounts are transactional and mechanical like how you imagine a Which Guide To Sex might be.Often you‚Äôre left unsureit‚Äôs a sexual encounter that‚Äôs being described or a new event in the modern pentathlon.And so you approach an interview assignment such as this with a degree of trepidation.I‚Äôm meeting Sophie Gravia, the young author of what might turn out to be one of the defining literary works of Scotland‚Äôs collective lockdown experience.This -something Glaswegian wrote A Glasgow Kiss from the collected accounts of her on-line dating experiences and those of her friends.It started le as a lockdown project from a series of Facebook blogs, written anonymously.Before long they were being shared widely by womenfor whom Sophie‚Äôs dating experiences struck several chords.They are raw, unflinching and very, very funny.The book, though fictionalised, features Zara, a young Glaswegian health worker whose online dating adventures could have been scripted by Quentin Tarantino and Bette Midler.But they‚Äôre characterised by the seasoned Glaswegian‚Äôs capacity to find humour in the most absurd and socially awkward encounters.And amidst all the unrefined concupiscence and gleefully abandoned foundation garments there is tenderness too and the eternal struggle of a young woman seeking reassurance and validation about her looks and experiences.This being The Herald, I‚Äôve chosen the comparatively subdued aftermath of one of Zara‚Äôs bedtime rendezvous which she discusses with her friend, Ashley.‚ÄúSo, how big was he,‚Äù she screeched as she walked through the door into the kitchen, holding the Chinese bags in her hand.I burst out laughing. ‚ÄúF***ing big. Like ‚Ä¶ this big.‚Äù I pulled a rolling pin out of the cutlery drawer.‚ÄúLucky! And was he generous ‚ÄùThis confirms all men‚Äôs worst nightmares of how women describe these occasions.The full account of the previous evening‚Äôs exertions are outrageously funny and gloriously manky.In all the spilling and leaking and splashing, though, there‚Äôs humanity and compassion as one girl struggles through shame and self-doubt to find what everyone is looking for: love and a little tenderness.‚ÄúI was really touched by the messages I was getting from other women when I first started posting my blogs. They were telling me that they‚Äôd been waiting for years for someone to describe how it really is for them in real le.‚ÄúThere was a time when people tended to be judgmental about dating websites, as though it was for desperadoes. But it‚Äôs totally mainstream now.‚ÄùI ask herit‚Äôs not fraught with a greater degree of peril for women than it is for men. Are they taking a bigger risk Several of my female friends have relayed tales of meeting blokes who think that the simple act of agreeing to go on a date is a contractual guarantee of sex.‚ÄúI‚Äôve never agreed to date someone with whom I haven‚Äôt had a prolonged period of chatting beforehand. Therefore, you can usually tell who the roasters are. Are they over-affectionate or too complimentary about the way you look ‚ÄúAndyou‚Äôre only agreeing to have a coffee then that sets its own boundaries.‚ÄúWhen I was younger I was probably quite naive about all of this, but you learn from experience. I think you can get a sense of someone from the way they dress and their chatthey‚Äôre bad news.‚ÄúMy friends call this ‚ÄòThe f***-boy vibes‚Äô.‚ÄùThis is one of several revelatory locutions with which Sophie acquaints me during our conversation. I strive to appear knowledgeable and seasoned about all of this and affect an insouciant man-of-the-world vibe that soon crumbles.I‚Äôm treated to some other new concepts. One of these is ‚Äúdropping a pin‚Äù.Sophie explains this is a safety mechanism where her friends can electronically embed her location on their smartphones in case anything untoward unfolds.Another one is the ‚ÄúTinder-walk‚Äù. This, Sophie explains, became one of the big features of Scotland in lockdown while people like me were watching old football videos and trying to decipher cookery books.Yet this Tinder-walk malarkey possesses a reassuringly vintage aesthetic. ‚ÄúEveryone got a dog and went on Tinder walks during lockdown,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt helped to ease us all through the social restrictions and was a way of keeping the flames of romance enkindled.‚ÄùHeather Suttie, the Scottish events and PR specialist, was thrilled when she first read A Glasgow Kiss. ‚ÄúIt just seemed to be what a lot of us had been waiting for,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt remember laughing so much at a book ‚Äì and crying too.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just so honest and it could only have been written by a Glaswegian because it‚Äôs got that honesty and directness that‚Äôs usually missing from fiction that deals with sex and relationships.‚ÄùSuttie is founder of BookFace, an international, online book club that holds monthly events in Glasgow with modern authors. ‚ÄúWhen Sophie appeared at one last month the response from women and men was overwhelmingly positive. Yes, some of the scenes are outrageously graphic, but they‚Äôre leavened with humour and honesty.‚ÄùThere are several astonishing aspects to A Glasgow Kiss. It‚Äôs been written by a first-time author who had not the remotest idea of how to break into the publishing world and yet has secured her a two-book deal featuring the further adventures of Zara.And as well as hitting top spot in the Erotic Fiction charts, Waterstone‚Äôs made it one of their books of the year. Yet, she‚Äôs still looking for a literary agent.Perhaps the most startling is that Sophie wrote the book while juggling the demands of being a full-time nurse in a busy Glasgow hospital during lockdown with the responsibilities of being a single mother to two children.‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt really stop to think about that,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWriting the book probably helped me cope during the pandemic.‚ÄùAnd while the majority of the responses to the book have been from women, quite a few blokes responded too.‚ÄúI can honestly say that all the responses from men, including from some former internet dates, have been very positive. They all got the humour.‚ÄúOne messaged me last night and said: ‚ÄòF*** me, it was like reading an old scuddy mag when I was a lad. If you ever feel like ditching the halo just give me a shout and I‚Äôll take you out‚Äô. I mean, where did he even get his hands on the book ‚ÄùAny worries she may have harboured about the reactions of friends and family were ill founded.‚ÄúI‚Äôd only initially told a few of them and they were all so supportive. I was a bit more anxious about my family‚Äôs reaction, to be honest.‚ÄúThey‚Äôre all pretty committed and traditional west of Scotland Catholics, but my mum says she‚Äôs very proud of me. She hasn‚Äôt read it and I don‚Äôt really want her to. But she knows what it‚Äôs about. And my family have also said that, of all of them, I was the one with no filters.‚ÄúI recently bumped into one of my gran‚Äôs friends, a woman in her s. She waved over and said: ‚ÄòI bought your book. I sat down with it at  o‚Äôclock last week and I didn‚Äôt stop til am.‚Äô And she‚Äôs the holiest wee woman ever. She‚Äôs lovely.‚ÄúAnd then she said: ‚ÄòYour granny would have been so proud of you‚Äô. ‚ÄúI was also a bit worried about how it might be received at my workplace. And then I saw that some of my patients were reading it. One of them was sitting in our dialysis unit reading it and asked me to come over and sign it for her.‚ÄùRecently, on the gogglebox, there have been some howlers posing as provocative television drama that are about as edgy as Classic FM.You find yourself unconsciously casting A Glasgow Kiss even as you‚Äôre reading it, as it‚Äôs perfect for a six-part comedy drama. The second book in the series will be published in August and by then Sophie hopes to have found an agent.There‚Äôs a message from the author at the front of the book. It says simply: ‚ÄúThis book is for any girl who has ever wondered why she isn‚Äôt enough.‚ÄúJust open your eyes and raise your standards. I see you.‚Äùl A Glasgow Kiss, by Sophie Gravia, is published in paperback by Orion Books, ¬£..It should have been a safe space for informed debate, somewhere for readers to discuss issues around the biggest stories of the day, but all too often the below the line comments on most websites have become bogged down by off-topic discussions and abuse.¬†heraldscotland is tackling this problem by allowing only subscribers to comment.We are doing this to improve the experience for¬†our loyal¬†readers and we believe it will reduce the ability of trolls and troublemakers, who occasionally find their way onto our site, to abuse our journalists and readers. We also hope it will help the comments section fulfil its promise as a part of Scotlands conversation with itself.We are lucky at The Herald. title: nadine-dorries-presenter-kirstie-allsopp-clash-channel-4-privatisation
story: The pair exchanged messages on Twitter after an opinion piece by Ms Dorries was published in the Mail on Sunday, addressing the Government‚Äôs decision to push ahead with plans to sell off the channel.Ms Dorries wrote that former Conservative prime minister Margaret Thatcher, who set up Channel  in , had ultimately wanted it to be ‚Äúfree from the constraints of the state‚Äù and described opposition to the move as ‚Äúlazy, overwrought and ill-informed rhetoric from the Leftie luvvie lynch mob‚Äù.Allsopp, who presents property show Location, Location, Location on Channel , responded on Twitter, questioning whether it was ‚Äúreally ministerial‚Äù to describe those contesting privatisation as a ‚Äúlynch mob‚Äù while ‚Äúat the same time complaining about having been accused of fascism‚Äù.Sharing an article about the US Senate passing an anti-lynching Bill, she added: ‚ÄúThis piece might make you think twice about using the term.‚ÄùThe Government confirmed last week that it will proceed with plans to privatise Channel , which has been publicly owned since it was founded in  and is funded by advertising.Allsopp responded to the announcement by tweeting that ‚Äúno true Conservative would sell Channel ‚Äù and that ‚ÄúLady T will be spinning in her grave‚Äù.Replying to her posts on Sunday night, Ms Dorries suggested Margaret Thatcher‚Äôs memoirs, The Downing Street Years, proved she intended Channel  to be sold.She also said Channel  could not be preserved in its current state because of ‚Äúdecreasing advertising revenue and decreasing investment in new content‚Äù.The Tory MP added: ‚ÄúThere is of course the bonus a sale will bring to the entire sector which is that the proceeds of sale will be invested back into people from all backgrounds, especially those from left-behind communities because talent is everywhere, not just in the SE.‚ÄúWe will invest in skills in order to benefit from incoming demand due to our booming film and TV sector due to the favourable tax benefit relief and funding this gov has put in place to encourage film industry to regard Britain as its home.‚ÄúI also love C, especially Location Location, but as I say in my article, it‚Äôs time to look to the future. The channel‚Äôs salad days are in the past. Being owned by the Gov is restrictive. Time for C to fly the nest towards a very exciting future.‚ÄùMs Dorries also apologised to Allsopp after spelling her name incorrectly.She said: ‚ÄúApologies, I know your name is spelt Kirstie, @KirstieMAllsopp. My autocorrect disagreed, I should have double checked!‚ÄùPlans for the sale will reportedly be set out in a White Paper later this month and will be included in a new Media Bill for next spring.A string of Tory MPs and peers, including Sir Peter Bottomley, former Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson, chairman of the Digital, Culture, Media and Sportcommittee Julian Knight, and former cabinet ministers Damian Green and Jeremy Hunt have publicly questioned the plans.Sir Peter, who represents Worthing West, said he opposes the sale ‚Äúbecause I am a Conservative‚Äù.On Monday, Lucy Powell, Labour‚Äôs shadow culture secretary, dismissed the suggestion the sale of Channel  would help the regions.She tweeted: ‚ÄúSelling off C to a foreign media giant is the opposite of levelling up. It will cost jobs in Yorkshire and across the North where C has been investing for years.‚ÄúApprenticeships, HQ and support for independent productions companies are all at risk.‚ÄùIt should have been a safe space for informed debate, somewhere for readers to discuss issues around the biggest stories of the day, but all too often the below the line comments on most websites have become bogged down by off-topic discussions and abuse.¬†heraldscotland is tackling this problem by allowing only subscribers to comment.We are doing this to improve the experience for¬†our loyal¬†readers and we believe it will reduce the ability of trolls and troublemakers, who occasionally find their way onto our site, to abuse our journalists and readers. title: wordle-297-april-12-wordle-word-hints-todays-answer
story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result.If you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If you‚Äôre still trying to save your streak, then don‚Äôt scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Today‚Äôs word starts with the letter R¬†and ends with the letter L.It has two vowels.Having the status of King or Queen, or a member of the family.What is today‚Äôs Wordle answer, Tuesday, April  If you have given up on today‚Äôs game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now.¬†¬†¬†The Wordle for April ¬†is ROYAL.¬†¬†The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.In a statement on Twitter he wrote: ‚ÄúSince launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.‚ÄúThe game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .‚ÄúIt has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me ‚Äì from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.‚ÄúOn the flip side, I‚Äôd be lyingI said this hasn‚Äôt been overwhelming.It should have been a safe space for informed debate, somewhere for readers to discuss issues around the biggest stories of the day, but all too often the below the line comments on most websites have become bogged down by off-topic discussions and abuse.¬†heraldscotland is tackling this problem by allowing only subscribers to comment.We are doing this to improve the experience for¬†our loyal¬†readers and we believe it will reduce the ability of trolls and troublemakers, who occasionally find their way onto our site, to abuse our journalists and readers. title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site or pages you visit which helps us to understand how we can improve the site for you.The Google AdSense service we use to serve advertising uses a DoubleClick cookie to serve more relevant ads across the web and limit the number of times that a given ad is shown to you.For more information on Google AdSense see the official Google AdSense privacy FAQ.More InformationHopefully that has claried things for you and as was previously mentionedthere is something that you aren#t sure whether you need or not it#s usually safer to leave cookies enabled in case it does interact with one of the features you use on our site.Howeveryou are still looking for more information then you can contact us through one of our preferred contact methods.Email: support@orcadianPhone:  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. ‚Äì SC Registered Office: Hell‚Äôs Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: face coverings to remain legal requirement until april 18
story: coronavirusFace coverings to remain legal requirement until April March ,  at : pmDue to the #very high level of infection# from COVID- and the resultant pressures on the NHS, the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, has announced that the legal requirement to wear a face covering indoors will remain until Monday, April .In setting out the context for this decision, Ms Sturgeon referred to the most recent Office of National Statistics COVID infection survey which found that one in  people in Scotland had the virus ‚Äì the highest level of infection that has been recorded so far in these surveys.‚ÄúThe volume of people in hospital with COVID is causing very signicant pressure for a health service that has been dealing with the pandemic for more than two years now,# she said. #That means we cannot be complacent.‚ÄùDespite the high rates of infection, the First Minister found some cause for optimism from the daily data, suggesting that the peak of the current wave has been reached and that the infection rate is perhaps stabilising.Nevertheless, the legal requirement to wear a face covering will remain for places of worship or for events like weddings or funerals until Monday, April .As of Monday, April , it will become guidance, rather than a requirement, to wear face coverings on public transport and in shops and other indoor spaces.Ms Sturgeon said: ‚ÄúThis phased approach strikes, I think, a sensible balance between our desire to remove this one remaining legal measure and the common sense need for continued caution, not least for the sake of the NHS while this wave of infection does subside.‚ÄùIn addition, for the period until Easter, everyone will continue to be asked to take to lateral flow tests twice a week, and to take a daily test for seven daysyou are a close contact of someone who has tested positive. People are also being advised to take a test prior to visiting someone who is vulnerable.If you develop symptoms, you should continue to get a PCR test.On vaccination, the First Minister said: ‚ÄúThe advice to everyone, of course, remains as important as ever ‚Äì please do take the opportunity to get vaccinated as soon as you are able and make sure you get all doses of vaccine that you are eligible for. This remains the most important thing any of us can do to protect ourselves and others.‚Äùcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. ‚Äì SC Registered Office: Hell‚Äôs Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: hoy head returns while the graemsay goes on refit
story: newsHoy Head s while the Graemsay goes on refitApril ,  at : pmIt#s a case of one in, one out, for the south isles ferries.The Hoy Head has ed from refit and has resumed sailing the Houton, Flotta, Lyness route, which had been covered by the Thorsvoe.While the Graemsay has gone for refit and the Stromness, Graemsay, Moaness route is being covered by The Nordic Sea.A spokeswoman for the council said: #It is hoped that the Graemsay will be back in service the last week in April.#However nothing is straight forward, due to prevailing weather and predicted tidal heights, on Wednesday April , the vessel has had to cancel all scheduled arrivals and departures from Moaness, while all sailings to Graemsay are under review.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: new cathedral vestibule complete
story: The transformation of St Magnus Cathedral#s west door vestibule is now complete, giving access through the main door for the first time in two years.Moderator of the Church of Scotland, Lord Jim Wallace, will be performing a sermon in the Cathedral on Palm Sunday, April , and has been asked to give a short dedication, which will be followed by a blessing from Cathedral Minister, Reverend Fraser Macnaughton.Custodian and visitor services officer, Fran Hollinrake, had the privilege of opening the main door on Tuesday morning.‚ÄúI was so delighted to be given the honour of unlocking the main entrance doors after two years‚Äô closure due to COVID and the restoration works,# she said.#The new vestibule has been signed off and means it is available for use so that everyone can enjoy this, not only practical new entryway, but also its magnicence.‚ÄùThe restoration and the new vestibule have been made possible with funding from the Society of the Friends of St Magnus, and the work was carried out by local firm Casey Construction Ltd, under the watchful eye of the Cathedral‚Äôs Historic Buildings Conservator, Meredith Macbeth.Elaine Grieve, chairwoman of the Society of the Friends of St Magnus Cathedral said: ‚ÄúThe Cathedral is so precious that it is hard to contemplate making any changes for fear they won‚Äôt do the building justice.#However, in this case, what an absolutely wonderful transformation the vestibule has made to the entrance of the building. The craftmanship is outstanding and we now have an addition which befits this treasured building loved by so many near and far.‚ÄùThe Cathedral is managed by Orkney Islands Council on behalf of the people of Orkney.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. ‚Äì SC Registered Office: Hell‚Äôs Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: oic election full candidate list revealed
story: Campaign season is now officially under way for the Orkney Islands Council election, after the full list of candidates was declared this Wednesday evening.Voters across Orkney are set to head to the polls on May , to elect the  councillors who will represent them for the next five years.Membership within the OIC chamber is broken up into six electoral wards. These wards, and their candidates are as follows:East Mainland, Burray and South Ronaldsay Kirkwall East Kirkwall West and Orphir North Isles Stromness and South Isles West Mainland Anyone aged  or over that day, resident in Orkney and registered to vote, will be able to vote. Letters have recently been sent to all properties, listing electors who are currently registered to vote andthey have a postal vote in place.Anyone not included on that letter can register to vote between now and Monday, April . Anyone registered to vote but not listed as a postal voter can apply to vote by post which must be ed by pm on Tuesday, April , or sooner.For full coverage of the election as we head towards polling day, pick up The Orcadian, available in shops and online from Wednesday each week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney to bloom in new series of beechgrove
story: newsOrkney to bloom in new series of BeechgroveApril ,  at : amThe latest series of Scotland‚Äôs premier gardening programme Beechgrovewill follow the toil and soil of an Orkney garden. vw, px"  The series introduced the a new strand ‚ÄòBeechgrowers‚Äô last year, which followed the sprouts and doubts of six gardeners across Scotland.This year the Beechgrowers are back, with six new hopeful horticulturalists, including Orkney based Sanne de Koeijer.Sanne, who is described as #a student, studying¬† Culture and Heritage with Gaelic studies. She grew up gardening with her grandparents in the Netherlands, and likes the idea of growing to feed yourself.#She has a  x  plot at a local community garden and the series will follow her green fingered venture.Beechgrove Executive producer Gwyneth Hardy said: ‚ÄúOur Beechgrowers ‚Äì including Sanne #¬† are all raring to go this year to share their gardening experiences, tips and occasional disasters.‚ÄúThere is a big emphasis among this year‚Äôs Beechgrowers on growing your own food, but they all promise to have a wealth of gardening stories to share across the board.‚ÄùViewers will be introduced to Sanne in episode two which is due to be aired on April .The new series of Beechgrove will air on Thursday‚Äôs at .pm BBC Scotland and will be repeated on Friday at . on BBC , the first episode will go out ion April .The programme will also be available on the BBC iPlayer.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: parish cup draw made
story: The draw for The Orcadian Parish Cup has been made ‚Äî with a potential heavyweight clash between Holm and Stromness in the quarter finals.Fteen teams were in the hat this morning as the draw for the first round was made live on BBC Radio Orkney, before the draw for the quarter final was made off-air.This year saw two teams re-enter the cup after period of absences in Harray and Stronsay, and as usual,¬†there was no shortage of intrigue and suspense as teams and communities discovered what the famed Radio Orkney Quality Street tin had in store for them.The full draw for the first round is:Deerness v StromnessHolm v StennessBirsay v StronsayRendall v SandayHarray v St AndrewsFirth v St OlaSandwick v South RonaldsayWestray ‚Äî byeThe first-leg first-round ties will be played over the weekend of May  and .The full draw for the quarter final is:Holm Stenness v Deerness StromnessRendall Sanday v Firth St OlaWestray v Harray St AndrewsSandwick South Ronaldsay v Birsay Stronsay.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: temporary closure for hatston recycling centre

story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.The Australian state of Victoria has been officially announced as host of the  Commonwealth Games.It will mark the first time a state or region has been awarded the Games, and the sixth time they have been staged in Australia.Victoria emerged as favourite from a number of interested parties in Australia, and entered into a period of exclusivity with the Commonwealth Games Federation in February.Sixteen sports, all of which are also part of the  Commonwealth Games in Birmingham, have been confirmed on the initial programme, with up to seven more set to be added before the end of the year.The Victoria Games will be staged across several cities including Melbourne, Geelong, Bendigo, Ballarat and Gippsland, with the opening ceremony at the Melbourne Cricket Ground.Melbourne also hosted the  Commonwealth Games, which were considered to be among the most successful ever. vw,vw,px, px"Scotland‚Äôs Kenny Anderson was among the gold medal winners in  CGF president Dame Louise Martin said: ‚ÄúThe Commonwealth Games Federation is absolutely delighted to award the  Commonwealth Games to Victoria.‚ÄúCommonwealth Games Australia and the Victorian Government have set out a bold and innovative vision that provides an exciting new blueprint for hosting our major multi-sport event.‚Äù

These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.World Rugby will consider introducing the -minute red card as a global law trial despite concerns that it could diminish the deterrent effect.The law, which is being trialled in Super Rugby, means the dismissed player can be tactically replaced by a substitute after  minutes.England lock Charlie Ewels was sent off after  seconds against Ireland in the Guinness Six Nations last month, with many observers feeling the dismissal ruined the game as a contest.World Rugby, however, is determined to keep lowering tackle heights and the Super Rugby trial so far has proved inconclusive.‚ÄúThat‚Äôs been discussed before and will be discussed again,‚Äù World Rugby chief executive Alan Gilpin told the Daily .‚ÄúIt would be greatmore competitions, even in a closed trial, would use it because that would give us more of an overview of the effect it would have on the game.‚ÄúWe need to see more of the data to see whether that strikes the balance between safety and spectacle better.‚ÄúThere is more work to do to analyse that and the concern is,a team goes back to  players, is that enough of a deterrent to drive that behavioural change.‚ÄúWe would like to see it trialled more widely before drawing any conclusions.‚Äù

title: lace to compete at crufts for fifth time
story: A Sandwick woman and her seven-year-old dog will compete at Crufts in a Scottish team this week # for the fth time together.Sally Sanford and Lace, her Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retriever, will take part in the rally event on Thursday at the NEC in Birmingham.The pair are part of a Scotland team who will face Wales, Northern Ireland and four English regional teams in the inter-regional rally competition.The rally course sees dog and handler work as a pair to navigate a course of between  and  dferent exercises.Ms Sanford said the competition was always #a step-up#.#You#re asking the dogs to do stuff that isn#t that complicated for them, but it#s the handlers who need to be able to multi-task, to concentrate in the moment and navigate their way around the course.#You need your head in the game.#But she said that was one of Lace#s strengths, and said he had finished second in his event previously.The pair are hoping for another strong showing, but with Crufts taking place for the first time since March , she said there were some uncertainties.#None of us know how busy Crufts is going to be this year,# she said.#I would be lyingI said there wasn#t a degree of trepidation.#She said that she was excited for theof the #enormous# event, though, and hopes Lace will be able to inspire Scotland to better their previous best performance of third...Pet pooches are being given the chance to test their agility and obedience without even having to leave their own gardens ‚Äì proving that lockdownSandwick resident Sally Sanford will be appearing at the Crufts dog show this week as part of the Scottish rally team with her Nova ScotiaA dog lover from Bigton says that making the final in the Kennel Club‚Äôs Eukanuba Friends for Le competition at Crufts  would mean the#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: new coxswain for lerwick lifeboat
story: A new full-time coxswain has been appointed to the Lerwick leboat.Twenty-nine-year-old Stephen Manson starts in the role today , replacing Darren Harcus who has taken up another coxswain#s role within RNLI.Mr Manson originally trained as a vehicle mechanic and has been recently employed on workboats in the salmon industry.He has been part of the volunteer crew on the Lerwick leboat since October , and will now take up a full-time role at the station.After undertaking training in the coming months he will take command of the leboat during future launches.Mr Harcus, who has been Lerwick coxswain since , has been appointed full-time resilience coxswain for the north of Scotland # providing relief coxswain work wherever he is needed.Lerwick leboat operations manager Malcolm Craigie said: #I‚Äôm delighted that Stephen and Darren have both been appointed to these full-time roles # they‚Äôre both experienced and capable members of our leboat crew.#We rely on full-time crew members to train and support our volunteer crews and to keep the leboat ready for launch  .#..Volunteer lesavers put their navigational skills to festive use by mapping out a Christmas tree design.Tributes have been paid to the brave lesaver Billy Deacon on the th anniversary of his tragic death. Lerwick RNLI issued a post of remembrance#Aith Leboat volunteers spent  hours at sea yesterdayhelping to recover a whitefish trawler which had lost power and was taking on water#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: power out at da street during cruise ship visit
story: Da street in Lerwick was hit by an unexpected power cut on Monday afternoon., which can hold over , passengers, is visiting Lerwick today .But shops along the street lost power just after .pm, with SSE saying the outage was reported to them at .pm.SSE said it had engineers working to restore the power shortly afterwards, and power was restored at around .pm.The company said at one stage as many as , customers across  Lerwick postcodes had been affected by the outage.The cause of the power cut was a fault on a high-voltage cable, SSE added, with engineers now investigating the fault.SSE said: #We would like to apologise to our customers who experienced a loss of power this afternoon and thank them for their patience whilst our engineers worked to restored power as safely and quickly as possible.#..SSE has presented two cheques totalling ¬£, to Shetland Foodbank. The figure has been highlighted by partner SSE#Farmers are being urged to stay safe when working near overhead power lines and poles.
