title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person‚Äôs parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary ‚Äì not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection ‚Äúa genuine product of the past‚Äù with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‚Äòblood is thicker than water‚Äô, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance ‚Äì strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly ‚Äì we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex G√†idhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much ‚Äìnot more ‚Äì influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the G√†idhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‚Äòmycelium‚Äô of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream ‚Äì the carrying stream ‚Äì slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: editorial budhmor decision must be
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineJust  weeks‚Äô notice has been given to families to make new arrangements for their loved ones, and while staff have apparently been offered alternative positions, there is considerable anger and upset among workers who have served the home and those who have lived in it with diligence and compassion over many years. adds our voice in support, and in doing so raises further questions about the provision of care for the region‚Äôs elderly.Not so very long ago there were residential care homes in just about every district of Skye and Lochalsh # in Staffin, Struan, Dunvegan, Uig, Broadford and Dornie.But changing regulations on facilities and staff were not sufficiently accompanied by support for the owners to make the transition the new rules demanded of them. It is now surely a matter of huge regret for our communities that so many small-scale care providers # despite their good reputation and obvious appeal in rural parts of the country ‚Äì have been allowed to wither on the vine and disappear. on standards which followed the Covid outbreak in April and May .Budhmor‚Äôs owners are not a shadowy offshore conglomerate trying to put profit before care ‚Äì but CrossReach, the social arm of the Church of Scotland. Despite their benevolent roots, the modern pressures facing the sector, they say, simply make it too dficult to keep their Portree home open.The building needs too much work and they don‚Äôt have the money to pay for it.The only option, families were told, is closure ‚Äì with the suggestion that the  residents could all be accommodated nearby in a refurbished and expanded Home Farm.It is not dficult to understand why families are so aggrieved at this proposal.Things may well have improved at Home Farm since the horrors of Covid, but have all the lessons been learned The blanket national policy of shting patients from hospitals to care homes in the frantic weeks of early  was a huge factor in the devastating Covid death toll that followed.Yet now, with the pandemic still not behind us, families in Skye are being told they should accept the transfer en masse of their elderly relatives to the very home so ravaged by coronavirus when it was proven to be over capacity and understaffed.At Budhmor, they managed to keep the home safe from the worst of Covid-. Relatives of residents will tell you that was no fluke ‚Äì but down to good standards, diligent management and conscientious staff.There will be some truth in the financial and staffing pressures that CrossReach cite in their reasons for closure. But two years on from the outset of Covid, should the sector not be doing all it can to preserve and build on the success of an institution which proved such a good example during the pandemic, rather than bowing to the bottom line and accepting its loss.There is also the matter of an options appraisal on health and care needs in the north of Skye, currently being prepared by NHS Highland.Closure must at the very least be halted until this review is complete ‚Äì andthis requires support for CrossReach, our Government should find it.In the longer term what we really need are alternative models to those that are currently governed by economies of scale than on inidual or community needs. An agenda of rationalisation and centralisation has taken hold of far too many of our public services and is ultimately driving decisions like the closure of small care facilities offering a homely, personalised environment in favour of a vast, but possibly distant one many miles from an inidual‚Äôs home community.No-where has this been more obvious, or dangerous, than in the west Highland health and care sector.We should start the fightback by backing Budhmor care home, and keeping it open.

title: education minister visits ballymena primary school
story: EDUCATION Minister Michelle McIlveen paid a recent visit to Ballymena Primary School.During the visit on March  the Minister spoke to members of the student bodies active within the school which included the School Council, Eco-Council and Digital Leaders. She witnessed children engaging in ICTlessons, in play sessions both indoor and outdoor and spoke extensively to staff on the Special Needs team. The pastoral and Mental Health programmes within the school were of interest to Minister McIlveen as well as how children had found theto face-to-face learning after Lockdowns. The Minister also enjoyed seeing a class making toast around the fire pit as part of their Forest School activities and was shown the continual development in children‚Äôs outdoor learning in the school which the staff were finding to have had a positive impact upon their well-being and academic achievement.The Minister was initially due to visit Ballymena Primary School as part of their ceremony to celebrate an outdoor play award called TOPS back in October . Due to ious Assembly commitments the Minister had been unable to visit until now and was keen to honour a promise made to visit what was the first primary school of the town established back in . Minister McIlveen was pleasantly surprised by the extensive, bright and modern interior of the school which was not immediately evident from outside and complimented the children on their behaviour, enthusiasm and sense of responsibility. The children of the school were happy to welcome Minister McIlveen and staff were delighted to be able to share some of the developments and progress made within the school due to the hard work and dedication of the staff.Principal, Mrs Ritchie said: ‚ÄúWe were so pleased to welcome the Education Minister to Ballymena Primary School on Wednesday as a way of celebrating all of the continued hard work and advances within the school. ‚ÄúThe Minister was happy to engage with the children and staff and asked interested questions around child development and we were keen to display as many aspects of our educational provision as time would allow.‚Äù

title: daria through to miss ni final
story: A former pupil of Patricks College in Ballymena has made it through to the final of the Miss Northern Ireland competition.Daria Gapska, a -year-old childrens nursing student, recently ed to the college for a presentation to Year  on her chosen charity Braveheartsni.Daria was one of two finalists to be crowned at the first live Miss World Northern Ireland Heat of  in Nu Delhi, Belfast in front of an an astute judging  which included Managing Director of ACA models and Event organiser Victoria Withers. The event saw girls from across Northern Ireland compete for their place at the Miss World Northern Ireland final.Daria was crowned as Miss Nu Delhi and Poppy Smith a  year old Biomedical Science student from Portadown was crowned as Miss Belfast. St Patricks College congratulated their former pupil on her success in the competition.The school said: ‚ÄúDaria has chosen Braveheartsni as her charity. It is a charity very close to our hearts as founder, Shealyn Caulfield is also a past pupil. ‚ÄúDaria did an excellent presentation on the charity to our Year  pupils and will present this to other Year Groups next week.‚ÄúWe wish her all the best with her preparations for the Miss Northern Ireland final.‚ÄùBraveheartsni is Northern Ireland‚Äôs only charity supporting the needs of teenagers and young adults with Adult Congenital Heart Disease.The charity has grown from the strong volunteer ethos of HeartbeatNI who are also a local volunteer charity who support families with children with congenital heart disease.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220410newscurry s fun park opens in portrush
story: AFTER months of waiting, Currys Fun Park in Portrush is finally open! The eagerly anticipated successor to the popular Barrys Amusements opened its doors for the first time on Saturday amid great excitement. Hundreds of people young and old filed through the doors all afternoon as the magic ed to Portmagic - and just in time for Easter. The good news is that Currys is now up and running, boasting all the old Barrys favourites and adding some new ones too. And for those with old Barrys tokens - no, you cant use them, but you can help the RNLI by dropping them into collection boxes dotted around the complex. The fun park has chosen the charity as its partner - a thoughtful gesture given the important work volunteers do in the waters off the north coast. But for now, after two years of zero craic because of the pandemic, all roads lead to the Port and what promises to be a fun-filled holiday period. Happy days.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220410newsfamiliar faces on this week s rare breed
story: UTV‚Äôs hit farming series, ‚ÄòRare Breed - A Farming Year‚Äô, s on Tuesday th April at pm. The families are bringing in their ious harvests and making preparations for next year. It‚Äôs October, and on the shores of Strangford Lough the Elliott family rear turkeys. The family have years of experience looking after the birds and yet Mark and Olive are still fascinated by their behaviour. Olive comments that they are ‚Äòextremely inquisitive‚Äô. While Mark is making sure the turkeys are well fed, his mum Olive can‚Äôt help giving them an extra treat. She comments too, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do without my family, I have to be so nice to them at the minute!‚Äù Mark points out that they have been receiving orders for Christmas since August, which is ‚Äòabsolutely nuts.‚Äô Near Kilcoo in the Mourne Mountains, Aine Devlin is preparing her flock for the most critical part of her farming year- breeding season. Aine is keeping an eye on her rams to make sure they‚Äôre doing their job. She coats their chests with paint to see which ewes they have been with. Aine laughs, ‚ÄúThis is his cologne for the girls!‚Äù For her AI is not the way to go as the ewes would then all lamb on the same day on the mountain. She loves this time of year and is proud of the part she plays in the economy. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs better than buying produce from down the road from your neighbours and local communities ‚Äù she says. Outside Crossgar, Richard Orr is thinking ahead to next year‚Äôs wheat crop. It‚Äôs all about the planning and attention to detail to make sure the groundwork is done right. He‚Äôs conscious of the environment, saying, ‚ÄúThe major thing in the world is carbon footprint. Chemicals have made farming easy, and modern machinery has damaged the structure of the soil - we need to rebuild that.‚Äù Meanwhile, just outside Portadown it‚Äôs all hands on deck for apple harvest at the McKeever family farm. There isn‚Äôt a high yield this year but sometimes things not going to plan can be a blessing. Pat talks about the seven to eight weeks of hell and this year pickers have been hard to get. Peter comments, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs half the battle when you have good people around.‚Äù On the Donegal   Londonderry border, potato farmer Jamie Rankin and his team are coming towards the end of their harvest. He enjoys the early starts and says, ‚ÄúWhat you do before dinner time‚Äôs your day‚Äôs work.‚Äù While it‚Äôs a job Jamie enjoys, it also comes with challenges as winter months close in. The bad weather has led to reduced yields and a late harvest, but he‚Äôs very proud to have produced a good crop. UTV‚Äôs Mark McFadden narrates the series. Sponsored by Moy Park, ‚ÄòRare Breed ‚Äì A Farming Year‚Äô continues on Tuesday th April at pm on UTV.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220411newsapril showers keep them shorter
story: Spring has finally sprung and with rising energy costs there is no better time to dust off old habits and create some new ones that are good for your pocket and the environment. Start by thinking how much water you are using each day. Whether you are washing your hands, cleaning endless amounts of dishes or getting through that mountain of washing, you start to realise just how important water is and the sheer amount we use. NI Water‚Äôs Environmental Outreach  Learning Officer, Anna Killen, explains how we can save water by looking at everyday habits, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs amazing to think that each day each person uses around  litres of water! However, saving water can be really easy, there are simple things we can all do that can make a huge dference. ‚ÄúDid you know that the average time people in Northern Ireland spend in the shower is  minutes, over % of people still overfill the kettle and less than frac of people have a waterbutt ‚Äù  ‚ÄúWe want that to change and it‚Äôs easy, start by looking at small changes for example, your kettle, since working from home it has have been working overtime, but just fill with as much water as you need. Overfilling can use twice as much energy and water, each time you boil. ‚ÄúWith rising energy costs, it might be time to think about reducing the time spent in the shower, hot water costs money! Why not try the  minute shower challenge, put on your favourite  minute song and seeyou can finish before the end.‚Äù To help you embed with these new habits and ‚ÄòGet Water Fit‚Äô, complete our online water audit at https:www.getwaterfit or take part in water saving challenges and receive your free water saving items including  minute shower timer, toothy timers and swell gel bags for the garden. Some water saving tips:  Turn off the tap when brushing your teeth - A running tap can use  litres ofwater per minute.  Use a bowl for washing vegetables - Then you can reuse this water for plants.  Make full use of your washing machine - Half load programmes on washing machines use more than half the water and energy of a full load, so wait until the machine is full before switching it on.  Fix leaking taps - A dripping tap can waste more than  litres of water per week.  Keep a jug of water in the fridge, instead of letting the tap run cold. NI Water are encouraging customers to sign up to its free text alert service which keeps them updated about anything that may impact on their water supply or any of our other services in the area.here https:www.niwater register-for-keeping-you-informed

title: two more rural schools to seek integrated status
story: Thumbs up: Gillygooley PS in OmaghSion Mills Primary School. Credit: Declan Roughan PressEyeMandatory Credit PressEye FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThumbs up: Gillygooley PS in OmaghMark BainTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailParents at two rural primary schools in Co Tyrone have voted overwhelmingly in favour of beginning the process of transformation to integrated status.Sion Mills PS and Gillygooley PS in Omagh both held the parental ballots necessary to begin the procedure.All parents were eligible to vote in the ballot, with % of Sion Mills PS parents casting a vote.Some .% voted yes to integrated status for the school, providing a resounding endorsement for their future plans.In Gillygooley PS there was % turn out and % voted in favour of moving to the next stage of the transformation process.There are currently  integrated schools in Northern Ireland with two more to follow in September this year, including Glengormley High School, which last month became the first post-primary school to transform to integrated status since .The news has been welcomed by Oonagh McNelis, principal at Sion Mills PS.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up ‚ÄúSion Mills Primary School has had a long history of serving all parts of the community and surrounding area since the Herdman family set up a school in the village in ,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúCross community education and inclusivity has been part of our ethos for almost  years. The natural next step for the school was to seek to formally integrate through the transformation process.‚ÄúIn everything we do as a school, we put the children and families first.‚ÄúWe‚Äôd like to thank the parents for pointing the way forward,‚Äù she added.We know through experience that learning together in an inclusive environment, even from this young age, is what is best for all children.‚ÄùAnd at Gillygooley PS acting principal Jayne Baird said the school was delighted at the unanimous support for integrated status.‚ÄúWe have a long tradition of providing a high standard of education to the rural community on the outskirts of Omagh, and we pride ourselves in encouraging our pupils from all communities to respect and learn from each other.‚ÄúEverything we do within our school community has the overarching ethos of ‚ÄòLoving to Learn, Learning to Love‚Äô and integrated status is an exciting next step for us.‚ÄùTina Merron, chief executive of the Integrated Education Fund said the news is another major boost in the campaign for greater integration in education.‚ÄúThis positive news coming so soon after the success of the Integrated Education Bill shows that parents are firmly behind the ideal of educating children together,‚Äù she said.The next step for both schools will be compiling a development proposal, which will be submitted to the Department of Education.The Minister for Education will then make the final decision.Related topicsDepartment of EducationMore On Department of EducationAnger as teachers are told to pay fees to suspended General title: jim wells resigns from dup after endorsing tuv candidate
story: DUP South Down veteran admits he walked before he was pushed Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseTUV‚Äôs Harold McKee with Jim Wells FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueTUV‚Äôs Harold McKee with Jim WellsEimear McGovern and Noel McAdamApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailJim Wells has resigned from the DUP in his latest move after dramatically endorsing the TUV candidate instead of that of his party for almost five decades.Speaking to the BBC‚Äôs Nolan radio programme, the South Down politician said: ‚ÄúI have now resigned from the party after  years. I have decided I cannot support the candidate that the party Executive have imposed upon the people of South Down.‚ÄùHe shared the news with local newspaper the County Down Outlook after the Belfastrevealed the turn of events which led Mr Wells to support TUV candidate Harold McKee ‚Äì which could have seen the veteran politician expelled from the DUP. On Tuesday morning, Mr Wells admitted he walked before he was pushed after late on Monday night, he made the decision to contact senior members of the DUP to resign. I feel very strongly about this and I feel that Harold McKee is the best candidate to represent the unionist community of South Down,‚Äù he said.  Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreJim Wells faces the boot from DUP for endorsing TUV candidateThe move could pave the way for the former Health Minister to eventually join Jim Allister‚Äôs party.Mr Wells on Monday night admitted many would view his action as ‚Äúsour grapes‚Äù after he lost the nomination for South Down ‚Äî having already lost his party whip.Read MoreMalachi O#Doherty:OpinionStephen Nolan doesn‚Äôt always get it right buthe is silenced, then what  He isn‚Äôt the first to be scapegoated for damage done by isionPastor Rusty Thomas: US preacher who attended Lurgan rally claims ‚Äòpowers of darkness‚Äô are pushing NI ProtocolThe veteran Assemblyman said he would have campaigned for Edwin Pootshe had won the nomination for the constituency but he could not support Diane Forsythe.The -year-old mother of three, who worked as an accountant, was chosen by party officers under the DUP selection procedures, despite many in the South Down Association still favouring Mr Wells.Mr Wells declined to elaborate on his opposition to Mrs Forsythe but said her nomination had left him with little option but to formally back the TUV standard-bearer Harold McKee.‚ÄúHarold McKee is the standout candidate and I urge those who supported me in the past to give him their number one preference,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúAs I leave the Assembly it is my earnest desire that South Down should continue to have a unionist MLA whose politics are grounded in conviction and principle.‚ÄúAmong the candidates, Harold McKee is the standout candidate with these credentials.‚ÄúHe holds dear many of the core principles that I upheld in Stormont and is widely and properly respected as a politician of conviction rather than expediency.‚ÄúAccordingly, I recommend him to those who faithfully supported me at the polls over the years and urge them to vote McKee .‚ÄùA DUP spokesman said, however: ‚ÄúIn our opinion only the main unionist party can win this seat and it is absolutely essential that we maximise the number of seats we have in the next Assembly.‚ÄúEvery seat counts. Make no mistake. If on the Saturday morning after the election, Sinn Fein is the largest party there will be no more talk of the health service or rising costs, the focus will be on getting a Border Poll.‚ÄúTherefore nothing should be done which would split the unionist vote. Although we don‚Äôt believe unionism has anything to fear from a Border Poll, it would be destabilising and a distraction from the important business we need to get on with.‚ÄùThey added: ‚ÄúThis election is much more important than mere personalities. The seat totals after the count will decide whether Northern Ireland goes in the right or wrong direction and our priorities for the next five years.‚ÄúDiane Forsythe secured the DUP‚Äôs best ever result in South Down in . She is a young mother, rooted in the Mournes with a plan for South Down. Diane will focus on what matters to people.‚ÄùMr Wells, meanwhile, arranged a photo-call with Mr McKee and the TUV leader on Monday. Former Ulster Unionist Mr McKee said he was delighted and honoured to have Mr Wells‚Äô support.‚ÄúIn the end he was abandoned by his own party but it is the mark of the man that he wishes the best for South Down going forward,‚Äù added Mr McKee who quit the UUP for the TUV last October over the more liberal approach of Ulster Unionist leader Doug Beattie and his party‚Äôs stance on abortion, same-sex marriage and support for a ban on gay conversion therapy.He added: ‚ÄúI am delighted to have Jim‚Äôs support and gratied that a broad swathe of unionism is uniting behind me as the standard bearer of principled unionism.‚Äù TUV leader Mr Allister also joined in welcoming Jim Wells‚Äô support but there was no comment on the prospect of him joining Mr McKee in the TUV ranks.‚ÄúAt critical times in Stormont Jim Wells was often the only MLA prepared to join me in doing what was right,‚Äù Mr Allister said.‚ÄúIn December  we were the only MLAs to speak and vote against  EU regulations essential to bedding in the iniquitous Protocol.‚ÄúPutting party advantage before principle would have been easy, but Jim did the right thing and likewise today in backing Harold he is putting principle before party.‚ÄùMr Allister insisted the Wells backing would bolster the chances of Mr McKee in the tightly-fought constituency where unionist isions could hand the last of the five seats to Alliance or the SDLP.‚ÄúIn strengthening Harold McKee‚Äôs hand he is laying the foundation for the continuance in Stormont of South Down representation based on conviction politics. We‚Äôve seen enough of synthetic unionism it‚Äôs good to offer the real thing with Jim Wells‚Äô backing,‚Äù Mr Allister added.Related topicsDemocratic Unionist PartyJim WellsTraditional Unionist Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium New ¬£m apartment complex in Belfast awaits approval from councilExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseAn artist‚Äôs impression of the proposed Loft Lines apartments FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueAn artist‚Äôs impression of the proposed Loft Lines apartmentsAndrew MaddenTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailBelfast councillors will later this week decide whether to grant planning permission for a huge, ¬£m apartment complex on the banks of the Lagan, made up of  units across three blocks.The application is for three buildings of between  and  storeys on land on Queen‚Äôs Road, next to the Titanic Quarter. Amenities are to include private balconies, shared courtyards and shared roof terraces. Some  units are to be social housing.Lacuna Developments, Titanic Quarter Ltd and Belfast Harbour have teamed up with Welsh firm Watkin Jones Group for the development, which will be called ‚ÄòLoft Lines‚Äô.It will be a mix of private rented and social apartments, alongside recreational spaces, gyms and children‚Äôs play area. Loft Lines will also include a public area with a sports park for outdoor events and exercise classes called South Yard Square, while there will also be space for a coffee shop, restaurant and creche.According to planning documents submitted on behalf of the applicants: ‚ÄúThe proposals describe a new, contemporary and sustainable residential development that is rooted in the qualities and history of the place and declares its future as an iconic waterfront neighbourhood. We want to express the three blocks as a cluster of urban objects around a new square. We believe each should have its own distinct qualities, derived from how it responds to its specic site and programmatic conditions, but should also feel related to its neighbours.‚ÄúDferent but the same. This ‚Äòurban assembly‚Äô has the potential to rest confidently on a prime site within the city ‚Äî a backdrop to the river. This will be arguably the first mixed use, mixed tenure residential development in this area of the city, providing much needed homes for people of all ages and backgrounds.‚ÄúA mix of social and affordable housing , alongside build to rentis proposed delivering a choice by providing ,  and  bedroom apartments and studios for rent, alongside social and affordable accommodation to meet a range of needs.‚ÄùDaily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up According to a briefing document prepared for members of Belfast City Council‚Äôs planning committee, consultees including the Department for Infrastructure, the Northern Ireland Environment Agency and Belfast City Airport have no objection to the proposals, subject to conditions.The document states the development would cost around ¬£m and generate an estimated  full-time equivalent construction jobs over three years.‚ÄúThe three buildings are referred to as Blocks ,  and a. Blocks  and a are proposed for Build to Rentblocks whilst Block  is proposed for social housingwith the remainder being managed by the Housing Association for private rental. An area of the sitewould be dedicated as a public square ,‚Äù the briefing paper reads.‚ÄúIt is further estimated that non-residential uses at the proposed development will require a total of  gross direct FTEjobs on-site to support commercial community operations in the retail, professional services, health and care and hospitality sectors. The application is accompanied by an Environmental Assessment which concludes that subject to appropriate mitigation, the negative impactswhich could arise from the developments are either negligible or are not signicant.‚ÄùTo date, the planning application has attracted six letters of support and nine objections. BCC planners have recommended the application for approval, subject to conditions.Related topicsBelfast City CouncilDepartment for InfrastructureGeorge Best City AirportMore On Belfast City story: The labour market recovery is continuing. Photo: Getty FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe labour market recovery is continuing. Photo: GettyEimear McGovernTwitterEmailApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailNorthern Irelands labour market recovery has continued in March with the number of payrolled employees now higher than pre-Covid for the tenth consecutive month.The number of employees receiving pay through HMRC PAYE in Northern Ireland in March  was ,, an increase of .% over the month and .% over the year according to the Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency .There was also a fall in the unemployment rate to .%. This latest unemployment rate is the same as the rate reported in the pre-pandemic period .However, the total number of hours worked and the unemployment rate are still below pre-pandemic levels.Read Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Northern Ireland graduates overpaid loans by over ¬£m in six yearsCompany responsible says students end up paying more due to the nature of the schemeExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseAccording to the latest figures, in the   financial year, a total of , graduates from Northern Ireland overpaid in their student loan repayments to the tune of ¬£.m. Credit: Chris Ison PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueAccording to the latest figures, in the   financial year, a total of , graduates from Northern Ireland overpaid in their student loan repayments to the tune of ¬£.m. Credit: Chris Ison PAAndrew MaddenTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailIt comes after the Belfastrevealed how some students here are leaving university with debts of up to ¬£,.According to the Student Loans Company , student loan over-repayments happen because of the nature of the loan repayment scheme, known as Income Contingent Repayment .Up until April , the SLC received student loan repayment information each year from HMRC, and as a result of this process some borrowers nearing the end of their repayments might overpay, the SLC said.Since April , HMRC has sent SLC student loan repayment information as reported by employers on a weekly basis, known as More Frequent Data Sharing, which the SLC says has helped reduce overpayments, but they still might happen unless a borrower switches to the direct debit scheme when eligible to do so.According to the latest figures, in the   financial year, a total of , graduates from Northern Ireland overpaid in their student loan repayments to the tune of ¬£.m. The average overpayment per graduate was ¬£.Figures also show , graduates received refunds in   and , graduates were awaiting a refund, as of January  this year. Since  , overpayments from NI students have totalled ¬£,,. The total amount of overpayments has been falling in recent years, from a high of just over ¬£m in  .The SLC said: Over recent years, a number of initiatives have been introduced to reduce over-repayments and improve the repayment process for SLC customers including introduction of the Online Repayment Service, automatic refunds and encouraging uptake of the direct debit scheme.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The frequency of data received from HMRC has also increased from annually to weekly. Additionally, further campaigns have been run to contact customers who have over-repaid, advising them to claim their refund. Therefore, these changes have reduced over-repayments and the decrease reported reflects this.Ellen Fearon of the student body NUS-USI said the SLC needs to ensure it places as much emphasis on locating graduates who have over-repaid as it would tracking down those it believes owe it money‚Äù.‚ÄúIn many cases, the SLC will no longer have accurate contact information to alert people they are owed money, so we would encourage all those who have repaid their loans to consider getting in touch with SLC to seethey are eligible for a refund and ensure their details on record are correct, she said.‚ÄúIt is also important for graduates to check their payslips and student loan statements to understand when the loan expires, which can address any overpayment. Ultimately, the SLC must reduce the incidence of overpayments by updating its systems and how it works with HMRC.‚ÄùAlliance Party economy spokesperson Stewart Dickson added: It is challenging enough for graduates to repay student loans without some people making overpayments. Better systems should be in place to prevent this from happening in the first place. Refunds should be made quickly and I would encourage former students to check repayment schedules once they begin.‚ÄùThe SLC said: ‚ÄúWe want to make it as easy as possible for customers in repayment to manage their student loan accounts and over the last two years we have made a number of improvements to help customers avoid over repaying.Our Prevent Over Repaymentscheme enables customers to switch to Direct Debit in the final years of payment as over repaying is entirely avoidable. In addition, our new Online Repayment Servicegives customers much more control over their repayment journey.‚ÄùThe news comes after figures obtained by the Belfastshowed that the level of student debt for NI graduates is topping ¬£, in some cases. One person from here has a student debt balance of more than ¬£,, while over , others have debts of between ¬£, and ¬£,.Figures released via a Freedom of Information request show the top five highest student loan balances of students from Northern Ireland are ¬£, ¬£, ¬£, ¬£, and ¬£,.Read MoreNorthern Ireland students ‚Äòburdened with debts of almost ¬£k‚ÄôRelated topicsStewart DicksonAlliance title: dup wont run females just to tick a box says candidate
story: There was criticism about the number of women who will be represented in electionsExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseDUP candidate Diane Forsythe. Credit: Press Eye FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDUP candidate Diane Forsythe. Credit: Press EyeLisa SmythTwitterApril   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe DUP has defended the low number of female candidates it is running in next month‚Äôs Assembly elections.With just a quarter of women making its list of candidates, the DUP has the lowest number of females in the running for election out of Northern Ireland‚Äôs five main political parties.By contrast, % of Sinn Fein candidates are women, followed by the Alliance Party, where half of its runners are female. The SDLP is next, with % of candidates women, while a third of the UUP‚Äôs runners are female.The DUP‚Äôs South Down candidate has rejected accusations of gender bias and said the party does not run females as a tick box exercise.Diane Forsythe, who has replaced Jim Wells as the DUP‚Äôs candidate after  years at Stormont, said: ‚ÄúI am an accountant and mother of three young children.‚ÄúI am the only DUP candidate in this constituency.‚ÄúA lot of parties field female candidates in seats where they have little chance of winning or they field women as a second candidate but then ide the area in way which makes it very dficult for the female candidate to win. This shouldn‚Äôt be about tokenism. The DUP run female candidates in seats where we can win.‚ÄùDaily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Ms Forsythe also pointed out the fact that the DUP was the first major party to have a female leader and female First Minister.‚ÄúWe want to see more females in politics but it should be on merit rather not than tokenism,‚Äù she added.Meanwhile, UUP leader Doug Beattie said ensuring more women represent the party at Stormont remains¬†a priority and that efforts will continue to increase the number of female UUP MLAs.‚ÄúWhen I took over as leader of the UUP in May last year, I made it one of my absolute priorities to encourage more female candidates to come forward,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúWe have not yet reached where I want us to be ‚Äî¬†% of our Assembly candidates are female, but I desperately want this to increase at the next Assembly elections.‚ÄúThey may have been selected, but the most important thing now is getting them elected alongside their male colleagues, so that we have a base to build on for the future.‚ÄúWe are on a journey and I want to bring about further change as we head towards next year`s council elections and every election after that.‚ÄùMr Beattie said he wants the make-up of his¬†party to¬†‚Äúreflect society‚Äù.He continued: ‚ÄúDiversity and inclusion can only increase the strength of any organisation. We need more role models and I hope that the exceptional candidates we are standing at this election will be future leaders in our party and society.‚ÄúWe are not yet there yet, but I am absolutely committed to taking us in the right direction.‚ÄùConnie Egan, who is running for the Alliance Party in North Down, welcomed the gender make-up of her party‚Äôs candidates which she said had happened without a quota being set.¬†However, she said more needs to be done to tackle sexism faced by female candidates: ‚ÄúWe each have a role to play in ensuring we continue to encourage more women to participate.‚ÄùRelated topicsDemocratic Unionist PartySDLPAlliance PartyNorthern Ireland AssemblyJim WellsDoug BeattieMore On Democratic Unionist Party PremiumMalachi O‚ÄôDohertyOpinionStephen Nolan
