title: rugby bosses consider bringing  minute red card global trial
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityThe law, which is being trialled in Super Rugby, means the dismissed player can be tactically replaced by a substitute after  minutes.England lock Charlie Ewels was sent off after  seconds against Ireland in the Guinness Six Nations last month, with many observers feeling the dismissal ruined the game as a contest. vw,vw,px, px"IRB‚Äôs head of rugby World Cup Alan Gilpin¬† .World Rugby, however, is determined to keep lowering tackle heights and the Super Rugby trial so far has proved inconclusive.‚ÄúThat‚Äôs been discussed before and will be discussed again,‚Äù World Rugby chief executive Alan Gilpin told the Daily .‚ÄúIt would be greatmore competitions, even in a closed trial, would use it because that would give us more of an overview of the effect it would have on the game.‚ÄúWe need to see more of the data to see whether that strikes the balance between safety and spectacle better.‚ÄúThere is more work to do to analyse that and the concern is,a team goes back to  players, is that enough of a deterrent to drive that behavioural change.‚ÄúWe would like to see it trialled more widely before drawing any conclusions.‚Äù.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Rugby bosses to consider bringing in -minute red card in global trial article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: no six nations today   find wales play next watch
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communitySimply put the players need a rest. Weeks three and five are typically break weeks during the championship to give the teams times to recuperate.If you are desperate to see how Round  will play out though, you don‚Äôt have long to wait. Games will resume next weekend during the Guinness Six Nations match at the Principality Stadium, Cardf. Picture: PA" alt"Penarth Times: Wales Jac Morgan is tackled by Scotlands Hamish Watson and Duhan van der Merweduring the Guinness Six Nations match at the Principality Stadium, Cardf. Picture: PA" class"editor-image"Wales Jac Morgan is tackled by Scotlands Hamish Watson and Duhan van der Merweduring the Guinness Six Nations match at the Principality Stadium, Cardf. Picture: PA Twickenham Stadium, London‚ÄãSaturday, February .pmNew Wales flanker Jac Morgan admits playing at Twickenham next week would be special given the historic rugby rivalry between England and Wales.Morgan won his first cap on Saturday as reigning Six Nations champions Wales bounced back from a Dublin drubbing against Ireland to beat Scotland - in Cardf.The Welsh-speaking Ospreys openside says he was so nervous before kick-off that he almost forgot the words of the national anthem ‚ÄòHen Wlad Fy Nhadau‚Äô.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always a dream to play for your country from a young age,‚Äù said the -year-old.‚ÄúGrowing up England is one of the biggest games with the rivalry between the two countries over the years.‚ÄúEverybody knows how big the game is with the history between the two sides."Morgan produced an impressive debut display last weekend, as Wales revived their Six Nations title hopes before heading to Twickenham next Saturday.Courtney Lawes has resumed full training in time to reinforce the middle phase of England‚Äôs Guinness Six Nations title push.Lawes was unable to play in the opening two rounds of the tournament because of concussion but has now completed histo play protocols and comes into contention to face Wales next Saturday..removeDefence coach, Anthony Seibold, said: "Courtney trained fully today , which is obviously really good news for himself and England. He looked sharp."Meanwhile, Wasps flanker Jack Willis is set to make his first appearance in a year after finally recovering from the serious knee injury sustained against Italy at Twickenham in the  championship.England v Wales Six Nations:¬†How to watch on TV, live streamThe England v Wales Six Nations match kicks off at .pm on Saturday, February .You can watch coverage on ITV or live stream the game via ITV Hub.Alternatively,you cant make it to a screen, you can also listen live on BBC Radio  Live Sports Extra. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log Share s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"  CommentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: england v wales six nations   watch itv live stream
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityThe fierce rivals both have title ambitions but neither team can afford any further slip-ups at Twickenham.The competition might only be at the halfway point, but it will effectively be game over for whichever team loses.Both countries lost their opening matches ‚Äì England being defeated by Scotland and Wales suffering an emphatic reversal in Ireland ‚Äì but then put themselves back on track with respective victories over Italy and Scotland.After finishing fth in last season‚Äôs tournament, England know they must kick on towards tough assignments next month against Ireland and France, while Wales‚Äô continued hopes of a successful title defence hinge on the outcome at Twickenham ‚Äì a ground where they have not claimed a Six Nations win since .We‚Äôre here for those unforgettable moments. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityIt is quite often the case that those going in for their usual shopping might come out with an extra item or two.Whether it‚Äôs¬†Aldi‚Äôs Specialbuys¬†or¬†Lidl‚Äôs Middle of Lidl, the latest offers are always worth checking out and there are some fantastic buys from Sunday April .Lets take a look at some of the items you can buy this weekAldi specialbuysAldi often have many products that are perfect for your garden, and this piece might be perfect as a statement piece.The¬†Gardenline Oxidised Fire Globe is on the slightly more expensive side at ¬£.¬†and¬†is described as a "stunning centrepiece" to anyones outdoor space." alt"Penarth Times: Gardenline Oxidised Fire Globe " class"editor-image"Gardenline Oxidised Fire GlobeIt has an intricate bird and leaf laser cut design¬†and can provide a great deal of warmth when it gets cooler in the evenings.You can buy it on the Aldi website hereAnother garden-related item can be found in the¬†Cordless Grass  Hedge Trimmer Shear, which can be bought at the Aldi website for ¬£..It should provide an effective tool in cutting off the edges of hedges, and comes with a battery included.Meanwhile,you want something in your garden for the kids to do as summer begins to roll around, the¬†Plum Junior Trampoline might do the trick.At a cost of ¬£. it can support a maximum weight of around kg and should work fine for small children to bounce around in.Another item that will be fun for the kids is an Inflatable Water Slide, which will be able to fit in your garden." alt"Penarth Times: The inflatable water slide from Aldi " class"editor-image"The inflatable water slide from AldiIt is on the pricier side at ¬£., but it comes with a slide, climb, water cannon and the water pool, and it is very compact to put away.If you fancy owning this for when the summer months come around, then go to the Aldi website here for it.Lidls middle aisleLidl have a number of items this week that are related to the great outdoors as the weather improves and you can go out exploring again..removeIf you plan to go out hiking then these Crivit Walking Boots for ¬£. should provide some sturdy support on your walks." alt"Penarth Times: Crivit Walking Boots " class"editor-image"Crivit Walking BootsAdditionally, Crivit also come in handy with a¬†L Hiking Backpack for ¬£., which has a spacious main compartment plus a holder for a hydration pack and water tubeyou desire it.Crivit actually do a whole range of products specically tailored for those wanting to go camping, such as with this¬†Insulated Drinks Flask for ¬£. and a¬†Pocket Kne   Multial Camping Cutlery¬†for ¬£.¬†to help out with a number of s. article_url title: red squirrel volunteer of the year
story: Larne man banned from driving for three years   Toome bypass tragedy: police release name of crash victimNewsCoronavirusTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsHealthBusinessEducationPeopleEnvironmentRead ThisUkraine CrisisFootballIrish League FootballSportMotorcyclingIce HockeyOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleFood and DrinkTravelHomes and GardensCars FamilyYour NIRetroOpinionAdvertise My Businesscanonical_urlCANONICAL_URLhostnameCANONICAL_HOSTNAMElocationCANONICAL_URLreferrerEXTERNAL_REFERRERpage_view_id_PAGE_VIEW_ID_scroll_SCROLL_HEIGHTgeo__INJECT_GEO__cid_ga:CLIENT_ID,comScore:CLIENT_ID,compass_uid:CLIENT_IDversionsha-wJFtySqNnAxBmRbBZGkmXyZeJTYkxlpMdJsFNIrrGVlru-DcIEIZ" class"i-amphtml-layout-container" i-amphtml-layout"container"Loading...NewsEnvironmentRed Squirrel Volunteer of the YearThe Red Squirrel Survival Trustis delighted to announce that Glenshesk man Gerard McCaughan is the winner of the David Stapleford Award for Volunteer of the Year .By Una CulkinTuesday, th April , : am  "       "  Mark Henderson presenting Gerard McCaughan with his awardThe award was originally presented in  as a letime achievement award to David Stapleford, a pioneer of red squirrel conservation.Following his passing, the award was ed to the RSST to be used in his memory.       " d"M.,.c-.-.-.-.-.-.c-.-.-.-.,-.c.-.,.-.,.,l.-. c.,.,.,.,.,c.-.,.-.,-.L,.c.,.,.,.,,.C.,.,.,.,.,."   " d"M,.c.,.,.,.,.,.c.,.,.,.,,.c-.,.-.,.-.,l-.,. c-.-.-.-.-.,c-.,.-.,.,,.L.,c-.-.-.-.,-.C.,.,.,.,,."   " d"M.,c.,,.,.,.,.c,.-.,.-.,.S,.,,.C,.,.,,.,"     " fill"#ea"   to our daily NorthernIrelandWorld Today newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Gerard was chosen from a hugely impressive number of nominations for his work across all aspects of red squirrel conservation and habitat restoration within the UK. Gerard, who is a volunteer for the Glens Red Squirrel Group the second longest Red Squirrel conservation group in Northern Ireland, Gerard was nominated by the Glens group for the outstanding work he does with the the group across the Glens and beyond supporting and advising those interested in red squirrel conservation.During his years volunteering, Gerard has worked endlessly to conserve native red squirrels, he has played a key role in many projects including educational and habitat enhancement projects within Glenshek and across the nine Glens of Antrim. Mark Henderson from the Red Squirrel Survival Trust travelled to the Glens of Antrim to present the David Stapleford Award for Volunteer of the Year to Greard. It was Mark‚Äôs first time in Northern Ireland and he visited many of the Glens Red Squirrel Groups feeding sites and projects across the Glens. He visited Cregagh Wood Hide in Glendun where the hide is managed by the GRSG. While there along with Gerard, Mark was able to see two Red Squirrels feeding and playing together. Mark Henderson commented: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre delighted to present Gerard with the Volunteer of the Year award. Gerard and his team‚Äôs devotion to the protection of red squirrels is evident in the work he is doing in County Antrim. Red squirrels rely hugely on the support of volunteers, and we enjoy being able to celebrate the work they do.‚ÄùGerard said: ‚ÄúI was surprised to be nominated let alone win. I‚Äôm chuffed and embarrassed in equal measures. I think it‚Äôs a reflection of what we do as a group rather than what I do myself.‚ÄùTo find out more about the Glens Red Squirrel Group visit https:glensredsquirrelgroup  or go to Facebook and search ‚ÄòGlens Red Squirrel Group‚Äô.Read More Read MoreRed Arrows toto this year‚Äôs NI International Air Show  "       "   for the newsletterKeep up with the latest news and views from NorthernIrelandWorldSign Up       " d"M.,.c-.-.-.-.-.-.c-.-.-.-.,-.c.-.,.-.,.,l.-. c.,.,.,.,.,c.-.,.-.,-.L,.c.,.,.,.,,.C.,.,.,.,.,." story: Police advise of closure of Lisburn‚Äôs Moira Road    pictures from Lurgan anti-protocol parade and rallyNewsCoronavirusTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsHealthBusinessEducationPeopleEnvironmentRead ThisUkraine CrisisFootballIrish League FootballSportMotorcyclingIce HockeyOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleFood and DrinkTravelHomes and GardensCars FamilyYour NIRetroOpinionAdvertise My Businesscanonical_urlCANONICAL_URLhostnameCANONICAL_HOSTNAMElocationCANONICAL_URLreferrerEXTERNAL_REFERRERpage_view_id_PAGE_VIEW_ID_scroll_SCROLL_HEIGHTgeo__INJECT_GEO__cid_ga:CLIENT_ID,comScore:CLIENT_ID,compass_uid:CLIENT_IDversionsha-wJFtySqNnAxBmRbBZGkmXyZeJTYkxlpMdJsFNIrrGVlru-DcIEIZ" class"i-amphtml-layout-container" i-amphtml-layout"container"Loading...NewsPastor‚Äôs Pen: Don‚Äôt worry! Do something instead‚ÄòDon‚Äôt worry!‚Äô How often have we heard that and how often do we say it to others  I suspect it‚Äôs being said quite often at the present time, when there seems to be so much to be worried about, writes Rev. Ron Elsdon.By The NewsroomSunday, rd April , : am  "       "  There‚Äôs the state of the Health Service, the never-ending fallout from Brexit, the war in Ukraine, and the spiralling cost of living which is already inflicting so much hardship on so many. ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt worry!‚Äô But the problem is that it‚Äôs far easier said than done. So when you come across it in the bible as well, you could be excused for writing it off as unrealistic. Please stay with me for a few moments, however, while I try to explain.        " d"M.,.c-.-.-.-.-.-.c-.-.-.-.,-.c.-.,.-.,.,l.-. c.,.,.,.,.,c.-.,.-.,-.L,.c.,.,.,.,,.C.,.,.,.,.,." Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Much of the bible comes from times and situations of great stress and worry, so it‚Äôs not simply saying ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt worry!‚Äô or offering you a technique like meditation to help you cope. It points you to something rather more than that. I offer you two examples where it offers you responses that are practical ‚Äì strategies,you like.Ron ElsdonFirstly, Paul directs people to pray instead, and to pepper their prayers with thanksgiving . The trouble is that we‚Äôre so good at finding things to complain about, often trivialities, that finding things to give thanks for doesn‚Äôt come easily, even to people who pray regularly, but why not switch course and actually do it, then keep on doing it  Then, says Paul, the protecting peace of God is there to be discovered, even in the midst of stressful situations. Secondly, Jesus talks about worry in the Sermon on the Mount . When it consumes us, he says, what we need is a new set of ambitions which point us beyond ourselves ‚ÄúSeek first God‚Äôs kingdom and God‚Äôs righteousness‚Äù is His command to His followers. As I write, I‚Äôm thinking about a local politician, one I shan‚Äôt be voting for. I know he spends Christmas Day at a place for the homeless, helping to serve up hot meals for that I admire him greatly. As I write, hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians are fleeing the army of a tyrant from the east, many with nowhere to go in freezing weather. In neighbouring countries, churches and other organisations are swinging into action to help support these folk in their hour of desperate need. So, in their dferent ways, Jesus‚Äô and Paul‚Äôs words in the bible are saying to us all, ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt worry! Do something instead.‚ÄôRead: Covid travel requirement set to change

title: wit wisdom this too shall pass
story: Larne man banned from driving for three years   Toome bypass tragedy: police release name of crash victimNewsCoronavirusTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsHealthBusinessEducationPeopleEnvironmentRead ThisUkraine CrisisFootballIrish League FootballSportMotorcyclingIce HockeyOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleFood and DrinkTravelHomes and GardensCars FamilyYour NIRetroOpinionAdvertise My Businesscanonical_urlCANONICAL_URLhostnameCANONICAL_HOSTNAMElocationCANONICAL_URLreferrerEXTERNAL_REFERRERpage_view_id_PAGE_VIEW_ID_scroll_SCROLL_HEIGHTgeo__INJECT_GEO__cid_ga:CLIENT_ID,comScore:CLIENT_ID,compass_uid:CLIENT_IDversionsha-wJFtySqNnAxBmRbBZGkmXyZeJTYkxlpMdJsFNIrrGVlru-DcIEIZ" class"i-amphtml-layout-container" i-amphtml-layout"container"Loading...NewsAdam Harbinson. WIT  WISDOM: This too shall passWith our recent fine weather I‚Äôve been doing more than my usual five-to- miles a day walking, an activity that, with many of my countrymen, I developed during the lockdown, when there was little  to do, writes Adam Harbinson.By The NewsroomSunday, th April , : am  "       "  Last week was idyllic as I walked along the Donegal coast from Moville to Greencastle it was magical, and it struck me again, that while we all know the value of regular exercise, fresh air and social engagement, we might never really know just how beneficial such days are for our physical and mental health.But what perhaps, on the flipside, will our memories of - be in  years time  We‚Äôll be asking ourselves, how on Earth did we remain sane  Brexit has wreaked havoc on our economy, piled on top of which was Covid-. I can still feel the cloud of gloom that settled on me when a radio announcer was suggesting that all over s would not be allowed outside the door of their homes for  weeks.Thankfully it didn‚Äôt quite come to that.Then came the murderous war in Ukraine, with pictures being flashed onto our screens of European families hiding in cellars in fear or their lives, not to mention the bloody carnage. But how does this bad news affect our mental health To further exacerbate my potential for anxiety I can tell you that five of my close friends and family members are suffering from le-threatening health problems one has even invited me to his rd birthday party, when he and I know full well that in reality it‚Äôs a ‚Äògoing away‚Äô party. I‚Äôm in my mid-s and while I feel as mentally and physically fit as I was in my s, the thing I hate about my age is that so many of my contemporaries are dropping like flies.So, what can we do to protect ourselves  Firstly we must regulate our intake of deadly news regular exercise and getting out into the countryside is helpful too. Gratitude is of vital importance, so let‚Äôs get a pen and paper and make a list of the many aspects of our lives for which we can be truly grateful.But is that enough  You might say no, but since there might be little we can do to help our suffering brothers and sisters, we must recognise the need for serenity to accept the things we cannot change and thecourage to change the things we can.One thing‚Äôs for sure this too will pass. Read more from Adam at www.adamharbinsonbooks Read: Covid- spring booster who is eligible to get it

title: rnli lifeguards set to return for easter
story: Comedy, about members of Tandragee Golf Club in Co Armagh, played out in men‚Äôs locker room   Toome road tragedy: woman dies after crash and man is arrestedNewsCoronavirusTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsHealthBusinessEducationPeopleEnvironmentRead ThisUkraine CrisisFootballIrish League FootballSportMotorcyclingIce HockeyOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleFood and DrinkTravelHomes and GardensCars FamilyYour NIRetroOpinionAdvertise My Businesscanonical_urlCANONICAL_URLhostnameCANONICAL_HOSTNAMElocationCANONICAL_URLreferrerEXTERNAL_REFERRERpage_view_id_PAGE_VIEW_ID_scroll_SCROLL_HEIGHTgeo__INJECT_GEO__cid_ga:CLIENT_ID,comScore:CLIENT_ID,compass_uid:CLIENT_IDversionsha-wJFtySqNnAxBmRbBZGkmXyZeJTYkxlpMdJsFNIrrGVlru-DcIEIZ" class"i-amphtml-layout-container" i-amphtml-layout"container"Loading...NewsRNLI leguards set tofor EasterThe RNLI has revealed leguard statistics from  which show more people than ever visited a leguarded beach in Northern Ireland and needed the help of the charity‚Äôs lesavers.By Una CulkinTuesday, th April , : am  "       "  RNLI leguards at Castlerock BeachDuring the season, leguard teams located on  beaches along the Causeway Coast and in county Down, responded to  incidents, coming to the aid of  people, one of whom was a le saved. The leguards carried out thousands of preventative actions over the summer period which saw an estimated , visitors. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.The latest figures come as RNLI leguards train and prepare toto beaches for the  season.The range of people and activities leguards responded to included paddleboarders, body boarders, swimmers, jet-skiers, those spending time relaxing or walking, quad bikers, kayakers, surfers, paddlers and those on inflatables.Every year, RNLI leguards are involved in carrying out water rescues, administering casualty care, delivering water safety information, and helping to reunite missing children with their families. Over the past few weeks, they have been training and practicing their skills so that they are ready to face what the upcoming season brings.The RNLI will carry out its usual leguard service this year across Northern Ireland in its standard phased approach. The first set of beaches will go on service from this Good Friday,  April, for the Easter holidays. Leguards will patrol beaches at Benone, Portrush East Strand, Portrush West Strand, Whiterocks and Ballycastle from am to pm and Portstewart from am-pm daily until Sunday  April.A weekend service on these beaches will commence on Saturday  April and will run until the peak daily season starts on Saturday  June. Meanwhile, a weekend service on Tyrella Beach in county Down will start from am to pm on Saturday  April.Speaking ahead of the Easter leguard service commencing, Karl O‚ÄôNeill, RNLI Lead Leguard Supervisor said: ‚ÄúRNLI leguards are at the forefront of the charity‚Äôs lesaving work, as they keep beach visitors safe across the Causeway Coast and in county Down each year. Last year‚Äôs figures show the importance of our leguards and what they do for the public. We are expecting coastal areas to be just as busy in the summer season ahead.‚ÄúThe RNLI has been working closely with partners and local communities to ensure beaches and leguard units are ready and equipped, and that leguard training has been performed seamlessly.‚ÄúPre-season preparations have gone well, and our leguards are ready to get back on to the beaches and do what they do best offering preventative safety advice to visitors and rescuing those in dficulty in the water or on the beach itself.‚ÄúHowever, it is important to remember that our leguards can‚Äôt be everywhere. Our leguards will be supported by the charity‚Äôs   leboat service and water safety work, but we urge anyone visiting the coast to take responsibility for themselves and their family.‚ÄùConard McCullough, RNLI Lead Leguard Supervisor added: ‚ÄúHeading to coastal waters is a great way to have fun and stay active, especially during the summer months. But weather conditions can change quickly and,you‚Äôre not careful, you can easily get caught out.‚ÄúIt is important that anyone visiting the coast understands the hazards of the environment. It can be an unpredictable environment, particularly during early summer when the risk of cold water shock signicantly increases, as air temperatures warm but water temperatures remain dangerously cold. We would remind anyone entering the water to take extra care and avoid unnecessary risks as early season conditions are more challenging.‚ÄúTaking basic precautions can greatly reduce the risk of getting into dficulty and improve your chance of being found quickly should you need rescuing. With this in mind, we urge beach visitors to come dressed appropriately to ensure your visit is both safe and enjoyable. For activities like paddleboarding, we‚Äôd recommend you wear a wetsuit, as it will keep you warm in an emergency. Wearing an appropriate buoyancy aid or lejacket is also vital as is carrying a means of calling for help such as a mobile phone in a waterproof pouch.‚ÄùThe RNLI is urging anyone visiting the coast this Easter to make sure they keep themselves and their families safe by following beach safety advice:Visit a leguarded beach and swim between the red and yellow flagsCheck the weather forecast, tide times and read local hazard signage to understand local risksKeep a close eye on your family ‚Äì on the beach and in the water ‚Äì don‚Äôt allow your family to swim aloneIf you fall into water unexpectedly, float to live. Fight your instinct to thrash around, lean back, extend your arms and legs, and float.In an emergency, dial  or  and ask for the Coastguard.Read more: New date for Raft Race RNLINorthern IrelandCauseway Coast  "       "   for the newsletterKeep up with the latest news and views from NorthernIrelandWorldSign Up       " d"M.,.c-.-.-.-.-.-.c-.-.-.-.,-.c.-.,.-.,.,l.-. c.,.,.,.,.,c.-.,.-.,-.L,.c.,.,.,.,,.C.,.,.,.,.,." title: curry s fun park opens in portrush
story: AFTER months of waiting, Currys Fun Park in Portrush is finally open! The eagerly anticipated successor to the popular Barrys Amusements opened its doors for the first time on Saturday amid great excitement. Hundreds of people young and old filed through the doors all afternoon as the magic ed to Portmagic - and just in time for Easter. The good news is that Currys is now up and running, boasting all the old Barrys favourites and adding some new ones too. And for those with old Barrys tokens - no, you cant use them, but you can help the RNLI by dropping them into collection boxes dotted around the complex. The fun park has chosen the charity as its partner - a thoughtful gesture given the important work volunteers do in the waters off the north coast. But for now, after two years of zero craic because of the pandemic, all roads lead to the Port and what promises to be a fun-filled holiday period. Happy days.  addthis,     Leave your commentTyrone Constitution- High Street, OmaghBT BDTel:    n n nHome n n nNews n n nCommunity Lestyle n n nNews n n nGallery n n n n nSport n n nFootball n n nGAA n n nRugby n n nGolf n n nMotor Sports n n nOther n n n n nMotors n n n " Jobs n n n " Classieds n n n " Book an ad n n n " View an ad n n n n n " Announcements n n n " Book an announcement n n n " View an announcement n n n n nGallery n n n " Book an ad n n n " Order your photos n n n " Advertise with us n n nOther titles n n n " Antrim  n n n " Ballycastle Chronicle n n n " Ballymena  n n n " Ballymoney Chronicle n n n " Coleraine Chronicle n n n " County Down Outlook n n n " Limavady Northern Constitution n n n " Newry Democrat n n n " Strabane Weekly News n n n " Tyrone Courier n n n " Ulster Gazette n n n n nHome Delivery n n nDigital Paper n n n n n n bannerbox_faebfefac   n n. n n n n .remove n n n n n n n" .html.html  n n nHome n n nNews n n nCommunity Lestyle n n nNews n n nGallery n n n n nSport n n nFootball n n nGAA n n nRugby n n nGolf n n nMotor Sports n n nOther n n n n nMotors n n n " Jobs n n n " Classieds n n n " Book an ad n n n " View an ad n n n n n " Announcements n n n " Book an announcement n n n " View an announcement n n n n nGallery n n nOther titles n n n " Antrim  n n n " Ballycastle Chronicle n n n " Ballymena  n n n " Ballymoney Chronicle n n n " Coleraine Chronicle n n n " County Down Outlook n n n " Limavady Northern Constitution n n n " Newry Democrat n n n " Strabane Weekly News n n n " Tyrone Courier n n n " Ulster Gazette n n n n nHome Delivery n n nDigital Paper n n n n n n bannerbox_ddbdaffeceeeecec   n n. n n n n .remove n n n n n n n" .html.html .  ,.vc_most_readMost Popular Stories.   , ]]      []js  d js.id  idjs.src  "connect.facebook.net en_US #xfbmlversionv."fjs[],p ^http: .test http:httpsjs+: fjspo  text javascript   truepo.src  https:apis.google js plusone.js s  document[] s

title: familiar faces on this week s rare breed
story: UTV‚Äôs hit farming series, ‚ÄòRare Breed - A Farming Year‚Äô, s on Tuesday th April at pm. The families are bringing in their ious harvests and making preparations for next year. It‚Äôs October, and on the shores of Strangford Lough the Elliott family rear turkeys. The family have years of experience looking after the birds and yet Mark and Olive are still fascinated by their behaviour. Olive comments that they are ‚Äòextremely inquisitive‚Äô. While Mark is making sure the turkeys are well fed, his mum Olive can‚Äôt help giving them an extra treat. She comments too, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do without my family, I have to be so nice to them at the minute!‚Äù Mark points out that they have been receiving orders for Christmas since August, which is ‚Äòabsolutely nuts.‚Äô Near Kilcoo in the Mourne Mountains, Aine Devlin is preparing her flock for the most critical part of her farming year- breeding season. Aine is keeping an eye on her rams to make sure they‚Äôre doing their job. She coats their chests with paint to see which ewes they have been with. Aine laughs, ‚ÄúThis is his cologne for the girls!‚Äù For her AI is not the way to go as the ewes would then all lamb on the same day on the mountain. She loves this time of year and is proud of the part she plays in the economy. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs better than buying produce from down the road from your neighbours and local communities ‚Äù she says. Outside Crossgar, Richard Orr is thinking ahead to next year‚Äôs wheat crop. It‚Äôs all about the planning and attention to detail to make sure the groundwork is done right. He‚Äôs conscious of the environment, saying, ‚ÄúThe major thing in the world is carbon footprint. Chemicals have made farming easy, and modern machinery has damaged the structure of the soil - we need to rebuild that.‚Äù Meanwhile, just outside Portadown it‚Äôs all hands on deck for apple harvest at the McKeever family farm. There isn‚Äôt a high yield this year but sometimes things not going to plan can be a blessing. Pat talks about the seven to eight weeks of hell and this year pickers have been hard to get. Peter comments, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs half the battle when you have good people around.‚Äù On the Donegal   Londonderry border, potato farmer Jamie Rankin and his team are coming towards the end of their harvest. He enjoys the early starts and says, ‚ÄúWhat you do before dinner time‚Äôs your day‚Äôs work.‚Äù While it‚Äôs a job Jamie enjoys, it also comes with challenges as winter months close in. The bad weather has led to reduced yields and a late harvest, but he‚Äôs very proud to have produced a good crop. UTV‚Äôs Mark McFadden narrates the series. Sponsored by Moy Park, ‚ÄòRare Breed ‚Äì A Farming Year‚Äô continues on Tuesday th April at pm on UTV.  addthis,     Leave your commentTyrone Constitution- High Street, OmaghBT BDTel:     , ,, , , title: april showers keep them shorter
story: Spring has finally sprung and with rising energy costs there is no better time to dust off old habits and create some new ones that are good for your pocket and the environment. Start by thinking how much water you are using each day. Whether you are washing your hands, cleaning endless amounts of dishes or getting through that mountain of washing, you start to realise just how important water is and the sheer amount we use. NI Water‚Äôs Environmental Outreach  Learning Officer, Anna Killen, explains how we can save water by looking at everyday habits, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs amazing to think that each day each person uses around  litres of water! However, saving water can be really easy, there are simple things we can all do that can make a huge dference. ‚ÄúDid you know that the average time people in Northern Ireland spend in the shower is  minutes, over % of people still overfill the kettle and less than frac of people have a waterbutt ‚Äù  ‚ÄúWe want that to change and it‚Äôs easy, start by looking at small changes for example, your kettle, since working from home it has have been working overtime, but just fill with as much water as you need. Overfilling can use twice as much energy and water, each time you boil. ‚ÄúWith rising energy costs, it might be time to think about reducing the time spent in the shower, hot water costs money! Why not try the  minute shower challenge, put on your favourite  minute song and seeyou can finish before the end.‚Äù To help you embed with these new habits and ‚ÄòGet Water Fit‚Äô, complete our online water audit at https:www.getwaterfit or take part in water saving challenges and receive your free water saving items including  minute shower timer, toothy timers and swell gel bags for the garden. Some water saving tips:  Turn off the tap when brushing your teeth - A running tap can use  litres ofwater per minute.  Use a bowl for washing vegetables - Then you can reuse this water for plants.  Make full use of your washing machine - Half load programmes on washing machines use more than half the water and energy of a full load, so wait until the machine is full before switching it on.  Fix leaking taps - A dripping tap can waste more than  litres of water per week.  Keep a jug of water in the fridge, instead of letting the tap run cold. NI Water are encouraging customers to sign up to its free text alert service which keeps them updated about anything that may impact on their water supply or any of our other services in the area.here
